Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: IGUALDAD E INCLUSIÓN SOCIAL
Outcome: Bienes y servicios sociales de calidad, universales, inclusivos y resilientes
Output: 2.2 Mejoradas las políticas y los servicios de educación de calidad, incluidas la educación en materia de derechos humanos, educación sexual integral, educación alimentaria y nutricional, educación ambiental y desarrollo integral de la primera infancia
Sub-Output: National Initiative on Education for Sustainable Development  for 2030 - Dominican Republic
Description:
With the support of the Japanese Funds-in-Trust, UNESCO, in response to a request for technical assistance from the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources of the Dominican Republic, implemented the national assessment on ESD. 

Output: Country initiatives designed for implementation by Member States through increased capacities of the education systems and individuals in support of sustainability:

Activities in the Dominican Republic: Develop an overview of the legal and policy context in which ESD is delivered, including laws, policies, regulations, education sector guidelines and standards, environment regulations, and other areas studied by Evaluation of the National Initiative; analyze, based on the Evaluation of the National Initiative on ESD interviews, the materials reviewed in terms of the needs of the education sector, with a particular focus on Priority areas of ESD action for 2030, and identify GAPS and make recommendations to ensure the National Initiative on ESD.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: An initiative to devise a National Education Strategy for Sustainable Development has been launched in the Dominican Republic. The strategy seeks to reveal the challenges, opportunities and the roadmap to follow in terms of sustainability in order to align efforts in the conception of sustainable economic development, environmental conservation and social equity.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: Peace: A peaceful, fair, and inclusive society
Outcome: Outcome 6: A peaceful, fair and inclusive society promoted through social participation, transparency and democratic governance, respecting the secularity of the State and ensuring human rights for all
Output: 6.1 Legislation, public policies and institutional capacities strengthened and aligned with international human rights standards to protect, prevent and respond to violence, crime, exploitation, neglect and discrimination, including against groups in situations of greater vulnerability or emergency, considering gender, race, ethnicity, origin, nationality and age, ensuring democratic and transparent governance with broad social participation and access to justice
Sub-Output: UNOPS 21588 Implementation of Social-educational Infrastructure with the Ministry of Human Rights
Description: The project aims to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Human Rights by jointly designing and building 3 social-educational centers for youth offenders and operation and maintenance plans.
Agencies: United Nations Office for Project Services
SDG Targets: 16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative: In 2021 the project developed a study on investment parameters for social-educational infrastructure for youth offenders and architectural and engineering designs for 3 new social-educational centers. These results will enable youth to serve social-educational measures in higher quality spaces and closer to their families, improving the effectiveness of the social-educational system and promoting human rights.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, the project developed a study on female socio-educational infrastructure to identify the greatest investment needs. It also developed detailed designs for two male social-educational centers for youth offenders, incorporating sustainability, economy and humanization of environments. Documentation was prepared for the bidding of these works in 2023.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: PE3 Paz sostenible, inclusiva e igualitaria para el ejercicio de la  democracia y el goce de una sociedad más segura y justa
Outcome: E6 Al 2026, las instituciones salvadoreñas fortalecen la  gobernabilidad democrática garantizando el Estado de  Derecho y la participación política y cívica inclusiva, así  como la prevención y combate de la corrupción, fomentando  la transparencia y la rendición de cuentas.
Output: E6P4 Instituciones públicas, la sociedad civil, el sector privado, y la población en situación de  vulnerabilidad, cuentan con habilidades y capacidades fortalecidas, mecanismos, espacios de  participación cívicos y políticos, y procesos electorales, para la incidencia y toma de decisiones  políticas, económicas, sociales y culturales, en particular en las agendas de paz y gobernabilidad.
Sub-Output: Citizenship 2.0 Civic education to increase citizen participation in public decision making-128565
Description: The project will work with the Supreme Electoral Tribunal and civil society organizations to promote citizen participation through capacity building for the exercise of political rights and the elimination of political violence, with emphasis on youth, women, people with disabilities and LGBTI people. Likewise, civic education processes will be promoted for citizens in general, with emphasis on young people and, especially, for those who may participate in the electoral processes as part of the Voting Boards. The two areas of work to be developed will be: a) Work with political parties and CSOs on political violence for its prevention and control; b) Development of virtual/interactive courses on the political system and the role of the electoral bodies, with emphasis on young people.
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme
Contributing partners: Government of the Netherlands, United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: El Salvador Tribunal Supremo Electoral
SDG Targets: 16.8 Broaden and strengthen the participation of developing countries in the institutions of global governance.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity), Persons With Disabilities, Youth, Women & Girls
2022 Narrative: Con insumos de las instituciones nacionales de los tres órganos de Estado y municipalidades y liderados por el tribunal electoral, ONU Mujeres y el PNUD en alianza con IDEA Internacional, presentaron el estudio de “participación política igualitaria, una contribución al desarrollo sostenible”. El estudio busca hacer visible la situación de las mujeres en la administración pública, y que sea utilizado como una herramienta para la toma de decisiones inclusivas e igualitarias. Consta de 40 indicadores y 8 dimensiones que fueron utilizados para identificar los avances y desafíos de la participacion política de las mujeres en El Salvador.La sociedad civil a través de la Red para una Democracia Paritaria -la red es un colectivo compuesto por diversidad de instituciones, con diferentes naturalezas, orígenes, regulaciones, etc. Pero con un propósito común- se entregó al Tribunal electoral y al Instituto de Desarrollo de la mujer una “Propuesta de Protocolo de atención a víctimas de violencia política”, para que el TSE tenga insumos para reglamentar la nueva obligación legal de elaborar un protocolo de atención para las mujeres víctimas de violencia, recopilar información de ese tipo de casos e incorporar en todos los programas de formación y capacitación del Tribunal contenidos para prevenir y erradicar violencia contra mujeres que participan en la vida política electoral".
2023 Narrative: A partir del informe de la Misión de Evaluación de Necesidades (NAM) se contribuyó al fortalecimiento institucional del Tribunal Supremo Electoral para la educación cívica, la modernización de sus sistemas de gestión y la atención de la violencia electoral contra las mujeres. El PNUD facilitó una herramienta para monitorear el progreso del calendario electoral y las decisiones del Organismo colegiado; actualizó el aula virtual de formación electoral y se elaboró y publicó el "primer protocolo de atención para mujeres víctimas de violencia".

Plan name: Marco de Cooperación 2019-2022
Strategic priority: SP 2 - Chile cuenta con una matriz productiva diversificada, con instituciones, normas y políticas que promueven un desarrollo sostenible e inclusivo, basado en la innovación y articulación intersectorial, con énfasis en el sistema educativo y productivo.
Outcome: Outcome 2.1 - Al 2022, se reducen las brechas de integración económica, especialmente aquellas que afectan a mujeres, jóvenes, adultos mayores, pueblos indígenas, población rural, personas con discapacidad y migrantes
Output: Promoción de la participación laboral de las mujeres jóvenes y migrantes en áreas STEM
Sub-Output: Implementación proyecto TU Oportunidad /Second Chance Education
Description:
Durante 2022, SCE Chile puso en marcha una nueva metodología basada en la evidencia de la fase piloto, que considera dos vías de aprendizaje en emprendimiento y empleabilidad, de acuerdo con el perfil de la mujer (principiante/avanzado). Esta metodología es implementada a nivel nacional por AIEP, una institución académica técnica reconocida, con el objetivo de desarrollar un modelo sostenible para el papel de la educación técnica en abordar el empoderamiento económico de mujeres con vulnerabilidad socioeconómica, migrantes e indígenas. Además, esta institución está aprovechando su vasta red de actores privados y públicos para aumentar las oportunidades de las participantes a través de derivaciones a los entornos de emprendimiento y empleo e involucrando a su comunidad de estudiantes y graduados como voluntarios, lo cual es parte del modelo de sostenibilidad del programa.  Actualmente hay 6,476 mujeres participantes; 1,660 mujeres han recibido mentoría por parte de las 140 mentoras voluntarias que pertenecen a la Red de Mentoras Tu Oportunidad, y 542 mujeres han sido capacitadas para convertirse en mentoras de otras mujeres de SCE, así como agentes de cambio en sus comunidades. En términos de impacto, y de acuerdo con la encuesta de seguimiento realizada a las graduadas a los tres y seis meses después de graduarse del Programa, un 37% de las mujeres han mejorado sus ingresos gracias al Programa; el 16% de las mujeres han encontrado empleo gracias al Programa; 20%  ha regresado a la educación formal debido al Programa; 24%  ha iniciado un nuevo negocio debido al Programa y el 36%  ha mejorado el negocio que ya tenían; y un 44% reporta haber continuado con su educación.

El programa también ha fortalecido sus alianzas a nivel nacional y regional, identificando espacios de colaboración y estableciendo protocolos de referencia con el Ministerio del Interior, los gobiernos locales y las organizaciones de la sociedad civil. Específicamente en la región norte del país, se han reforzado las alianzas para la implementación de programas y vinculaciones (SERNAMEG -Servicio Nacional de la Mujer-, SECREDUC -Agencia Regional de Educación). Más importante aún, SCE ha tenido una participación activa en la mesa redonda sobre migración dirigida por la OIM y el ACNUR. En la zona sur, se han desarrollado alianzas en la Región de Magallanes (SERNAMEG, INDAP- Instituto Nacional de Desarrollo Agropecuario, Venezolanos en la Patagonia y otras instituciones de sociedad civil) para incluir a más mujeres de la zona más remota del país, al tiempo que se avanza en el vínculo con las instituciones y agencias actuales para este nuevo período de implementación (Ministerio de Desarrollo Social,  INJUV, Universidad de La Frontera y sociedad civil).

Además, SCE Chile lideró la mesa redonda público-privada "Más mujeres en la educación STEM"  desarrollada conjuntamente con la Fundación País Digital (financiada y apoyada por TELCOs y empresas de Tecnología en Chile) facilitando la discusión entre actores de la sociedad civil, empresas, universidades y gobierno para proporcionar insumos críticos y un enfoque de género para las políticas públicas en educación STEM. Finalmente, SCE Chile elaboró y difundió  un informe de política sobre Educación de Segunda Oportunidad con Perspectiva de Género con buenas prácticas y recomendaciones, contribuyendo a la política pública sobre la educación y capacitación en línea para mujeres adultas.
Agencies: UN Women
Implementation partners: UN Women
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.b Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Geography: Región Metropolitana de Santiago, Región de La Araucanía, Región de Antofagasta, Chile
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: MSDCF 4.3: National institutions strengthened to deliver shock-resilient education and learning
Sub-Output: JAM: Teacher capacity strengthened in digital pedagogies and ICTS to support student learning and assessment in blended and online modalities, with focus on populations significantly displaced by distance education.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Education, Youth and Information
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.b By 2020, substantially expand globally the number of scholarships available to developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States and African countries, for enrolment in higher education, including vocational training and information and communications technology, technical, engineering and scientific programmes, in developed countries and other developing countries.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.,9.5 Enhance scientific research, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries, in particular developing countries, including, by 2030, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.,9.b Support domestic technology development, research and innovation in developing countries, including by ensuring a conducive policy environment for, inter alia, industrial diversification and value addition to commodities.,12.a Support developing countries to strengthen their scientific and technological capacity to move towards more sustainable patterns of consumption and production.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure, 12 Responsible Consumption and Production, 13 Climate Action, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
2023 Narrative: UNESCO Kingston has developed a stock-taking report across the 20 countries it covers, including the Bahamas, with a view of reviewing existing national competency frameworks related to digital competencies of teachers, and of assessing the extent to which they align with UNESCO ICT Competency Framework’s components. The aim of the exercise is to subsequently develop a regional roadmap and guidelines for an effective and relevant integration of the UNESCO ICT competency framework in national frameworks in these countries in order to strengthen teachers’ ICT and competencies and skills. The idea is to offer countries a more comprehensive set of competencies and skills that teachers need to integrate ICT into their professional pedagogies and practices in order to facilitate students’ achievement of curricular objectives. It is envisaged that once developed, the roadmap will be submitted to a consultation across different stakeholders and will be validated through a regional workshop bringing together ministries of education representatives of the different countries.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ1014 Consolidation of SESI's Schools network as reference in the basic education in Brazil
Description: This project aims to contribute to the educational improvement and alignment of SESI's Schools network to the new education model adopted by the Brazilian Government. In this sense, it is essential to develop a new curriculum considering the area of competencies and the educational cycles applied in the SESI's Schools, especially for the upper secondary education, continuous education, and youth and adult education. It will be considered the incorporation of innovative and trend technologies, pedagogical material revision, as well as capacitation of managers, teachers, and other education professionals.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Serviço Social da Indústria
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: This project is on track. Activities are contributing the SESI School system on: supporting the reformulation and readjustment of SESI Network schools to meet the new standards of the SESI Network and the Brazilian educational legislation; supporting teacher training; analyzing the programs and curricula of the SESI Network; supporting the alignment of teaching materials, curricula and pedagogical practices of the SESI Network schools; and Materials distribution for the SESI Network schools to continue their robotics program in schools.
2022 Narrative: This sub-output to guarantee the consolidation of SESI's schools network as a reference in the basic education in Brazil is on track and the main results for 2022 have been achieved. To that end, the strategic impact of SESI Education's priority projects has been promoted, a methodology with quality and teacher training indicators for basic education in the SESI Network has been elaborated; services for the promotion of the strategic impact of SESI Education's priority projects has been provided; pedagogical practices of the SESI Technological Education is being supported; educational activities at SESI Lab Museum in the following subjects: Arts, Math, Physics, Engineering and Natural Sciences are being implemented.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: PE2 Transformación económica hacia un modelo inclusivo, ambiental  y socialmente sostenible, resiliente e innovador.
Outcome: E4 Al 2026, las personas, particularmente las que están en  situación de vulnerabilidad, tienen mayores oportunidades  de acceder a un trabajo decente, productivo y medios de vida  sostenibles, en un entorno de transformación económica  inclusiva, innovadora y sostenible.
Output: E4P1 Instituciones públicas y organizaciones de la sociedad civil cuentan con capacidades y  habilidades técnicas fortalecidas para formular e implementar políticas públicas y marcos  normativos basados en evidencia y diálogo social que promuevan el tránsito hacia el trabajo  decente y su perdurabilidad, así como hacia la economía formal y medios de vida sostenibles;  que aprovechen el bono demográfico, integren el enfoque de género, y desarrollen oportunidades innovadoras principalmente para aumentar la participación económica de las juventudes y de los  grupos en condición de vulnerabilidad
Sub-Output: Scholarships for Educational Opportunities Program
Description:
El proyecto buscará mitigar la migración irregular desde El Salvador y reducir la estigmatización de los retornados al aumentar el acceso equitativo a oportunidades educativas formales para posibles migrantes, retornados y sus familias para generar esperanza, prosperidad y autoestima positiva en sus vidas.

El Sub-Output está alineado con las transiciones de Educación y Empleo y protección social.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: El Salvador Ministerio de Educación, Ciencia y Tecnología
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project promotes activities linked to gender equity through its academic offerings. Women are a prioritized population for enrollment, in particular in non-traditional areas, and individual psychosocial support is delivered considering gender needs. A referral mechanism is in place for specialized assistance related to Gender-Based-Violence (GBV). For women in the scholarship program, the psychological service constitutes a key support for their wellbeing and selfcare, as well as an increase in knowledge and empowerment. In addition, psychosocial services for women contributes to retention, empowerment for employment, and in some cases helps to reduce the pressure from their partners to migrate irregularly.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Human rights approach is considered directly by providing education right to vulnerable population and out-school persons. It is algo a crosscutting theme for psychosocial assistance, including referrals and partnership with human rights specialized institutions.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Los principios transversales relevantes del proyecto son: 1) empoderamiento de las mujeres y equidad de género y 2) desarrollo positivo de juventudes. Esto se toma en cuenta con base en un breve análisis coyuntural, plasmado en el documento de proyecto, que aborda el conflicto o la violencia de la siguiente forma: Una considerable proporción de migrantes irregulares son jóvenes. Esto es debido a necesidades económicas por ausencia de oportunidades, por violencia y por inseguridad; además, muchos jóvenes son objetivos para ser reclutados por pandillas... En este sentido, el proyecto facilita oportunidades educacionales a jóvenes migrantes para garantizar  su desarrollo positivo a través del acceso a trabajo formal y medios de vida.
2023 Narrative: Para diciembre de 2023, el Proyecto facilitó el acceso a empleo/nuevos emprendimientos nuevos o mejorados para 479 beneficiarios de becas (42% hombres, 58% mujeres): 383 becarios (39% hombres y 61% mujeres) accedieron a nuevas actividades laborales/emprendimientos y 96 becarios (55% hombres y 45% mujeres) mejoraron la percepción de la calidad de sus empleos/emprendimientos.  Un total de 2,505 becarios estaban inscritos en los programas educativos: cursos cortos, programas educativos técnicos superiores y programas de educación acelerada.
2024 Narrative: El proyecto brindó oportunidades educativas integrales a 1,909 personas en riesgo de desplazamiento y en condiciones de vulnerabilidad, con el objetivo de reducir la migración irregular y fomentar la esperanza, la prosperidad y la autoestima en sus vidas. Esto incluye a 427 migrantes retornados. Para el año 2024, el proyecto ha alcanzado un total de 7,155 personas desde su inicio.

2024 Narrative: Interactive exhibition (Care Expo) for teenagers in schools in Amazonas, with support from Organon, carried out in partnership with the Manaus Health and Education Departments, in dialogue with youth audiences. It is worth mentioning that this initiative was one of those that received the UNFPA innovation award in 2024 (impact category). It will be scaled-up in 2025 to two other cities in the country.Within the scope of the project “Promoting inclusive opportunities, empowerment and rights for women, young people and families in the recycling chain in Curitiba-Brazil”, supported by Unilever, community dialogues are held regularly, which provide information on health, well-being, self-care and rights for youth and women. Activities included 4 activities for the promotion of information on health and environment (204 participations in total). Also, information materials and 120 dignity and hygiene kits were distributed. The “Oxe, Me Respeite nas Escolas” initiative for providing Comprehensive Sexuality Education in schools, developed by the Government of the State of Bahia in partnership with the UNFPA, was developed in 10 schools. The aim is to reach 1000 schools by the end of 2026. The project aims to mobilize the school community, through educational actions that address the prevention of gender violence and the promotion of sexual and reproductive rights.   Additionally, the project “Salas de Genero” was launched in September, as part of ‘Oxe, Me respeite nas Escolas”. “Salas de Gênero” is an online capacity building for school teachers in Bahia on gender and its intersections.

Description:
The objective of this Joint Programme (JP) is to drive the digital transformation of the education system in Jamaica by prioritizing
digitalization of key processes in the education sector that would ultimately contribute to the achievement of better learning outcomes and higher levels of teacher engagement and retention. Focus on digitalization in education around improving data governance and interoperability of existing and newly developed digital systems within the education sector will strengthen data collection, monitoring, and reporting, and will support improved and more informed decision making within the education sector, including around gender responsiveness. Priority will also be placed on stakeholder capacity building, and institutional strengthening towards enabling data-driven decision-making by education ministry staff and teachers, to improve system-wide efficiency, and foster improved learning outcomes of about 240,000 students (girls and boys) in grades 1 through 6 by the end of the 3 years.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Education, Youth and Information

Contributing partners: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Implementation partners: Jamaica Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.

Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity)
2024 Narrative: TransWave Jamaica continued the conversation around transgender health and advocacy which resulted in stronger partnerships with other trans-led organizations and projects as well as government. This increased the visibility of transgender and gender non-conforming people and their needs, built capacity of not just the team at TransWave but of other trans and gender non-conforming advocates, encouraged community leadership, internal growth and stronger advocacy efforts that is and will continue to benefit our community greatly. The following outputs were achieved: 103 persons engaged (43 police officers, 2 social workers, 2 CSO representatives, 56 trans community members). The activity also included consultation sessions with trans community members to get their feedback on their interactions with service providers and how service can be improved and more gender affirming. 8 IECs produced which reached 15,529 online. The IECs related to trans health and wellness, including the effects of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and PrEP. Three (3) videos were developed around mental health and well-being of trans persons in the workplace, identifying methods of affirmation in the workspace to boost employee morale and personal mental health.  13 ambassadors engaged and 3 trans-led initiatives developed as a result. 10 of the 13 participants (76.9%) showed an increase in knowledge around trans-specific advocacy. 100% of ambassadors willing to implement advocacy activities  Engagement and building capacity of trans-masculine people. Support session with 15 people to discuss bridging the gap between acknowledging the struggles across the trans community and to find solutions to support each other.  TransWave was able to complete 100% of project’s activities and, in some cases, surpassed targets. 43 more persons were reached for the service provision and legal educations trainings, produced three (3) more IECs/videos for the media campaign on trans health, reached 7000+ more accounts, had three (3) more trans ambassadors and one (1) more trans-led initiative developed than originally proposed. Due to this, more people were reached to learn more about the lived experiences of trans and gender non-conforming Jamaicans daily.  Through the residential training, participants felt empowered to advocate for legal reform that protects the rights of transgender individuals in Jamaica. They expressed that they found the training to be useful and gained valuable information as it pertains to advocacy methods and resources, and how much work TransWave must do in the background to advocate for the rights and inclusions of the trans community. The activity allowed TransWave to strengthen partnerships with other trans focused groups to promote increased visibility for the community. Participants included representatives from TranscendX, Cari-Trans Support Group, TransForm, Totally Inspiring Trans (TiTs) and Solidarity Yaad.   TransWave offered support to Cari-Trans which aided them in providing support to the trans-masculine community. The support helped in building partnership with Cari-Trans and allowed TransWave to expand its reach and further in understanding and representing especially the trans-masculine community in Jamaica, who have expressed a desire for more representation and visibility. During a session held by Cari-Trans with support from TransWave, 15 persons across the transgender spectrum came together with six (6) of Cari-Trans’ staff to discuss the challenges each community faces.  A media campaign around physical and mental health of trans persons, as well as the residential training which introduced our Trans Health Strategy to participants allowed the organisation to make some progress towards this objective. The campaigns spoke to the effects of HRT on the body and how it can be used to affirm trans persons, but the posts also shared the other effects of HRT to inform interested persons before accessing treatment. They also spoke to using HRT alongside PrEP as a way of affirming and protecting oneself simultaneously, and focused on building one’s mental health within workspaces, informing employment offices of the effects of transphobic work policies and attitudes on the mental health of trans persons.

2021 Narrative: In 2021 UNICEF increased its evidence-based advocacy efforts for the Safe School Reopening due to devastating impact on children and adolescents not receiving formal or non-formal education during the COVID-19. Through UNICEF supported programmes, 3,078 municipalities and 22 states were engaged and implementing School Active Search (SAS) strategy. In 2021, several events were held, such as lectures, technical meetings, webinars, aiming to mobilize and disseminate the SAS strategy to the new municipal administrations and make them aware of its re-engagement. With that, 19,647 out-of-school children and adolescents were re-enrolled in schools in 2021.
2022 Narrative: Guaranteeing the education rights to children and adolescents is a priority to UNICEF. The evidence-based advocacy activities included development and dissemination of 3 important research on school exclusion data, profile of children and adolescents out of school and the School Active Search (SAS) strategy itself. The SAS strategy has been implemented in more than 3,460 municipalities and 22 states and is a reference to tackle the school exclusion and dropout, two phenomena intensified by the Covid-19 pandemic and other emergencies situations. In 2022 UNICEF supported the identification of more than 311,000 out-of-school children and adolescents and 39,905 were re-enrolled.

2024 Narrative: The “Play, Discover  Learn” curriculum, developed and piloted in 2022 with support from UNICEF, which focuses on the development of children in childcare institutions (creches/daycares) and was further rolled out. Capacity-building efforts successfully extended the program to 10 additional Daycares, including 9 public managed institutions, benefiting 15 daycare workers, 150 children annually, and their parents or caregivers. Overall reach on social media of 13,500 views of the early stimulation and learning content achieved in 2024 with early stimulation and learning content. Building on previous years' progress in strengthening intersectoral collaboration among ECD stakeholders, the development of a national ECD policy was officially launched in 2024 with UNICEF’s support. This process culminated in a draft policy plan, with the Ministry of Education (MoE) leading the coordination efforts.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ3010 Understanding the history of Africa - Strengthening educational spaces sensitive to ethnic-racial discrimination
Description: This project aims to provide opportunities for a better understanding of the historical and cultural origin of African matrices in Brazil and their contributions to the construction of Brazilian identity. It foresees the reprinting of the General History of Africa collection in Portuguese and its respective synthesis, to distribute it to important stakeholders and educators. Webinars to launch this new edition will be developed to broaden the public debate on preventing stigma and racial discrimination in educational spaces.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Instituto Humanize
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNESCO and the Humanize Institute joined forces to develop mutual actions that contribute to reducing inequality and promoting racial and social inclusion in Brazil, by improving the quality of education, in an equitable and inclusive perspective for all.

Outputs:
500 complete collections of the General History of Africa in Portuguese were printed and distributed to public schools, key institutions and partners working on providing opportunities for a better understanding of the historical-cultural origin of African matrices in Brazil and their contributions to the construction of national identity.
A webinar took place in November 2021to demonstrate to education partners the importance of using the published materials.

Outcomes:
This project supported the recognition, among schools and educational institutions, of the value of African culture and the importance of its influence on Brazilian history. It contributed to disseminate the value of the African contribution to the history of Brazil and to promote the inclusion of Afro-descendants in the country's educational system, in addition to developing actions to promote racial equality.

New partners that followed the Webinar have contacted UNESCO for possible similar partnerships in other states in the country.

Challenges and lessons-learnt:
It was a challenge to agree on a common list for distribution and also to store the publications once they arrived. The issue was partly solved as the Office was rather empty due to the pandemic and we were able to use the meeting rooms to store the publications. This helped to accelerate the distribution process.

Contribution to C/5 and SDGs:
This project contributed to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 4 - Quality education, as well as to SDG 10 - Reduction of Inequalities, in addition to contributing to SHS ER1 and the struggle against racial inequalities, it also contributed to ED ER 1.
2022 Narrative: The project ended in February of 2022. It was a very important experience to UNESCO and Humanize Institute. We had the opportunity to produce 500 complete collections of the General History of Africa in Portuguese and distribute them to public schools, key institutions and partners working on providing opportunities for a better understanding of the historical-cultural origin of African matrices in Brazil and their contributions to the construction of national identity. A webinar took place in November 2021 to demonstrate to education partners the importance of using the published materials.This project supported the recognition, among schools and educational institutions, of the value of African culture and the importance of its influence on Brazilian history. It contributed to disseminate the value of the African contribution to the history of Brazil and to promote the inclusion of Afro-descendants in the country's educational system, in addition to developing actions to promote racial equality.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Outcome: 2.1 Até 2027, o Brasil terá ampliado e fortalecido a proteção social e demais políticas públicas para serem mais intersetoriais, inclusivas, participativas e efetivas, baseadas em evidências, atentas a grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e orientadas, em todos os níveis de governo, ao respeito aos direitos humanos e à redução da pobreza, da fome e das desigualdades de grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e à promoção da igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia e do desenvolvimento sustentável ambiental e socialmente.

Sub-Output: UNICEF - Output 2.2 - Education initiatives to address the culture of school failure and to foster the development of foundational skills of children and adolescents
Description: Girls and boys have increased permanence in the basic education system, based on intersectoral policies addressing diversity, including contextualized education. UNICEF initiatives to support states and municipalities in the implementation of programs to address the culture of school failure and consequently propose actions for students to develop competencies and skills defined by the National Curriculum (BNCC), through the initiative Successful School Pathways (SSP). UNICEF will prioritize the Amazon and Semiarid regions via the initiative Selo UNICEF, engaging over 1,800 municipalities and 18 states, as well as engagement with government actors at the federal and subnational levels. UNICEF will prioritize the Amazon and Semiarid regions via the initiative Selo UNICEF, engaging over 1,800 municipalities and 18 states, as well as engagement with government actors at the federal and subnational levels. In addition, UNICEF will prioritize urban geographies affected by armed violence, more specifically 08 large urban centers (Belém, Fortaleza, Manaus, Recife, Rio de Janeiro, Salvador, São Luís e São Paulo), as well as engagement with government actors at the federal and subnational levels.

2023 Narrative: UNICEF trained almost 60.000 teachers, through strategies related to: the development of foundational and transferable skills; quality early childhood education; hybrid education practices and connectivity improvements; creation of contextualized curriculums; and education that protects. These initiatives allowed around 5 million students benefited from skills development programs in 7 states, which joined the Successful School Pathways (SSP) strategy, 8 capitals of the UNICEF City Agenda and 2,023 municipalities of the UNICEF Seal. Besides that, UNICEF organized workshops and materials to address learning recovery and violence prevention, bringing together different stakeholders committed with quality basic education for all.

2021 Narrative: UNICEF promoted equitable and inclusive education practices in Brazil through the skills development programmes to face school failure which reached almost 20,000 students. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, UNICEF strengthened the capacity of municipal and state education policy makers to address the challenges of school closure and developed a set of materials to enhance activities related to digital culture and quality hybrid education. New audio materials for early learning have reached out to more than 135 thousand children and their families.
2022 Narrative: UNICEF promoted skills development programmes to face school failure which reached 78,740 students directly and 342,576 indirectly, since early childhood education. 26,960 teachers and managers were trained on innovative curricula development, quality of early childhood education, education that protects, inclusive education and hybrid education, through 08 online and 05 face-to-face courses. These actions took place in 10 partner states of the SSP Strategy, in 10 capitals, and in 1,272 municipalities under the UNICEF Seal. All benefited teachers and students were part of the development of innovative methodologies to promote School Success Pathways for every child and adolescent.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: 3. Meio Ambiente e Mudança do Clima para o Desenvolvimento Sustentável
Outcome: 3.2 Até 2027, o Brasil terá avançado na implementação de ações de mitigação da mudança do clima e adaptação aos seus efeitos, redução do desmatamento, de riscos de desastres, considerando os grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade, inclusive pessoas forçadamente deslocadas, a partir da perspectiva de geração, gênero, raça e etnia, e proteção dos territórios dos povos indígenas, dos povos e comunidades tradicionais e das populações do campo, floresta e águas em geral, com vistas a promover uma economia resiliente e descarbonizada, à luz dos marcos legais e regulatórios nacionais, e com alinhamento aos compromissos internacionalmente vigentes.
Output: 3.2.3 Capacidades institucionais e das comunidades e grupos expostos a riscos de sofrer os impactos da mudança do clima fortalecidas, tendo em vista o aprimoramento contínuo dos diversos setores socioeconômicos brasileiros, incluindo a harmonização com padrões e boas práticas de sustentabilidade, resiliência, descarbonização e incentivos à produção, ao consumo e descarte sustentáveis.
Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1019 Brazilian National Environmental Education Strategy strengthened
Description: This project aims to improve national strategies for implementing Environmental Education Policies and Programmes through the institutionalisation and mainstreaming of Environmental Education (EE) in multiple national-level plans and programmes, starting with those managed by the Ministry of the Environment. This strategy will be strengthened through activities that seek to dialogue with the axes of the National Environmental Education Programme (ProNEA): (1) Management and Planning of Environmental Education, (2) Training in Environmental Education, (3) Communication for Environmental Education - Educommunication (4) Monitoring and evaluation of environmental education policies, programmes and projects, with the expansion of social participation in the formulation and monitoring of public environmental policies.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation

SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The gender equity strategy of this project is fundamental to ensuring the inclusion and active participation of women at all stages. Aligned with UNESCO's perspective on women and science, and women and oceans, the initiative seeks to promote gender equality in the environmental and scientific fields. UNESCO emphasizes the importance of empowering women to play transformative and ambitious roles in understanding, exploring, protecting, and sustainably managing the oceans. This project, focused on Youth, Environment, and Sustainable Development, aims not only to involve young women in environmental actions but also to empower them to lead initiatives addressing critical issues such as biodiversity, climate change, and socio-environmental justice. By integrating these perspectives, the project contributes to reducing gender inequalities and strengthens community resilience in the face of environmental challenges.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the Brazilian Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change (MMA), with the support of UNESCO, has made significant progress in harmonizing national standards and promote good practices on sustainability amongst groups vulnerable to climate change, notably youth. The National Plan for Youth and the Environment (PNJMA) has been restructured, with active participation from various MMA Secretariats, the National Youth Secretariat, and UNESCO. As a result, integration of youth policies with environmental actions have been strengthened. The development of the environmental education strategy has started, and it aims to reach young people across the country, promoting important dialogues on biodiversity, desertification, extreme weather events, and socio-environmental justice. Finally, technical expertise has been given to start the organization of the National Youth Conference, scheduled for March 2025, with extensive mobilization of young people and partner entities. No financial disbursement was made in 2024.

2021 Narrative: UNICEF leads the education sector and its response, having built up efforts for the provision of non-formal education services, for the identification, documentation, and enrollment of out of school children and adolescents. The strategies include maintaining 26 child friendly spaces that befitted almost 14,000 boys and girls, provision of education services, training of almost 800 professionals, distribution of learning material, supporting local authorities for their sufficient and adequate response, including sensitization on indigenous specific needs, and awareness raising on protection, gender, and xenophobia.
2022 Narrative: As the coleader of R4V Education Sector, UNICEF plays a key role at the Migratory emergency response, continuously backing up local governments for an adequate and sensitive response to refugee and migrant children and adolescents, considering the specific needs of indigenous, girls, and people with disabilities. It reached 18,208 beneficiaries, providing non-formal services at 26 child-friendly spaces and supporting the integration of Venezuelan students in the formal education system. In addition to the identification, documentation, and enrollment of out of school children and adolescents, the strategies include the training of professionals, distribution of material and maintenance of learning spaces.

2024 Narrative: Through UNICEF support, local capacity for data-driven decision making in Education was strengthened. As part of these efforts, EMIS training was provided to 92 head teachers, teachers, and data entry clerks from 24 schools (6 nursery, 16 primary and 2 secondary), allowing for the electronic tracking of 4,685 students' records including attendance. This support benefitted 11 schools in region 1, one of Guyana's interior indigenous regions. Schools with internet connectivity now have the ability to update students' records in real-time while others can utilize the offline EMIS capability which gets updated on a monthly basis. From this support, enrollment and attendance information is readily available at the school level for both teachers and students and can be used for informed planning and resource allocation in order to improve education outcomes.

2024 Narrative: Support for student care and well-being continuing in 2024 with an expanded implementation of the mental health education program, in collaboration with the Ministry of Education (MoE), across secondary schools led to a total of 44 student counselors from 7 of Suriname’s 10 districts being trained in the use of a mental health video series (12 videos) and learning plans. This enabled them to conduct mental health education and information sessions in their schools. In addition, mental health awareness posters distributed to 150 secondary schools led to a potential of reaching approximately 35,000 students.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO provided technical assistance to the following SESI’s priority activities: production of guidelines on distance learning; teacher training; modernization of learning environments; analysis of the conclusion levels on basic education and adult learning and education; education management monitoring; education projects management; digital management system; revision of early childhood education pedagogical guidelines; and methodologies to promote the consolidation of quality education. Technical support was provided to the national and international phases of the SESI Robotics Festival, including the script and the festival’s overall planning. Additionally, support was provided to the implementation of regional SESI teachers’ training sessions, as well as to the organization of the event celebrating 10 years of Movimento pela Base, a non-governmental and non-partisan network, which is dedicated to supporting and monitoring the implementation of the National Common Curricular Base.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, SESI and UNESCO have made significant progress in adapting SESI's network of schooles according to the new education model adopted by the Brazilian Government as a means to enhance management capacities to promote quality education. Substantive techinal assistance and knowledge sharing was promoted throughout the year to produce guidelines on distance learning, develop capacity-building courses for teachers, update learning environments, manage and monitor educational programmes and digital systems, and revise early childhood education pedagogical guidelines. Technical advice was also provideed to develop SESI's Robotics Festival.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1075 Annual SDG 4-Education 2030 agenda workplan (2018-2019-AE), agency execution, with the Ministry of Education - National Museum Rio de Janeiro
Description: A fire occurred on 2 September 2018 which destroyed one of the most important scientific and anthropological institutions in Latin America, the National Museum at Rio de Janeiro, constituting the greatest tragedy for Brazilian culture and education in recent times. After the fire, an Emergency UNESCO Mission was mobilized to act at the National Museum, in coordination with national and local authorities and technical teams. The Mission contributed to planning the first rescue and emergency actions and the final report proposed a plan of action for the reconstruction of the National Museum.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Geography: Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: In 2021, the consortium integrated by the companies H+F Architects and Atelier Arquitetura began the development of the Basic Architecture and Restoration Project of the São Cristóvão Palace, historic gardens and annex building of the National Museum of Rio de Janeiro. In addition to the Architecture and Restoration Project and other complementary projects, UNESCO also hired in 2021 management and BIM (Building Information Modelling) consulting services to make technical projects compatible and integrated. Finally, it is important to highlight the launching of the virtual platform Projeto Museu Nacional Vive, in order to inform about the evolution of the global recovery works.
2022 Narrative: The project in partnership with the Ministry of Education came to an end, presenting relevant results for the recuperation of the National Museum, the Project Museu Nacional Vive. Under the project were developed the conceptual and technical bases for the restoration of the Paço de São Cristóvão, headquarters of the Museum. The architecture and restoration project of the Palace, the historic gardens and the annex building Alipio de Miranda Ribeiro as well as the complementary projects were also elaborated (at a level of Basic Project), reveling great knowledge of the monument, and museological solutions for the renewal equipment. Management and BIM (Building Information Modelling) services guaranteed the integration and compatibilization of the technical projects. The virtual platform Projeto Museu Nacional Vive, informs the general public the evolution of the global recovery works. An open-air exhibition about the Project will be open at the celebration of the Bicentenary of the Independence of Brazil, in September 2022. A final Progresss Report was prepared for the Ministry of Education. UNESCO contribution to the reconstruction of the National Museum continues under project 570RLA4000.

2021 Narrative:
In 2021 the project developed a diagnostic study of the Brazilian social-educational system for youth offenders, benchmarking of national and international experiences, architectural designs for 4 new social-educational centers with special considerations for girls, pre-feasibility studies for the PPP management model, economic-financial and legal modeling, and draft contracting documents.  These results will enable youth to serve social-educational measures in higher quality spaces and closer to their families, improving the effectiveness of the social-educational system and promoting human rights.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: People:  An inclusive and equitable society with full rights for all
Outcome: Outcome 1: Strengthened social development throughout the country, with poverty reduction through access to quality public goods and services, particularly in the areas of education, health, welfare, food and nutritional security and decent work, equitably and with emphasis on gender, racial, ethnic and generational equality
Output: 1.1 Public policies and institutional capacities strengthened in the areas of education, health, social assistance, food security and nutrition and decent work in order to address the needs of the most vulnerable groups and promote gender, race, ethnicity throughout the life course
Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1102  Higher Education and the National Education Plan: the commitment to quality and training for work and citizenship
Description: This project aims to promote Brazilian higher education by improving innovative actions implemented by the Ministry of Education's Secretariat of Higher Education (SESu). The project proposal consists in expanding new methodologies for teachers' and managers' training; studies evaluating access, permanence and insertion in the labor market; improvement of health residency programs; incentive to improve academic-institutional management; and strategies internationalization for higher education.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: ME - Ministério da Educação
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
This project aims to promote Brazilian higher education by improving innovative actions implemented by the Ministry of Education. The expansion of new methodologies for training teachers and managers are proposed; studies to assess programs for access and insertion in the labor market; improvement of residency programs in health; encouraging the advancement of academic-institutional management, and higher education internationalization strategies.
 
In 2020, more than 8.6 million enrollments were registered by the Higher Education Census, with 1.2 million graduating students. In addition, 3.7 million students entered an undergraduate course that year. The survey also found that 323,376 teachers worked at the educational level in 2020. The survey revealed 2,457 higher education institutions in Brazil on the census reference date. Of these, 2,153 (87.6%) are private and 304 (12.4%) are public. Private institutions registered 3.2 million new entrants, representing 86% of the total.
 
Public universities and federal technical institutes in Brazil are now required to reserve at least 50% of the vacancies for the following students:
who have completed high school in public schools (schooling criteria);
with income per capita of up to a minimum wage and a half (socioeconomic criterion);
with a proportional distribution of vacancies among blacks, browns, and indigenous people (ethnic-racial criterion).
 
 
Considering the main results of the last semester, the Project managed to achieve the main proposed results, that is:
Studies on the effectiveness of public universities and higher education institutions on the National Student Assistance Program - PNAES, from 2016 to 2020.
Studies analyze ?ows and methodologies to provide further ef?ciency and e?ectiveness to tax regularity within the scope of the University for All Program (Prouni).
Study to analyze the impacts of COVID-19 on the internationalization actions of Brazilian Federal Institutions of Higher Education (IFES). 
Developed an analytical study for the adequacy of public universities in the context of the vacancies offered and the number of first-year students.
Developed an analytical study regarding the redistribution of vacancy posts among Public universities. 
Study to identify the impacts of COVID-19 on the Student-Graduate Agreement Program (PEC-G) and the Milton Santos Program for Access to Higher Education ( PROMISES).
 
The pandemic improved the Ministry of Education's relationship with higher education institutions, as well as higher education in Brazil. Health courses, priority and educational strategies were prioritized.
 
Contribution to Global Priority Gender Equality:
Considering that the enrollment profile of women in Brazilian public universities is predominantly concentrated on women, this population group ends up benefiting from the actions developed by the project. That is, the evaluation of the profile of university entrances, as well as the analysis of funding for payment of private universities, proportionally benefits young women. This project contributes to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) and UNESCO's global priority for gender equity. The actions guarantee equal access and permanence for all in higher education.

Contribution to Priority Group Youth:
Teenagers and young people are the primary students at Public universities in Brazil. The universities could be linked to the central government, states, and municipalities. The universities' object of this project intervention is the universities connected to the ministry of education, called federal universities. Students at Brazilian higher education institutions have an evident profile: they are white, female, aged between 19 and 24, study in private institutions at night, completed high school in a public school, live with their parents, and have to work to earn an income of up to two minimum wages. In both public and private higher education institutions, most students come from public high schools. In the case of private higher education, 68.5% of students came from public high schools and 31.5% from private. In public higher education institutions, 60.1% came from public high schools, and 39.9% came from private high schools.

Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: Living Water Community, Trinidad and Tobago Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Preliminary reporting as at the end of Q3-
At September 30, 2022, there were 2,005 children enrolled in primary education and 423 children enrolled in secondary education initiatives. The Education Working Group, in which UNHCR participates, continues to collaborate with UNICEF and other agencies, including the Ministry of Education, to advocate for inclusion of children of refugees, asylum-seekers and migrants in the public school system
2022 Narrative: At December 31, 2022, enrollment figures for primary and education initiatives stood at , there were 1,175 children for primary and 257 children for secondary education. The Education Working Group, in which UNHCR participates, continues to collaborate with UNICEF and other agencies, including the Ministry of Education, to advocate for inclusion of children of refugees, asylum-seekers and migrants in the public school system
2023 Narrative: In July 2023, the government of Trinidad and Tobago announced that migrant children would be admitted into national schools, which was later approved by the cabinet. The Education Working Group (EWG), chaired by UNICEF and including UNHCR, continued to prepare for integration by identifying refugee and migrant children who meet the Government’s criteria for admission, training teachers to educate refugee and migrant children and meeting weekly to strategize on ways to support the Government with inclusion. UNHCR also procured school supplies in preparation for inclusion and supported the purchase of 408 access codes for refugee and migrant children of primary and secondary school ages to access online learning platforms.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1149 Strategies and tools development to strengthen and consolidate school maintenance public policies as national and international references in excellent educational public policies
Description: This Project aims to improve the institutional capacity of the National Education Development Fund - FNDE, in particular the General Coordination of Support for School Maintenance (CGAME), the Educational Actions Board (DIRAE), to become a national and international reference in public transport and school maintenance policies excellence. The proposed results should contribute to the improvement of these educational policies and, as a consequence, reduce educational inequality and achieve better access and learning rates for Brazilian students.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR National Fund for Educational Development
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Achieved results – 1st semester 2022
- Document in progress with a survey of projects and national and international innovative actions that support the FNDE programs.
 
- Improvement in the process of monitoring the management of the programs  -  BI panel with data on the three FNDE school maintenance programs
 
- Presentation of a detailed proposal for calls for proposals to establish new partnerships with educational and research institutions to strengthen support for the management of school maintenance programs and for the identification and dissemination of innovative management experiences.
 
2) Main difficulties
The project is still very new, and the project team is not yet familiar with UNESCO's hiring and accountability processes.
 
3) Potential risks and mitigation measures
As the project team, on the part of FNDE, does not yet know in depth the necessary procedures for the execution of the project, there was a risk of hiring being done outside the expected standard. As a mitigation measure, the team has been going through a series of training with the UNESCO team, in order to feel safe to carry out the necessary actions.
 
4) Lessons learned
An important lesson was the constant need for communication and training of FNDE's staff, to ensure that all hirings and accountability are correct.
Contribution to Global Priority Gender Equality:
All activities developed are gender-balanced.
2022 Narrative: Document in progress with a survey of projects and national and international innovative actions that support the FNDE programs.- Improvement in the process of monitoring the management of the programs - BI panel with data on the three FNDE school maintenance programs- Presentation of a detailed proposal for calls for proposals to establish new partnerships with educational and research institutions to strengthen support for the management of school maintenance programs and for the identification and dissemination of innovative management experiences.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: MSDCF 4.3: National institutions strengthened to deliver shock-resilient education and learning
Sub-Output: JAM: Technical Assistance for Health and Family Life Education
Agencies: United Nations Joint Programme on HIV and AIDS Secretariat
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Education, Youth and Information
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.), Women & Girls, Children , Youth
2024 Narrative: The Ministry of Education, Skills, Youth and Information (MoESYI) strengthened the capacity of educators to deliver the sexuality component of the HFLE curriculum. Through the partnership with UNAIDS, the MoESYI finalized its draft Sexuality Education Training Manual and facilitated the training of 27 HFLE teachers in Sexuality Education. A consultant finalized the training manual based on the existing draft and feedback from the internal review process. A Handbook with content from the manual and the training handouts was also compiled and finalized by the consultant. As part of this project, 27 secondary HFLE teachers were trained in a 4-day residential Sexuality Education training workshop held on October 18-20, 2024, at the Ocean Coral Spring Hotel in Trelawny. The workshop aimed to equip teachers with the knowledge and skills to improve the delivery of the Sexuality and Sexual Health theme in HFLE, as well as increase their comfort level in delivering topics related to sexual and reproductive health.  The training was consistent with the then near-finalized sexuality education training manual and covered six modules as follows:·     Introduction to Sexuality Education·     Understanding Sexuality and Sexual Health Education·     Understanding Sexual Development·     Knowledge Empowers (SRH)·     Gender·     Gender-based Violence All 27 teachers completed the evaluation for the workshop. Only 1 teacher left the workshop in need of immediate support around Gender vs Sex. Areas of interest from the teachers for further capacity building were Human Trafficking, Sexting  Revenge Pornography, Cervical Cancer, Sexual Grooming, social media, and Accessing Health Services. Capacity building sessions will therefore be organized in these areas as resources become available. There is tremendous need for consistent engagement and support for educators tasked with delivering the HFLE Curriculum in schools. This is critical because while information about HIV and AIDS and young people’s sexual and reproductive health needs is readily available, the knowledge levels among educators vary. There is a critical need to provide competency support to build and sustain their comfort in delivering parts of the curriculum they find to be controversial.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: 2. Inclusão Social para o Desenvolvimento Sustentável
Outcome: 2.1 Até 2027, o Brasil terá ampliado e fortalecido a proteção social e demais políticas públicas para serem mais intersetoriais, inclusivas, participativas e efetivas, baseadas em evidências, atentas a grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e orientadas, em todos os níveis de governo, ao respeito aos direitos humanos e à redução da pobreza, da fome e das desigualdades de grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e à promoção da igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia e do desenvolvimento sustentável ambiental e socialmente.
