Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ1018 Educational resources for quality education for all promoted through the restructuring of the YouTube Edu platform
Description: The project "Educational resources for quality education for all: restructuring of the YouTube Edu platform" aims to restructure YouTube Edu, a large broadcasting platform of educational videos, in order to promote among lower and upper secondary education students and teachers quality educational resources as a tool in the teaching-learning process. The target audience of this project are students, teachers, school community, and education personnel.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: YouTube
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,17.17 Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there are some planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants of activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO restructured and launched the YouTube Edu channel. The new version of the channel presents selected educational videos covering the subjects of Brazilian secondary education, with content aligned and organized accordingly to the National Common Curricular Base (BNCC). The channel also has special playlists covering all the SDGs and other relevant educational topics. A launching event was organized and held to present the new YouTube Edu to several education stakeholders, including the Government, UNESCO and Google’s partners, civil society and edutubers. Two online teacher training pilot sessions were held in April, benefiting 51 teachers (60% female educators). The training sessions aimed at introducing the new YouTube Edu and its educational possibilities. Communication actions to disseminate YouTube Edu were also planned and implemented, including 1 exclusive video about Black Consciousness, 12 Shorts, 32 posts in the Community tab, 5 posts about the project on UNESCO's Instagram (Brazilian profile), and 2 Newsletters for teachers. Given the very particular dynamics of a YouTube channel, the first year of YouTube Edu's communication actions will be a testing phase, to identify the best communication strategies, considering that this is an educational channel and that a language closer to young people is necessary.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, YouTube and UNESCO have made significant progress in providing students, teachers, school community, and education personnel with quality educational resources through the YouTube Edu platform, as a means to enhance management capacities to promote quality education. Throughout the year, over 600 teachers were trained on the YouTube Edu channel, and more than 150 new videos were produced to enhance the platform's catalogue, resulting in 7,856 new subscriptions. The Channel's playlists for the lower secondary education level was updated, and Brazilian Sign Language was added in 103 videos. The document "YouTube Edu Guidelines for Teachers" was also produced. Additionally, two online training sessions of approximately 1 hour each were delivered to secondary education teachers, to present the YouTube Edu channel as an educational resource.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Protección social y servicios sociales de calidad
Outcome: En 2026, las personas, considerando su edad, sexo, identidad de género,  autoidentificación étnica y diversidad, en particular aquellas en situación de  vulnerabilidad y en contextos de emergencia, incrementan su acceso igualitario  y equitativo a la protección social y a servicios sociales de calidad, incluyendo  alimentación, salud, educación, agua, saneamiento e higiene, vivienda, cuidados y  cultura.
Output: 1.4 Capacidades fortalecidas, estrategias y herramientas desarrolladas para  la comunidad educativa, que reduzcan la exclusión y el rezago escolar;  faciliten la recuperación de los aprendizajes y la reducción de la brecha  digital; promuevan los servicios de desarrollo infantil; aseguren el acceso a  servicios básicos de agua, saneamiento e higiene y fomenten un ambiente  libre de todo tipo de violencia y discriminación.
Sub-Output: Education Multi-year Resilience Programme (MYRP) 2021-2023
Description: El objetivo general del Programa Multianual de Resiliencia (MYRP) de ECW para Ecuador fué garantizar el acceso continuo a una educación inclusiva y equitativa de calidad para aproximadamente 105 000 refugiados, migrantes y niños y jóvenes de las comunidades de acogida. Asegurar que los niños, niñas y adolescentes en situación de movilidad humana y de las comunidades de acogida accedan al sistema educativo, aprendan, y prosperen, a pesar de los desafíos generados por la pandemia COVID-19. En conjunto con el Ministerio de Educación de Ecuador y el Grupo de Trabajo de Educación de la plataforma GTRM (R4V), se diseñó el Programa Plurianual con el fin de promover el acceso a la educación de la población migrante y refugiada de Venezuela en Ecuador. Este Programa Plurianual dió continuidad al programa First Emergency Response (FER), financiado por Education Cannot Wait (ECW) durante 2019 y 2020. En la "FER", UNESCO actuó como Sub-beneficiario.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: ChildFund International, Education Cannot Wait Fund, Embassy of Canada, Instituto Iberoamericano de Patrimonio Natural y Cultural, Ministerio de Educación del Ecuador, RET International, United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, United Nations Resident Coordinator Office
Implementation partners: ChildFund International, Instituto Iberoamericano de Patrimonio Natural y Cultural, Ministerio de Educación del Ecuador, RET International, United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
Geography: Carchi, Azuay, El Oro, Ecuador, Guayas, Imbabura, Manabi, Pichincha
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Normative Support, Other (including coordination)
Humanitarian marker narrative: El programa atiende a personas en situación de vulnerabilidad, con énfasis en movilidad humana.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Nuestro programa es transformador de género, dedicando más del 50% del presupuesto a sus acciones y con líneas de trabajo específicas en torno a género.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Nuestro programa dedica más del 50% del presupuesto a sus acciones y con líneas de trabajo específicas en torno a garantizar el derecho a la educación.
Sustaining peace marker: 3 - Sustaining Peace is the principal objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: El programa tiene el objetivo de reducir la discriminación, la xenofobia y construir espacios educativos pacíficos y seguros.
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Children , Minorities, Persons With Disabilities, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Women & Girls, Migrants
2022 Narrative: Desempeño general: En contribución a las funciones clave de la UNESCO, en 2022 el Programa Multianual de Resiliencia (MYRP), funcionó como motor de cooperación internacional, laboratorio de ideas y generador de capacidades, convocando y congregando a los actores del grupo de trabajo de educación en Ecuador para promover el acceso al sistema educativo ecuatoriano de la población migrante y refugiada de Venezuela. En concreto, este año el programa se centró en ejecutar las acciones del periodo 2 de 3 de acuerdo con su planificación, garantizando el acceso continuo a una educación inclusiva, equitativa y de calidad para aproximadamente 105.000 niños, niñas y jóvenes refugiados, migrantes y de acogida comunitaria.Resultados: Se incorpora un especialista en Movilización de Recursos y se completa el equipo territorial. Propuesta para la obtención de nuevos recursos del FIEDS para la prevención del embarazo adolescente y para evitar la deserción escolar. Propuesta conceptual de estrategia de movilización de fondos. Productos de educomunicación que están siendo utilizados por los beneficiarios en la web "la educación es el camino" y youtube. Nuevo proyecto adicional de recursos de la ONU a la ONU con UNICEF (fondos canadienses) 201ECU1004. Firma de 2 acuerdos ONU a ONU con ACNUR y UNICEF. UNICEF está definiendo una intervención de adecuación de infraestructura para la accesibilidad de personas con discapacidad. Convenio de colaboración entre UNESCO-UNICEF-LLECE-INEVAL y MINEDUC, para la evaluación integral del aprendizaje en el Ecuador. Las acciones se enfocaron en la definición de la estrategia de Búsqueda Activa y elaboración de los términos de referencia para la recopilación de buenas prácticas brindadas a padres y cuidadores sobre la importancia de la educación. Proceso de Búsqueda Activa suscrito y en fase de implementación a través de RET Internacional. Entrega de KITs escolares con un avance superior al esperado en base a las acciones del ACNUR para acceder a insumos de calidad y menor costo al planificado.Beneficiarios directos, socios clave y otros actores: Sistema ONU, Ministerio de Educación del Ecuador, Población migrante venezolana, Universidades, Comunidad Andina, Asociación de jóvenes, Sociedad civil, Oficinas e institutos regionales de la UNESCO, Comisiones Nacionales ante la UNESCO, INEVAL, ONG, entre otros .Riesgos, desafíos y acciones preventivas y correctivas tomadas Los principales riesgos que surgieron en la implementación del plan de trabajo están asociados a los cambios políticos y económicos que surgen en el tiempo, la naturaleza y evolución del fenómeno migratorio en la región que muestra una movilidad permanente de personas entre países latinoamericanos dada la situación geopolítica venezolana y su impacto en los sistemas educativos regionales, específicamente en Ecuador. Para mitigar el impacto de los riesgos negativos, el sector Educación y el equipo técnico del proyecto MYRP de la oficina de la UNESCO en Quito, invierten su tiempo en fortalecer las relaciones con el Ministerio de Educación y otros actores vinculados al MYRP, trabajando como catalizador. de ideas para solucionar conflictos, promoviendo espacios de consulta y asesoría técnica oportuna. Lecciones aprendidas El equipo logró posicionar a la UNESCO con acciones que implicaron tomar riesgos calculados en tiempos cortos y con altas presiones externas e internas. Es importante mantener una buena planificación, comunicación con las contrapartes, los stakeholders y el donante del proyecto para generar eficiencia e innovación en los procesos y actividades del plan de trabajo.Comunicación y visibilidad: Los informes reflejan los índices de participación y desempeño de las audiencias en las redes sociales (Facebook, Twitter y Linked In). La agenda de trabajo en torno a la comunicación pública se vuelve cada vez más imprescindible dado su progresivo crecimiento. En general, el engagement y aumento medio de la audiencia respecto a las publicaciones, supera el 100% de un mes a otro a lo largo de 2022.Valor por dinero/rentabilidad: Cada una de las transacciones realizadas para la implementación del proyecto consideró los mecanismos más eficientes y efectivos para tener la mejor relación calidad-precio entre el personal, los proveedores y los contratos en general.Estrategia de salida y sostenibilidad: Todas las actividades del proyecto se coordinan con socios y aliados estratégicos para que el proyecto sea sostenible y la UNESCO tenga una estrategia de salida exitosa. Se han presentado al Ministerio de Educación metodologías de trabajo en el marco del programa con el fin de buscar sinergias para políticas de inclusión educativa que sean sostenibles en el tiempo.Sostenibilidad ambiental: indirectamente relacionada.

Description: This project aims the strengthening, evaluation and improvement of programs and actions implemented by SECADI / MoE, giving the necessary conditions to reach the goals established in the National Education Plan 2014-2024, related to SECADI responsibilities. In this sense, the planned activities are focused on improving conditions in the School System to increase the quality of education regarding to literacy, youth and adult education, rural population education, education of traditional communities of decedents of slaves ("quilombolas"), Indigenous schools , Ethnic and racial education, Human rights education, and education and access for people with special needs.

LNOB groups targeted: Indigenous Peoples, Persons With Disabilities, Youth, Children , Other, Persons of African Descent
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO developed a technical document proposing, raising, and consolidating themes to be presented by the technical areas and subsequent treatment of the information in communicative support content for advertising pieces, to support the Secretariat and its directorates in the elaboration of a schedule programming for broadcast on open TV and social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube), on the official communication channels of the Ministry of Education (MoE). It also developed supporting studies to implement the deaf bilingual education policy in the country, carried out research on the status of implementation of the National Guidelines for Education in Human Rights in Basic and Higher Education, as well as on the process of planning, implementing and evaluating the pedagogical and methodological practices of management of education policies for youth. The agency also mapped conditions, by region, of the Youth and Adult Literacy provision in the municipalities, pointing out its impact on literacy rates in the country, and developed subsidiary studies to the process of mapping the provision of the National Program of Inclusion of Youth - PROJOVEM, Urban and Countryside modalities in the states and municipalities. Finally, it carried out a study to identify students who entered the under-graduation course by the Law 12,711/12 (Quotas Law), between 2013 and 2022, and subsequent identification of those students currently enrolled or who have already concluded stricto sensu postgraduate courses (Master and PhD), before and after MoE Ordinance No. 13, of May 11, 2016, as well as studies with recommendations for the institutionalization of innovative practices and governance in the cycles of SECADI actions and programs.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the Brazilian Ministry of Education, with the support of UNESCO, has made significant progress in the planning, management, evaluation, and monitoring of policies and programmes of the Secretariat of Continuing Education, Literacy, Diversity and Inclusion (SECADI), as a means to enhance institutional capacities to promote quality education from generational, gender, race and ethnicity perspectives, with due respect to human rights. A series of technical events was organized to gather data on vulnerable populations, with a particular focus on Quilombola and Indigenous education. As a result, the partner tailored evidence-oriented policies to advance the inclusion of these communities within the educational system.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF increased its cooperative interface with local Government, inciting the adequate integration of Venezuelan children and adolescents into the Brazilian formal education system. It supported the implementation of public policies that consider the specific needs of refugee, migrants, indigenous, girls and boys, and people with disabilities. Also, as the co-lead of R4V Education Sector and in close coordination with other UN agencies and CSOs, UNICEF contributed for improved responses for the migratory emergency, having carried out enrollment campaigns, teacher trainings and ultimately providing tailored non-formal education services at 13 child-friendly spaces for 20,922 children and adolescents

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1066 Strengthening the intersectoriality among education and health sector for the promotion of school health
Description: This project aims to qualify the intersectoral response of education and health in the school. The main strategy will be strengthening the management, technical capacity and evaluation of the Health in School Program. The main objectives of this project are beyond to strengthen integrated actions between health and education: improve health conditions for students, reduce teenage pregnancy (the main cause of school dropout among girls in Brazil), and improve the management of the School Health Program.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,12.8 By 2030, ensure that people everywhere have the relevant information and awareness for sustainable development and lifestyles in harmony with nature.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 12 Responsible Consumption and Production, 13 Climate Action, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
The current project is on track, although the delay in the beginning, changes in management, and the COVID pandemic.
In 2020, the project focused on designing the evaluation model and the School Health Program's logical design. The actions began and should guide the structure and strategy of the Brazilian government's school health in the coming years.
In 2021, the project's activities were focused on educational materials for teaches and students related to health in school.
The project activities are directly linked to the expected outcomes of the 40C/5.
Major Program I, Expected Results (ER 6). Besides, it ensures that evidence-based strategies are the driving axes of the project actions. It is essential to highlight that this project contributes to the achievement of ODG. As can be seen in the achievement of the goals and objectives listed below:
Goal 3: Good health and well-being (goals targets - 3.3, 3.5, and 3.d)
•
Promote prevention policies and comprehensive health care for students in the School Health Program throughout Brazil.
Goal 4: Quality education (goals targets - 4.7, 4.a).
•
The project invests in lifelong education in partnerships with organized civil society and municipalities, such as education Secretariats.
Goal 10: Reduced inequalities (goals targets - 10.3 and 10.4)
•
Promoting gender equity actions, implemented through education, evidence-based, and human rights-guaranteed information.
2022 Narrative: The project has been implementing Health education, and HIV prevention in schools. In addition, the Project also included the COVID prevention strategies in its own activities. In this sense, HIV and COVID prevention work with the most vulnerable populations in public schools.The Project managed to achieve the main proposed results:The project's activities were focused on educational materials for teachers and students related to health education.Technical consultant specialized in administration, health, or education to elaborate and test instrument of evaluation of learning with the representatives of the Intersectoral Working Groups of the states and capitals to validate the training initiatives for this public.An international and online event related to health at school was held. Almost 3000 education and health professionals attended.The Brazilian education Census considers that the enrollment profile of women in Brazilian Basic education (primary and secondary) is equally distributed among boys and girls. Girls represent 49.51% of enrollments and boys 50.49%. The number of registrations during the pandemic has dropped. In other words, girls were more significantly affected during the pandemic. The project is intended to encourage and guarantee girls' permanence through health education strategies. This project contributes to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) and UNESCO's global priority for gender equity. The actions guarantee equal access and permanence for all in basic education.Teenagers and young people are the primary students at public schools in Brazil. The schools could be linked to the central government, states, and municipalities.Students at Brazilian public schools have an evident profile: they are children, adolescents, and youth, aged between 05 and 17.One hundred seventy-eight thousand four hundred are enrolled at Basic education (Primary and Secondary) schools registered in Brazil. In all, 46.7 million enrollments were registered - about 627,000 fewer compared to 2020, which corresponds to a reduction of 1.3%. The municipal network serves the majority (49.6%) of students. The state is the second-largest (32.2%), followed by the private (17.4%). The União (national network) is responsible for 0.8% of students enrolled in basic education.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Outcome: 2.1 Até 2027, o Brasil terá ampliado e fortalecido a proteção social e demais políticas públicas para serem mais intersetoriais, inclusivas, participativas e efetivas, baseadas em evidências, atentas a grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e orientadas, em todos os níveis de governo, ao respeito aos direitos humanos e à redução da pobreza, da fome e das desigualdades de grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e à promoção da igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia e do desenvolvimento sustentável ambiental e socialmente.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1071 Quality on public education in Brazil improved from the revision and re-adequation of management processes at FNDE.
Description: This project aims to develop and implement methodologies for: 1) monitoring , 2) coorporative education on public governance, 3) risk management, and 4) internal and external control of actions and practices implemented by the FNDE, in order to minimize faults on control and execution of programs and actions on education. In addition, it aims to broadening the technical assistance to social and education councils, working on mechanism of transparency and capacity building for education authorities and the general society mobilized toward the education. As a result, management process implemented by FNDE will be optimized, having the different programs being executed integratedly.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,17.14 Enhance policy coherence for sustainable development.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 17 Partnerships for the Goals

Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there are some planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants of activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO supported the establishment of the FNDE Executive Council, with the purpose of acting in consultation and coordination of the mechanisms of leadership, strategy, and control that constitute the governance in the Autarchy. The formalization of the Executive Board enables the coordination of the other internal governance instances. It also provided support in the development of other norms on ethics, integrity, and risk management issues through the publication of specific ordinances: FNDE Ordinance No. 435, of August 7, 2023, instituted the Risk Management and Integrity Policy at FNDE; and through the publication of Ordinance No. 442, of August 9, 2023, which approved the new Code of Ethics applicable to municipality public staff. It also supported the new management in updating regulations and creating representative bodies to institutionalize governance, risk management, and integrity practices. These measures were adopted throughout the first semester and aim to comply with the legal provisions and determinations of the internal and external control bodies, such as the General Federal Comptroller and the Federal Audit Court.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the Brazilian Ministry of Education, with the support of UNESCO, has made significant progress in strengthening the management and implementation of educational programs in the framework of the National Education Development Fund (FNDE), as a means to enhance institutional capacities to promote quality education from generational, gender, race and ethnicity perspectives, with due respect to human rights. As the project was finalized in 2024, the Brazilian authority advanced the revision and adjustment of FNDE management processes by improving monitoring methodologies, corporate education approaches, and practices related to public governance, risk management, and internal controls of the Autarchy, thus enhancing internal educational management procedures.

Description: This project aims to develop and implement methodologies for: 1) monitoring , 2) coorporative education on public governance, 3) risk management, and 4) internal and external control of actions and practices implemented by the FNDE, in order to minimize faults on control and execution of programs and actions on education. Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: FNDE has achieved expressive results in the strengthening of Monitoring, especially in the Terms of Commitment that has the accomplishment of works in its object. In terms of instrumentalization, flow, and legal framework, there has been progressing in intermediate aspects of action, which avoids the saturation of the institution and qualifies its response capacity. Regarding risk management, it is worth highlighting the work front in the Malha Fina Project, achieved by the Project and which promotes a strategy of improving controls based on Risk Management, qualifying the accountability of all programs and projects involving financial decentralization and, therefore, generating benefits of the action throughout the whole national territory.
2022 Narrative: - More timely decisions based on criteria for the accountability of the Malha Fina project through analytical dashboards - Knowledge management improved, processes standardized, and best practices consolidated.- Compliance area strengthened as a mechanism to improve Corporate Governance.- Improvement in the management of agreements, in order to achieve results with institutional coverage, enabling capacity-building.- Consolidation of guidelines regarding higher education, which mitigated risks, especially legal ones, in the management of the Student Financing Fund (FIES).- The project evaluation concluded with high standard results indicated. - Malha Fina: in 2022, the first application of the FNDE's Malha Fina model of accountability analysis took place, which approved 60,471 accounts rendered and the immediate conclusion of 20% of the Autarchy's liabilities, which represents an initial savings of R$ 782 million to the public coffers. Compacting with the model's success, Malha Fina was the winner of the 26th Public Sector Innovation Award.- Management Report: improvement of the collection and integration of data and information provided by the various Directorates of FNDE, as well as better systematization and presentation of the Management Report data on FNDE's Portal, contributing to the transparency and accountability of the Autarchy's management.- Process Office: Process Management is a component of the FNDE's institutional governance, making it possible to continuously improve the services provided to society and, consequently, excellence in the management of Educational Programs and Projects. Between 2021 and 2022, the FNDE executed the Project for Improvement of Process Management, which has as scope the aggregation of processes already mapped to the integrated value chain, the revision of processes and the implementation of the Business Process Office. In 2022 the actions were concluded and the BPM event at FNDE was held, bringing several positive results, such as the increase in the BPM maturity level, which improved by almost 20%.- New FNDE Structure: new organizational structure for the FNDE, based on the diagnoses and priorities made in the various sectors of the institution, with international cooperation as an important source of this knowledge. Based on an internal proposal, the publication of Decree No. 11.196/2022 was achieved, the constitution of an internal audit office was made possible, the strengthening of the finalistic areas, with the consolidation of the technical institutional urgency and the insertion of several project initiatives, aiming to provide the FNDE with a more dynamic capacity, in order to respond to the necessary qualification in educational policies.

Description: This Technical Cooperation project between the Municipal Education Secretariat of Leme and UNESCO aims at quality education, through democratic management, valued teachers, restructured curriculum, evaluation systems, continuous training plan and strengthening of the management policy that will enable the Municipal Education Network to play a leading role in shaping the new generations of the Municipality.

Implementation partners: #BR Municipal Government of Leme
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,17.14 Enhance policy coherence for sustainable development.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there are some planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO reviewed the syllabus of the Leme Curriculum Guidelines for Municipal Basic Education (early childhood and primary education) in order to present changes, ratifications, and/or addendums necessary for the full fulfillment of its objectives, concerning pedagogical actions. Data was collected and analyzed in the diagnosis of student learning, based on the Leme Municipal Education Assessment and the Basic Education Development Index, as well as recommendations for improving the quality of municipal education. The first online seminar on special education from the perspective of inclusive education was carried out, highlighting the need to ensure the basic principles of access, inclusion, equity, and quality education for all, leaving no one behind. The event was held in February, for approximately 250 Leme Municipal Education System professionals, in addition to institutional and governmental bodies’ representatives of the city of Leme who provide services/assistance to children and adolescents with disabilities/global developmental disorders/high abilities or giftedness and local community’s representatives. UNESCO also led the diagnosis, monitoring, and evaluation of each goal and strategy from 2015 to 2022 of the Leme Municipal Education Plan. It also hired a company specialized in providing technical and multidisciplinary services in public management, consistent with the review, analysis, and suggestion of indicators for improving the performance evaluation of educational professionals in the Leme Municipal Education System, identifying technical and behavioral skills, aiming at improving the quality of teaching, following the rules and legislation in force. Finally, it developed an informative video about successful practices in Special Education from the perspective of Inclusive Education and organized the Municipal Forum of Education, with more than 200 participants to validate the targets achieved in early childhood education
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the Municipal Education Secretariat of Leme and UNESCO concluded a successful partnership to enhance quality education through democratic management, valorization of professionals and restructuring of teaching curricula, as a means to promote quality education in the city of Leme. Through the year, inputs on governance, followed by the development of a SDG-oriented methodology, were implemented and translated into a new educational management model aligned with the 2030 Agenda, which now considers sustainability as a new paradigm of municipal education in both administrative and pedagogical aspects. As a result, indicators have shown a significant improvement in national educational asessments, as the Basic Education Development Index (IDEB). According to the independent external evaluation, the support of UNESCO was successfully held in terms of relevance, effectiveness, efficiency, impact and sustainability, and shall be considered a case of success. In 2024, Leme was selected to integrate UNESCO Global Network of Learning cities.

2019:

2020:

Preliminary reporting as at the end of Q3-
Training in Motivational Interviewing conducted for staff of the RHAs to enable them to support patients with NCDs to improve adherence and self management. Awaiting final report.
2022 Narrative: The HEARTS Initiative using a standardized hypertension treatment algorithm has been implemented in 100% of public primary care facilities. Training in Motivational Interviewing conducted for staff of the RHAs to enable them to support patients with NCDs to improve adherence and self management. Final report of the training submitted.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: IGUALDAD E INCLUSIÓN SOCIAL
Outcome: Respuesta integral a la reducción de la pobreza y las desigualdades
Output: 1.1 Fortalecidos los marcos legales, normativos, de políticas integrales, así como los mecanismos interinstitucionales e intersectoriales, para la igualdad de género e inclusión social de  grupos en situación de vulnerabilidad
Sub-Output: Sexuality Education Review and Assessment Tool (SERAT) in the Dominican Republic
Description:
In 2023, with UBRAF funds and UNESCO’s regular budget, the Organization, and the Ministry of Educación implemented the Sexuality Education Review and Assessment Tool (SERAT) in the Dominican Republic.

SERAT is an Excel-based tool, designed to help countries collect data and analyze the strengths and gaps in their [HIV prevention and] sexuality education programs at primary and secondary school levels. Its purpose is: To review school-based HIV prevention and sexuality education programs based on international evidence and good practice; To provide data to inform improvement or reform of programs; To assess program effectiveness by focusing on health data and other social criteria (notably gender) when looking at its strengths and weaknesses; To inform debate and advocacy by making available data on sexuality education that is understandable, easy to analyze and accessible to different audiences.

More than one hundred people representing the ministries: of education, health, youth, and women's affairs participated in the three consultative meetings (September, October, and November 2023). UNICEF, UNFPA, UNDP, PAHO, and UNAIDS participated by sharing data and facilitating access to other sources of information.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, United Nations Joint Programme on HIV and AIDS Secretariat, United Nations Population Fund
Contributing partners: UNAIDS Country Envelope, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Other, Women & Girls, Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.), Youth
2023 Narrative: A study to identify strengths and areas for improvement in the Dominican school curriculum on Comprehensive Sexuality Education was conducted using the Sexuality Education Review and Assessment Tool (SERAT) developed by UNESCO. Based on international technical guidelines, the study reviewed political-legislative documents and official programs on the subject and conducted interviews with all stakeholders. The results were presented to Dominican education authorities in November.

2023 Narrative: WFP continuó implementando su programa escolar en ocho estados de todo el país, que incluye comidas escolares nutritivas y diversificadas para 650.337 niños de educación preescolar y primaria, para estudiantes con discapacidad y sus familias, y para el personal escolar; en forma de comidas calientes a través de minoristas locales para garantizar alimentos frescos y secos diversos y nutritivos, y de raciones para llevar a casa, especialmente en lugares remotos, escuelas con difícil acceso y/o condiciones de cocción disuasorias, y escuelas de educación especial. Las actividades complementarias incluyeron la distribución de un alimento nutritivo especializado (Súper Cereal Plus) a 41.168 niños menores de tres años y la entrega de 1.010 kits a escuelas para la preparación del Súper Cereal Plus en siete de los ocho estados; mensajes de educación nutricional, WASH e higiene a la comunidad escolar y cuidadores de niños y personas con discapacidad; la rehabilitación de 248 comedores escolares en los estados Falcón, Yaracuy, Barinas y Trujillo y la distribución de utensilios de cocina en 180 escuelas de los estados del occidente del país para asegurar las condiciones básicas para la preparación de comidas calientes. Además, el PMA está implementando una estrategia para fortalecer operaciones inclusivas para personas con discapacidad que incluye un registro diferenciado de beneficiarios, la diversificación de canales de comunicación mediante la incorporación de grabaciones de audio e intérpretes de lengua de señas para personas con discapacidad sensorial, y la provisión de programas de sensibilización. talleres para todo el personal de los socios cooperantes.

2021 Narrative: The number of adolescents in the Socio-educational Correction System decreased by 12%,  reaching a population of 13,684. UNDP directly supported this figure.  In partnership with CNJ, a new formation focused on Initial and Integrated Services for Youth that committed infractions. The course provided information about the first contact with the Justice System and the System of Rights Assurance towards a positive impact on the future of young people served by the Socio-educational System in Brazil.
2022 Narrative: UNODC: Aimed at people in custody entering the prison system, the project is needed to enhance the capacity of pre-trial detention hearing to work as an effective mechanism to respond to vulnerabilities of people in custody, to assure reduction on unfair imprisonments and to identify cases of torture or mistreatment by law enforcement agents. The project is effectively improving this institute, with important impacts in imprisonment rates and the social protection of people in custody. In 2022, the project promoted the holding of custody hearings in the interior regions of the states according to the parameters developed by the project in cooperation with the National Council of Justice. It also promoted the resumption of custody hearings in person, after the implementation of the videoconference modality during the COVID-19 pandemic. The project also conducted trainings for members of the judiciary both on custody hearings and on confronting torture through these hearings. More than 400 members of the judiciary and related services were trained. Furthermore, the project showcased the Brazilian experience and results from the project through the side-event Decision Making in Pre-trial Detention Control Hearings in Brazil in the Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice and the side-event Sharing Brazil and Mexico experiences in Social Protection and People Who Use Drugs in the Context of Pre-trial Detention Hearings in the Commission on Narcotic Drugs. The project also released informational material about pre-trial detention hearing in the Nheengatu, Baniwa and Tukano languages. Eight posters were translated in partnership with the Federation of Indigenous Organizations of the Rio Negro (FOIRN) and the Socio-environmental Institute (ISA). The launch was attended by leaders of the 23 indigenous peoples, representatives of FOIRN, ISA, CNJ, UNODC, the Court of Justice of Amazonas (TJAM) and other organs of the Justice system and the Executive Power.https://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/05/cartazes-sobre-audiencias-de-custodia-sao-lancados-em-tres-linguas-indigenas-no-amazonas.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/04/material-sobre-audiencia-de-custodia-em-linguas-indigenas-sera-lancado-no-amazonas.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/02/unodc-promove-curso-sobre-enfrentamento-a-tortura-nas-audiencias-de-custodia.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/02/unodc-promove-curso-de-atualizacao-em-audiencia-de-custodia-para-magistratura-do-ceara.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/02/audincias-de-custdia_-vdeos-detalham-passo-a-passo-no-aniversrio-de-sete-anos.htmlhttps://www.unodc.org/lpo-brazil/pt/frontpage/2022/05/unodc-divulga-experiencia-com-audiencias-de-custodia-na-31-ccpcj-da-onu.html

2021 Narrative: In 2021, the project systematized the offer of the Profuturo Aula Digital Project in Brazil, through research and the elaboration of a guide to future steps and innovations for teachers. The Aula Digital Project is part of a global initiative that aims to contribute to equal opportunities for children and adolescents through educational innovation. Aula Digital encourages innovative practices and takes technological resources to remote and vulnerable areas in 28 countries, including Brazil. Currently, after 5 years of implementation, the Aula Digital project is in the consolidation phase in the territories and its systematization of this social technology and support in the preparation and management of the consolidation project to ensure its sustainability with UNESCO's expertise.
2022 Narrative: This suboutput aims to assess three projects focused on information and communication technologies: Innovative Schools, Connected Rural Schools and Entrepreneurship Development Platform. The former introduces innovative technologies for evaluating its impact over the student's achievement. The second project is implemented in 100 rural schools in seven Brazilian states; it aims to connect distant rural communities using the internet. Finally, the latter project seeks to empower young people in order to generate and implement innovative solutions to their own communities, with the use of technology. UNESCO contributed to the development of an online course on Digital Citizenship, introducing UNESCO´s materials on Global Citizenship (ECG), Media and Information Literacy (MIL) and Education for Sustainable Development (ESD), aiming to train students to make informed decisions and adopt responsible and citizenship actions.

2021 Narrative: The present Project was signed at the end of 2020. Sebrae has a wide range of entrepreneurship courses already available for teacher training and students' solutions. Undime is the ONLY Brazilian association with national capillarity and with the peculiarity of having all the country's municipal education secretaries as directive members. At the end of 2020, a contract was signed with UNDIME (Municipal Education Secretaries Union) in order to provide technical assistance to allow a wide dissemination of the online materials, which will be of great value for the training of education professionals and students, especially in the current context of COVID-19. Planning meetings and online meetings with all the Municipal Secretaries of Education and State representatives of SEBRAE are being held in order to attain the foreseen results in 2021. The website of courses available to Managers, teachers and students was developed and disseminated through the website: https://www.SEBRAE.com.br/sites/PortalSEBRAE/educacaoempreendedora/undime# From March to September 2021, dissemination via Undime's website and social networks. In October 2021, there were 1.376 signed adhesions of municipal education secretaries approved by SEBRAE to the Entrepreneurial Education Program. Due to the context of the pandemic at that time and the uncertainty regarding the possibility of implementing face-to-face activities in schools, it was decided, in common agreement between SEBRAE and UNESCO, not to extend the project to continue the actions as it was designed initially, having been closed by the end of the execution period. It was also discussed the possibility of a new technical cooperation project that can better meet the needs and current context of schools.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO consolidated the Cidadaniar Network, composed of 24 civil society organizations (CSO), located in Breves/PA; Campo Grande/MS; Manaus/AM; Recife/PE; and, in the Federal District, in the Administrative Regions Sol Nascente - Complementary Industry and Supply Sector (SCIA) and Structural, Housing Sector (SH). Managers of these CSO, which are part of the Cidadaniar Network, will be trained to act as multipliers to the beneficiaries of their organizations on the project's themes. UNESCO also started two new components of the project - 'Cidadaniar Content' and 'Cidadaniar Trainings' - which also include the production of the texts that will integrate the series of Cidadaniar Guides, on the themes of the project, and the methodological conception of the trainings to civil society organizations (that will start in the second semester). Furthermore, a new consultant specialized in the production of publications and methodologies was hired to produce Cidadaniar Guides and the training methodologies. The Situational Mapping of the 24 CSOs that integrate Cidadaniar Network was also concluded in 2023 aiming at analyzing the organizational situation of the CSOs as well as the kind of work they develop as well as the type of beneficiaries they achieve. The project's Communication Plan of Cidadaniar project designed and approved. Finally, the methodological framework of Monitoring and Evaluation Plan (for 5 years) of the project was produced and approved.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the capacity of the public and private sectors and civil society were improved to better promote rule of law through and the culture of lawfulness through education, with the support of UNESCO. Seven Cidadaniar guidelines were developed and disseminated to enhance knowledge of CSO managers and staff on Human Rights and Democracy, Culture of lawfulness and Citizenship, Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and Social Justice, Social Participation and Youth Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Social Project Management. As a results, beneficiaries from 20 CSOs are more empowered to lead healthy lives, promote sustainable development and engage with the world as creative and responsible global citizens, in line with SDG target 4.7.

PDDE Paulista Diagnosis and Planning System - Conduct studies, research and evaluations of implementation and use of educational technologies and innovative methodologies to support the definitions of the State Department, related to the goals and strategies established in the National Education Plan that refer to the action technology-mediated education. The study was completed in the first semester and is being implemented by the Education Secretariat. The studies are focused on supporting the development of the pedagogical area and solutions for improving the learning and management process, covering the following Project activities: Support Materials for Planning and Deepening Practices (MAPPA) - New High School Training Itineraries – Activity 1.3.8. Elaborate a proposal for the formulation, development, revision, adaptation and dissemination of content and materials in secondary and technical education.

2024 Narrative: In May 2024, IOM as part of its local cooperation agreement with the Ministry of Education, donated resources for English as a Second Language (ESL) classes. The resources amounted to a total of GYD 492,926. Both IOM and the Ministry of Education agreed to coordinate efforts related to the planned Social-Emotional Learning (SEL) mentoring program and other educational initiatives aimed at the migrant population in Regions 3, 4, and other areas within Guyana. The collaboration between IOM and MoE is intended to maximize cooperation and avoid unnecessary duplication of efforts, ensuring more effective support for migrant communities. Education resources for ESL classes benefitted 120 individuals.

SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.,12.8 By 2030, ensure that people everywhere have the relevant information and awareness for sustainable development and lifestyles in harmony with nature.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
The Project was signed in December 2019, and the funds were transferred in February 2020. In February of this year, there was a ceremony to launch the Project between the governor of Rio Grande do Sul and UNESCO. Then he started an action planning action and trained the teams to use the systems. However, the COVID-19 pandemic determined the remote work of all groups, including the Project.
In this sense, the Project postponed its beginning.
Considering the sanitary context due to COVID-19, all the personal hiring was postponed. A company was hired to develop health education and sexuality education remotely activities in schools in 2021.

The project activities are directly linked to the expected outcomes of the 40 C/5.
Major Program I, Expected Results (ER 6). Since the Project strengthens the institutional capacity of the Secretariat of Health response to the HIV epidemic, especially against the most vulnerable populations. The Project works on enhancing people's vulnerabilities from the most vulnerable groups.
Goal 3: Good health and well-being (goals targets - 3.3, 3.5, and 3.d)
• Through access to condoms, combined prevention strategies, prevention as a treatment, and reduction of Facial Lipoatrophy effects.
Goal 4: Quality education (goals targets - 4.7, 4.a).
• Investing in lifelong education in partnerships with organized civil society and NGOs that invest in people living with HIV/AIDS.
Goal 5: Gender Equality (goals Targets - 5.1, 5.2, 5.6)
• Promoting gender equity actions, universal access to sexual and reproductive rights, access to health services, scientifically qualified, eliminate violence against women and girls, including sexual exploitation.
Goal 10: Reduced inequalities (goals targets - 10.3 and 10.4)
• Promoting gender equity actions, implemented through sexual diversity, access to health services, scientifically qualified, evidence-based, and human rights-guaranteed information.
2022 Narrative: A company is developing actions focused on young people in schools all over the state of Rio Grande do Sul regarding health education and sexuality education. The activities started remotely considering the pandemic scenario, and nowadays, the actions are being developed directly in the schools. The Project focused on the prevention and well-being of people living with HIV and AIDS. This achievement results from continued action public policies that have been maintained and expanded, in addition to working with committed professionals and institutions. It has been working on HIV prevention with the most vulnerable populations: young people (especially students), men who have sex with men, transvestites, female sex workers, and drug users. Considering the main results of the year, the Project managed to achieve the main proposed results:Development of studies to comprehend the dynamics of the HIV epidemic focused on a vulnerable population. Development of education, communication, and information strategies on health education and HIV prevention.Implement a particular strategy focused on young people in schools related to health and sexuality education – Geracao consciente project.The activities of this Project are always focused on gender equality and gender mainstream. The Project always seeks to guarantee access to condoms. However, other alternatives to HIV prevention strategies, such as combined prevention and focus on the most vulnerable populations, are always considered. As part of the scope of the Project's objectives, it promotes studies and research on epidemiological, behavioral, and effectiveness trends in STI / HIV / AIDS. It developed: a cascade of care with an estimate of those infected with HIV; epidemiological and assistance analyses of HIV and AIDS; epidemiological analysis of viral hepatitis reports; research related to notifications of pregnant women with HIV / AIDS; studies related to cases of congenital syphilis; analyzes similar to syphilis during pregnancy. The Project has provided Management with the development of actions that contribute to studying the dynamics of the HIV / AIDS epidemic in the state and strengthening Management's governance capacity.The production and systematization of technical-scientific information have become an essential strategy for reaching health professionals and contributing to public political processes.Women, including Lesbians, bisexuals, transvestites, and transsexuals, were the population group with the most data produced. Currently, the HIV epidemic affects more young people, so the focus of the Project's actions was aimed at young people. Both research, interventions, and strategies considered young people, men who have sex with men and women in situations of social vulnerability and difficulty accessing education and health services.The Project's main objective is to work with primary and secondary education students on health education, sexuality education, and HIV prevention topics. The Project works with the largest municipalities (cities) in the Rio Grande do Sul. These cities have the highest rates of adolescent severity and HIV infection.

2024 Narrative: Trinidad and TobagoIn alignment with the MDSCF strategy and outcome 4, refugees and migrant children who were approved to enter the national education system in 2024, were supported by UNHCR with school kits and uniform donations to ensure their successful integration into the public school system. The capacity of schools and learning opportunities for refugees and migrant children were further expanded through the donation of one hundred (100) tablets by The UN Refugee Agency to the Ministry of Education under its Adopt-A-School Programme to enhance learning in the classroom and in support of education and development of children in Trinidad and Tobago. Approximately 1,774 refugee and migrant children (658 in primary and 1,116 in secondary) who were enrolled in Equal Place, a temporary initiative by UNHCR and UNICEF, were able to access online education and bolster their academic learning. By the end of 2024, 313 refugee and migrant children also benefitted from online education programming such as DAWERE through the support of UNHCR and implementing partner UNCIEF.https://www.unhcr.org/us/news/announcements/unhcr-donates-books-uniforms-refugees-and-host-community-children-refugees-are UNHCR Donates 100 Devices To Schools - TTT News

Support will be provided to review of documents and facilitate implementing agency engagement and assist in the project management and specific interactions with key implementing teams and the development of content to guide the development of associated MOUs.

Contributing partners: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Implementation partners: Caribbean Centre for Health Systems Research and Development, National AIDS Coordinating Committee, United Nations Joint Programme on HIV and AIDS Secretariat

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Persons With Disabilities, Children , Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.), Migrants, Women & Girls, Youth, LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity)
2023 Narrative: No implementation. Activity will be implemented in 2024.
2024 Narrative: Improved support and coordination among ministries, departments and agencies (MDAs) around the National Strategic Plan on HIV and National HIV Policy. More policy and decision-makers across government better understand the challenges faced by people living with and most affected by HIV and express more willingness to support the multi-sectoral efforts needed to end AIDS as a public health threat in TT by 2030. Under the leadership of Minister Ayanna Webster Roy, various departments across her ministry have now been tasked to lead of various aspects of the work being undertaken by the NACC. Several activities were undertaken to achieve these results: Capacity building training workshop in September 2024. UNAIDS, MOH, NACC, CDC and PEPFAR collaborated to build the capacity of around thirty senior officials in government and communities of people living with and most affected by HIV to address health inequalities and discrimination through advocacy as it relates to the National Strategic Plan on HIV and National HIV Policy. At the end of the training, participants developed advocacy action plans that they will implement to address issues that were identified during the training workshop. See https://x.com/UNAIDSCaribbean/status/1830972754272649388 and https://x.com/UNAIDSCaribbean/status/1833150307439661120  Development and Design of Advocacy Tools to Support the Implementation of the National HIV and AIDS Policy of Trinidad and Tobago. Working with several partners from the NACC, including the Ministry of Labour and civil society organisations, the NACC developed several advocacy materials for use in its engagement with policy and decision-makers from MDAs. These tools are instrumental in promoting ownership and active multi-sector participation in the implementation of the National HIV and AIDS Policy of Trinidad and Tobago (TT) as part of the national agenda to reduce HIV incidence, prevalence, morbidity, and mortality by ensuring that key stakeholders understand and fulfil their roles within the policy framework. The following were developed: Two (2) 3-4-minute Animated Promotional / Advocacy Videos; Fourteen (14) 2-3-page Advocacy Briefs for the Houses of Parliament, Office of the Prime Minister and other MDAs, Five (5) Updated National HIV and AIDS Policy Priority Area Summaries, Communication Materials (Artwork), and copy edited, Designed, and Formatted National HIV and AIDS Policy. High-level advocacy engagement. Several meetings have been held with various ministries, departments and agencies (MDAs), including with the Ministry of National Security around mandatory HIV testing and counselling for entry into service and the Ministry of Social Development and Family Services, among others. These meetings are a follow-up to the training workshop and have been instrumental in engendering greater support and partnership to facilitate the implementation of the NSP and National HIV Policy. https://x.com/UNAIDSCaribbean/status/1862117496825733397

2024 Narrative: UNHCR supported over 845 forcibly displaced children through ESL after-school classes in 21 schools across Regions 1, 2, 3, and 7. They also donated essential school supplies, including notebooks, backpacks, and tarpaulins to the Ministry of Education, alongside two boat engines for student transportation in the riverine areas•	Impact: Improved educational outcomes for displaced children and enhanced school accessibility.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: 2. Inclusão Social para o Desenvolvimento Sustentável
Outcome: 2.2 Até 2027, o Brasil terá ampliado e fortalecido os sistemas de garantias de direitos para que sejam ainda mais efetivos na integração transversal do respeito aos direitos humanos e da igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia, no enfrentamento às suas violações e às múltiplas formas de discriminação e violências, incluindo a violência de gênero, e para que promovam a atuação coordenada de diferentes instâncias em todos os níveis de governo, bem como a participação da sociedade civil.
Output: 2.2.1 Mulheres, jovens, pessoas negras, refugiados, migrantes e apátridas, pessoas com deficiência e de outros grupos que sofrem discriminação e organizações da sociedade civil têm suas capacidades fortalecidas e oportunidades iguais de mobilização social e participação na formulação de leis, políticas, planos e orçamentos, para promover a justiça social, a igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia e o respeito aos direitos humanos.
Sub-Output: UNESCO 465BRZ3007 (465BRZ3002) Social inclusion, educational qualification, and human rights protection to socially vulnerable populations promoted (Criança Esperança Programme)
Description: The Criança Esperança Programme is a multi-stakeholder partnership promoted by Globo TV and UNESCO. It is a multi-donor Social Mobilization and Fundraising Campaign, which has been promoted for the past 29 years. It provides technical and financial support to social projects implemented by NGOs in all regions of Brazil. Its main immediate objective is to promote social inclusion, educational qualification and to guarantee human rights to socially vulnerable populations.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Rede Globo
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.,17.16 Enhance the global partnership for sustainable development, complemented by multi-stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the sustainable development goals in all countries, in particular developing countries.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 10 Reduced Inequalities, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Each year, the initiative selects local NGOs to develop grassroots activities to promote social inclusion and sustainable development through education, culture, science, sports, human rights, and citizenship. In 2023, the education of women and girls in science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM) was included as a category of projects to be eligible for the grants scheme.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO, through the Criança Esperança Project, supported the implementation of 71 locally implemented projects in the fields of education, violence prevention, health, and social support targeting children, adolescents, and youth. The initiative reached 16.487 direct beneficiaries and over 50,000 indirect beneficiaries (estimated). 2023's Criança Esperança TV live show raised R$ 13.6 million through donations over the phone, bank transfers, donation platforms, and contributions from private companies, and reached the best audience peak in six years, with an average of 18.7 points in Greater São Paulo. During the event, UNESCO provided Globo’s team with many ideas and materials for the 2023 campaign, including a contribution regarding the fight against racism, which aired during the show to advocate for non-discrimination and black empowerment.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNESCO and Rede Globo made significant progress in strengthening the capacities and ensuring equal capacities of CSOs, youth, women, and other LNOB groups to better engage in social mobilisation and participate in the formulation of laws, policies, plans and budgets to promote social justice, equality of generation, gender, race and ethnicity and respect for human rights. Throughout the year, 101 grassroots projects located in 22 states and the Federal District that were selected in 2023 were implemented, reflecting the commitment to strengthening initiatives aimed at social development across various regions of the country. The total investment for these actions amounts to approximately R$19 million, highlighting the importance of promoting social inclusion and generating positive impacts within the communities served by these organizations. Also in 2024, Criança Esperança took part in the recovery efforts in Rio Grande do Sul, which faced the greatest humanitarian tragedy in its history due to intense climate change, causing the worst floods of the century and imposing major challenges for the local population. Through the ParaQuemDoar mobilisation campaign, Criança Esperança raised around R$800,000 from donations from society and Globo itself, which will be invested in restructuring CSOs that offer direct assistance to the most vulnerable population in municipalities affected by the floods.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: 1. Transformação Econômica para o Desenvolvimento Sustentável
Outcome: 1.2 Em 2027, o Brasil terá avançado na inclusão econômica que contribui para a redução da pobreza, da fome, das vulnerabilidades, das desigualdades, e da discriminação de geração, gênero, raça e etnia, e que garante o direito à educação transformadora para o pleno desenvolvimento da pessoa e o acesso ao trabalho decente, às oportunidades para geração de renda, à proteção social, econômica e políticas de cuidados e às infraestruturas resilientes, assegurando a igualdade de oportunidades e a sua sustentabilidade.
Output: 1.2.2 Capacidades institucionais fortalecidas para aprimorar políticas de transição positiva da escola para o mundo do trabalho, voltadas aos projetos de vida de crianças, adolescentes e jovens a partir da perspectiva de gênero, raça e etnia, com sua maior participação na tomada de decisões, para melhor inserção no mercado de trabalho, a fim de aumentar as oportunidades de formação profissional e sociocultural, a produtividade e fomentar o empreendedorismo e o cooperativismo ambientalmente referenciados.
Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ1016 Emancipatory and transformative education promoted through lessons in entrepreneurship
Description: This project aims to benefit, through educational activities, secondary education students, of all genders, enrolled in Brazilian public schools, in themes focused on the development of entrepreneurship, aiming at achieving an emancipatory and transforming education. The activities foreseen in this project will be carried out face-to-face and at distance, using digital platforms, comprising courses, workshops, lectures, seminars, and conversation circles, with the provision of videos and educational material.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Instituto Êxito
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project foresees that half of the students enrolled in the entrepreneurship training will be girls. The survey carried out as the project's first activity showed a higher proportion of girls interested in entrepreneurship than boys, which points to a great need to work on this theme among the young female population. In addition, the training material was careful to avoid gender stereotypes and show examples of female entrepreneurs as a way to empower and encourage female students to fulfill their personal and professional ambitions and projects.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO adapted to the e-learning format, delivered two training courses on entrepreneurship, and printed and distributed learning materials. A partnership was established with the city of Bezerros, in Pernambuco State, to execute the pilot project. Additionally, face-to-face entrepreneurship training was conducted with 210 high school students from the public school system. Two external consultants were also hired, aiming to disseminate the online training course more broadly, focusing on advocacy actions with education secretariats.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, Instituto Êxito and UNESCO, has made significant progress in promoting emancipatory and transformative lessons in entrepreneurship as a means to enhance policies focused on the positive transition from school to work. Along the year, learners were equipped with relevant skills to meet individual, labour market and societal demands through the adaptation of a set of teaching material and tools to be used in virtual environments, thus ensuring inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities for all. An online entrepreneurship training course was made available to support secondary students and teachers from public schools, benefiting 197 learners in total.
