2021 Narrative:
The programming and implementation of the Project started in 2021.
The following activities started being implemented:
• Developing teaching material on Financial Education for Secondary Education, for use by teachers and students in the implementation of this discipline from 2021
• Training of a technical team and pedagogical tutors on formative feedback.
• Engagement of secondary school students, in view of the implementation of the New secondary curricula in 2022.
• New Secondary education Implementation Process: Revision of the Secondary education Curriculum Framework; Restructuring of the 5th Training Itinerary of the New Secondary education; Analysis of the research with high school students about the New Secondary education; Preparation of the New Secondary education Proposal.
• Innovative management solutions for the Paraná state education system to improve student learning - Guidance, monitoring and data collection for the pilot test of the Writing Platform model for Elementary and secondary education.
• Management of Educational Projects: Education for the Future - systematization of the main projects and activities, in progress and being planned by the Secretariat, within the scope of the Education for the Future program.
• Training of Trainers - Proposal of strategies for engaging and attracting course participants and trainer teachers; Recommendations for structuring the content and course based on best continuing education practices; Subsidies for the creation of a monitoring and evaluation system (quality management) of the Trainers in Action Program; Proposal of strategies for engaging and attracting course participants and teacher trainers.
• Tutor training: Training on observation and training feedback; Guidelines and instruments to support the practice of observation and formative feedback.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, the following activities are being implemented:Engagement of secondary school students and families, for the implementation of the New secondary curricula in 2022.New Secondary education Implementation Process: Revision of the Secondary education Curriculum Framework; Restructuring of the 5th Training Itinerary of the New Secondary education; Analysis of the research with high school students about the New Secondary education; Preparation of the New Secondary education Proposal.Innovative management solutions for the Paraná state education system to improve student learning – Guidance, monitoring and data collection for the pilot test of the Writing Platform model for Elementary and secondary education.Training of Trainers - Proposal of strategies for engaging and attracting course participants and trainer teachers; Recommendations for structuring the content and course based on best continuing education practices; Subsidies for the creation of a monitoring and evaluation system (quality management) of the Trainers in Action Program; Proposal of strategies for engaging and attracting course participants and teacher trainers.Development teaching material in continuity with the production of financial education material produced in 2021. This year it is being produced for elementary and full-time education, completing material for the stages of elementary and high school3 training sessions with the secretariat management teams: Heads of Regional Centers and Seed technicians on collective work, strategic management, conflict management, teamwork, ethics.Culture of peace: Technical consultant to develop situational diagnosis, participatory processes, awareness and engagement of the actors involved in the culture of peace, to improve the learning of students in the state public network of Paraná State.Paraná redaction: projects and in actions related to the Paraná Redaction Platform, aiming at following up and monitoring the results and progress of students in relation to improving their proficiency in Portuguese. Available at: https://sites.google.com/escola.pr.gov.br/redao-paran/in%C3%ADcio?authuser=1pli=1.BI educacional solution: proposals for the development of Information Technology (IT) solutions for educational support. visualization of student and teacher attendance indicators, based on location and institution filters; visualization of proficiency indicators, based on student performance, based on the results of bimonthly evaluations, filtered by location, teaching modality, subject, grade or year, period, class and per student; the easy application of filters and modification of parameters for geolocated visualization of the result of applying these filters and parameter adjustments. Interactive visualization of the evolution of geolocated data to the school community, allowing greater monitoring by its members and available to the entire chain of administrative units.Community service: support the planning and implementation of a new institutional relationship and user service strategy at the Paraná State Secretariat for Education and Sport. These analyzes made it possible to assess the profile of the flow of processes between the Secretariat and the external community, so that in a process analysis, the necessary information was obtained to promote broader actions with a view to solving problems related to this hearing sector.Training of educational managers or Heads of the Regional Education Centers (NRE) with an emphasis on conflict management, decision-making under pressure, engagement, alertness, adaptation to new scenarios, collaboration, risk management, systemic vision, team management, communication, strategic thinking, among other areas of management, focused on public management.Development of guiding documents and trainings of the Secretariat team in project management, contributing to the structuring of the project management flow in the General Directorate of the State Secretariat for Education and Sport of Paraná.strengthening of the itinerary of Professional and Technological Education in the state of Paranáplan, organize and develop didactic sequences, using games and ludic materials for the development of concepts and logical-mathematical reasoning for students in the 1st, 2nd and 3rd years of public elementary education in Paraná and the contracting of continuing education for education professionals from the Municipal Departments of Education in order to improve the learning process.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: MSDCF 4.3: National institutions strengthened to deliver shock-resilient education and learning
Sub-Output: 2.4.12 BDS Families and communities are supported to access education
Description: Support family and community awareness to demand safe and inclusive quality education. Engage with adolescent and youth activists to promote community resilience and climate action
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Grenada Ministry of Education, Youth, Sports & Culture, Montserrat Minister of Education, Youth Affairs and Sports, Saint Lucia Ministry of Education, Sustainable Development, Innovation, Science, Technology, and Vocational Training, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Ministry of Education and National Reconciliation, St. Kitts and Nevis Ministry of Education, Youth, Social Development, Gender Affairs, Aging and Disabilities, Trinidad and Tobago Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
Geography: Trinidad and Tobago, Montserrat, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Grenada, Saint Lucia, Dominica, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Women & Girls, Youth, Persons With Disabilities
Focal users: N'guetta Koutoua Emery Bosso, Nicholas Guribie
2022 Narrative: Through technical and financial assistance, UNICEF ECA collaborated with governments, national and regional partners to support the back-in-school transition whilst utilizing opportunities to deliver quality ECD and Education using both in-person and digital modalities. Efforts are ongoing to enhance the knowledge, skills and competencies of approximately 5,417 parents, ECD practitioners, teachers and key stakeholders across 10 programme countries and territories to provide 13,426 girls and boys, ages 0-8 with nurturing care, learning and holistic development in safe, protective and enriching environments.Training and capacity development remain important strategies employed in the ECD sector strengthening the information base, skills, and competencies of parents, ECD practitioners, teachers, and other stakeholders to enhance child engagement and support quality play for holistic development and sustainable learning, including in emergencies. Approximately 5,417 key stakeholders in Antigua and Barbuda, Anguilla, Dominica, Grenada, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Trinidad and Tobago , Virgin Islands UK and the Turks and Caicos Islands benefitted from professional development sessions in supporting home-based learning, using materials effectively in structured play to enhance numeracy, literacy, language and communication , learning to identify and respond to children showing signs of developmental delay and integrating technology using online platforms with content for young learners.Advocacy and communication were key mediums for sharing information on quality ECD with targeted stakeholders and the public. The Ministry of Education in Grenada, with the support of the Ministries of Health and Social Development implemented an intersectoral advocacy campaign to ensure that the public had access to information about the overall benefits of quality ECD for children, families and the wider community emphasizing topics such as early brain development, active learning, positive parenting, keeping children safe, health and nutrition etc. Information was shared via social media platforms, television, radio with more than 4,000 views on the Ministry’s website.Using the generation of evidence as a critical strategy to support systematic planning, decision-making and to advance policy initiatives for inclusive ECD and Education, UNICEF ECA supported the comprehensive Diagnostic Review of the status of the ECD Sector in the 12 programming countries and territories. Consultations reflected the perspectives of more than 200 key informants across the region. The data revealed positive progress in key areas - implementation of ECD Policies, Standards and Regulatory Frameworks for provision of quality ECD services, the utilization of Regional Frameworks promoting effective curriculum delivery through child friendly environments for purposeful play and utilization of operational guidance promoting compliance with quality standards. Positive progress was reflected in training for parents, ECD practitioners and other caregivers on supporting holistic development in homes and communities, keeping the focus on Early Moments Matter. The research also revealed that there is more to be done to support countries to implement integrated approaches for planning, implementing, and monitoring of ECD programmes and services across the sectors of Education, Health, and Social Development.In collaboration with the respective governments, UNICEF supported the comprehensive review and updating of the ECD Policy, Regulations and Standards Frameworks in Anguilla, Antigua and Barbuda, Dominica and Montserrat with these countries placing significant emphasis on the articulation of more integrated approaches to ECD for children 0-8 years. Going forward UNICEF ECA will support the implementation of Policy Initiatives including strengthening mechanisms for effective governance, coordination, implementation and monitoring of integrated ECD programmes, support for holistic development in homes and communities and support for early identification, intervention, and improved learning outcomes for children with developmental delays/disabilities.Through UNICEF support, the Ministry of Education in St. Kitts and Nevis strengthened and supported the establishment of Toy Lending Libraries. These libraries support the principles of learning through play by providing ECD Service providers and teachers with access to developmentally appropriate materials and equipment for learning on a rotation basis. Six hundred and fifty-two (652) ECD practitioners, Teachers and Centre supervisors benefitted from professional development sessions which focused on building their capacity to make multi-purpose use of toys and manipulatives, to enhance child engagement, development and learning. Approximately 2,069 children, 0-5 years are enjoying more interactive and structured play using the materials being borrowed from the Toy Lending Libraries.The Integrated approach to ECD at country level has proven to be highly effective to support holistic development of young children. It now requires institutionalization and development of mechanisms both at the country level as well as at UNICEF internally to further strengthened integration approach across health, education and social development sectors.A key partnership with the Child Development and Guidance Centre and the Ministry of Education in St. Lucia resulted in the completion of an online learning platform and the launching of a new e-learning web series for young learners called Kaleidoscope Adventures. The website provides access to learning activities for children, 0-5 years and is part of a wider project which aimed to provide parents, teachers and other caregivers with knowledge and skills, and to support learning and development at home and in communities. This initiative was born as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic which saw children in the ECD sector with limited access to quality play and learning in their homes. Since the launch in the first quarter of 2022, more than 5,000 children and families have accessed the platform and engaged with the activities.
2023 Narrative: GrenadaIn collaboration with the Ministry of Education, UNICEF supported Professional Development Training Workshops during the Summer Holidays for Pre-primary and Kindergarten Teachers from Grenada, Carriacou and Petite Martinique. Emphasis was placed on the adult child interaction at the early childhood centres and schools with a focus on creating supportive environments, making effective use of strategies to help the preschoolers to resolve conflict, and adopting a problem-             solving approach to social conflict at the preschool and kindergarten level. Two hundred and     eighty-two (282) pre-primary and kindergarten teachers received the training over a two-week duration with more than 2,000 children benefitting from improved learning and care       environments        .      In collaboration with the Ministry of Education, 240 Early Childhood Educators have enhanced capacities in Effective Curriculum implementation, Instructional Leadership and Student Engagement. More than 2,000 preschoolers are benefiting from improved learning environments. Additionally, as part of the Ministry of Education’s Transition Policy, 56 Primary Schools received developmentally appropriate materials for interactive learning in kindergarten classes. More than 2, 185 children are benefitting from improved learning environments.MoE also focused on strengthening inclusive environments. Thirty-One Early Childhood Educators have been sensitized to support the learning and development needs of children with a focus on ADHD, Deafness and Speech and Language delays.The focus on Health and Safety in ECD settings continued with Sixty-Four (64) Preschools receiving supplies for hand washing, sanitizing and daily cleaning of furniture, learning equipment and furniture.MontserratA partnership with the University of the West Indies Cave Hill and the Ministry of Education resulted in a Special Education Diagnostic Clinic being convened by the Ministry of Education to identify those requiring learning and developmental support. During the Clinic sessions, 33 Students from the Primary and Secondary Schools received structured Educational and Psychological assessments, with 83.3% of those assessed being male students. A plan for support for the students will be developed.St. Lucia:Child Development and Guidance Centre (CDGC) and Dove Media Productions, a Parent Education Series, titled “Bonding” has been produced. This is an important innovation in the Eastern Caribbean Region, which when aired on the various media channels, has the potential to reach all families in St. Lucia with valuable information about positive parenting and caregiving. The Series will launch in January 2024. Additionally, under the ECD programme more than 2,000 children in the early childhood sector are benefitting from improved learning environments after Two Hundred and Ninety (290) Early Childhood Educators received training in using developmentally appropriate practices with young children.St. Vincent and the Grenadines In collaboration with the Ministry of Health, the promotion of exclusive breast feeding up to 6 months as a best practice for the infant and family continues. Advocacy material is being developed through the development of Human- Interest Stories to be shared with the public.St. Kitts and Nevis In collaboration with the Ministry of Health and the International Child Resource Institute (ICRI) sixty-three (63) children (0-5 years) have been engaged in early stimulation, play and learning in activity zones during their Infants’ and toddlers’ clinics in 2 health centers in Nevis. During the sessions in the activity zones parents and caregivers have received coaching to improve their play and communication with the children. Additionally, approximately 40 Educators, Social workers and Health Sector personnel participated in online training sessions on active learning and holistic development leading up to the opening of the Health Centre spaces in Nevis.In collaboration with the Department of Social Services, Nevis, UNICEF continued its support for the Second Chance Teen Mothers’ program through exposure to knowledge and the development of necessary skills and competencies to be able to provide the best quality early childhood development for their children. A developmental session which focused on the importance of providing young children with Positive Childhood Experiences (PCEs) to ensure sustainable learning and development during the life cycle have been facilitated. The 16 participants included the teen mothers and members of the RISE program.

2022 Narrative: With UNICEF ECA support, over 26,600 educational contents were developed while capacity of 628 teachers strengthened in digital content development. This result is expected to contribute to improved learning of 145,000 children and enhanced teaching support for 11,400 teachers across the countries in the region. 456 children from vulnerable families got better access to education through the provision of digital devices. Youth engagement and participation in safe school initiative have been enhanced. In addition, the Youth Agency Marketplace (YOMA) initiative as part of Generation Unlimited was commenced with the aim to provide a digital marketplace for youths.UNICEF ECA continued its support towards providing better digital learning opportunities for children in the countries of the region. In partnership with the OECS, 900 curriculum aligned digital learning contents for K-6 grades have been developed and are ready to be launched for public dissemination in early 2023. This provides digital learning opportunity to primary education students in five participating countries: Dominica, Grenada, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, St. Lucia and St. Kitts and Nevis. 400 teachers have been trained in the use of digital content development tools to create these learning resources. In addition, UNICEF ECA collaborated with Ministry of Education in Turks and Caicos Islands, Dominica, Antigua and Barbuda, Trinidad and Tobago, Grenada and Barbados to enrich digital learning resources for kindergarten, primary and secondary education. As a result, the capacity of 268 teachers and Education officials across six countries have been enhanced in effective use of digital skills in producing high quality digital learning resources. Consequently, 25,768 digital learning resources were developed. It is expected that 145,000 children and 11,400 teachers in the six countries will benefit from usage of these resources, which will contribute to improved learning outcome for students. UNICEF provided further support to the Ministry of Education in Trinidad and Tobago in developing five digital textbooks for primary and secondary. Moreover, newly developed self-training toolkit on Information and Communication Technology (ICT) skill to use the Ministry's Learning Management System as well as web-based pedagogy instruction was used to train 100 primary and secondary education officers. These were also made available in both hard (500) and soft copies to allow access for all teachers. Some 456 students from vulnerable families in Trinidad and Tobago benefitted from the provision of a laptop in support of their continuity of learning. In terms of connectivity, UNICEF worked with ITU to pilot a capacity expansion project in primary and secondary schools in Barbados. This project included an assessment of usage and temporary upgrades for selected schools. Subsequent assessments will be completed to collect quantitative data on usage and the impact of expanded access and capacity at the given schools. With UNICEF ECA contribution, the 3rd Ministerial Forum of the Caribbean Safe School Initiative (CSSI) and Youth Forum during 11th Caribbean Disaster Management Conference were organized successfully. The forums offered the opportunity to reflect upon the changes and challenges the Caribbean has faced since launching the CSSI. They also provided the platform for youth to engage in discussion and express their voice and opinion on the issue.As part of GenU initiative, UNICEF ECA commenced the rolling out of YOMA in Trinidad and Tobago with the aim to establish it as one of the primary mechanisms to engage, reach, and impact young people. As part of the initiative, social impact activities aimed at motivating and engaging youth more actively in addressing some key issues related to youth entrepreneurship, climate change are being designed. Moreover, preparation works to launch a localized YOMA platform in first quarter of 2023 have commenced.﻿A key lesson learned was the fact that blended education, especially the online delivery of education, is much more complex than previously thought. Curriculum based Content development, connectivity and availability of devices are just a few initial steps. Strategic planning needs to take place at the ministerial level, at the school level and classrooms for effective and efficient delivery. If an appropriate stepwise strategy is not devised, premature delivery of online education can further enhance the digital divide contributing to further inequity for the already disadvantaged groups.In addition to respective Ministries of Education in the countries, UNICEF ECA continued its partnership with regional bodies such as the OECS and the Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency (CDEMA) to implement digital learning and safe school related initiatives. New partnerships with the private sector are being explored in support of rolling out of YOMA in Trinidad and Tobago.
2023 Narrative: AnguillaIn collaboration with the Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) and the Ministry of Education, 57 teachers from the early childhood, primary and secondary school sectors have enhanced knowledge and skills to support their children and students to manage their behavior and understand positive approaches to discipline.British Virgin Islands Return to Happiness training was conducted in BVI in which 46 participants across all sectors participated. Meetings were held with the Disaster Office and Curriculum Officers for capacity support opportunity to integrate RTH into the curriculum.DominicaSafe School recognition program was introduced in 19 schools in which 38 participants 16 male and 26 female took part. In addition, a school safety training package was developed, and 26  teachers have been trained on the school safety training course. For Risk reduction and resilience education Training of Trainers (ToT) was conducted for return to happiness in which 46 (5 male and 41 female) participants have been trained who are expected to rollout the training in all primary and secondary schools. With support from USAID and in collaboration with OECS 174 curriculum aligned digital units for grade K to 3 have are produced by the curriculum writers in Dominica. 90 lesson plans developed 15 teachers trained in Augmented reality, 31 education leaders enrolled digital leadership training out of which 6 leaders earned certificate of digital leadership. A total of 90 teachers enrolled in digital pedagogy out of which 12 were certified in DP. 22 teachers were trained in content development, 4 specialists trained in content assurance and 21 teachers trained in development of H5P with Lumi.GrenadaUnder the spotlight initiative, HFLE tool configuration took place and workshop was organized to use zoom platform to conduct HFLE training during school closure or emergency times.MontserratIn collaboration with the Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) and the Ministry of Education, 91 teachers from the early childhood, primary and secondary school sectors have enhanced knowledge and skills to support their children and students to manage their behavior and understand positive approaches to discipline.St. Lucia:Safe School recognition program was introduced in 23 schools in which 46 (16 male and 30 females) teachers and educators participated. As follow up to the Transforming Education Summit, sensory corner support equipment such as sensory blankets, headphones, fidget, and emotion dice were provide to MoE for provision of psychosocial support to challenged children. St. Vincent and the Grenadines Safe School recognition program was introduced in schools in which 78 participants 32 male and 46 female took part. In addition, a school safety training package was developed, and 22 (8 male and 14 female) teachers have been trained on the school safety training course. UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education's integration of safety plans and the Climate Change and Disaster Risk Reduction CC-DRR Curriculum UNICEF worked alongside the Safety Unit from the Ministry of Education to facilitate three (3) two-day workshops in the Grenadines where 47 teacher/administrators, 20 students and 9 parents from Secondary, Primary and Early Childhood Centers participated in safety planning, safety simulation exercises and the integration of the Climate Change Mitigation and Disaster Risk Reduction curriculum into the existing lower secondary level school curriculum.St. Kitts and Nevis Safe School recognition program was introduced in schools in which 60 participants 29 male and 31 female took part. In addition, a school safety training package was developed, and 38 (15 male and 23 female) teachers have been trained on the school safety training course.

Description: This project aims to qualify the intersectoral response of education and health in the school. The main strategy will be strengthening the management, technical capacity and evaluation of the Health in School Program. The main objectives of this project are beyond to strengthen integrated actions between health and education: improve health conditions for students, reduce teenage pregnancy (the main cause of school dropout among girls in Brazil), and improve the management of the School Health Program.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Health

Although there are some planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO resumed the organization of intersectoral health education groups in all Brazilian states. Five regional meetings with the Education and Health secretariats were held in all five Brazilian regions. The meetings focused on drawing up action plans for each of the 27 Brazilian states.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1094 National annual workplan to improve national education polices in Brazil - 2020/2021
Description: The Ministry of Education of Brazil (MEC) is a UNESCO partner in the implementation of education projects that benefit public policies throughout the country. This project is the first project under the MEC / UNESCO 2020/2021 agreement. Its objective is to provide technical support to the various departments of MEC, as well as to give the development of studies, research, training, materials, and methodologies for the priority educational themes selected for cooperation.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: Since January 2021, the project has been developed and interactions have been stablished with the 9 Secretariats from the Ministry of Education (SESU, SEALF, SETEC, SEMESP, CAPES, EBSERH, FNDE, SERES and INEP) to implement the actions from the proposed sub-projects. The project aims to provide technical support to the Secretariats of MEC when developing studies, research, training courses, materials, and methodologies for educational selected themes in the scope of the National Cooperation stablished between UNESCO and MEC, managed by the Interministerial Coordination Group (GIC).
2022 Narrative: This project ended the creation of formative assessment items aimed at measuring the skills of relating phonemes to their written representation, locating explicit information in texts, recognizing what natural numbers indicate in different situations, etc., to be made available by MEC for teachers of the early years of Elementary School, in 2023.Furthermore, this project created studies and strategies to expand and strengthen the university infrastructure, the promotion of Admission and the permanence and training of students and professionals, as well as the improvement of management in Federal Institutions of Higher Education. This project also developed assessments on the positive and negative impacts of the new Corona virus (COVID-19) on Higher Education policies and programs, as well as developing new strategies for action during and after the pandemic.This project also elaborated subsidiary studies to the process of internationalization of Higher Education, from the programs and agreements managed by the Directorate of International Relations - DRI/CAPES, in order to subsidize the management of these processes, especially in the identification and proposal for the improvement of the agreements and programs, with a view to creating and strengthening research networks and improving Brazilian education.This project concluded studies in order to qualify the institutional management of the national policy of Professional and Technological Education (EPT), making the Secretariat of Professional and Technological Education of the Ministry of Education (Setec/MEC) more active in the improvement and availability of qualified information on the EPT, in proposing strategic guidelines and more efficient mechanisms to serve its different audiences, including demands related to research and technological innovation, thus seeking to strengthen the quality of EPT and meet the goals set out in the PEI/MEC 2020-2023 and its association with PNE.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: MSDCF 4.3: National institutions strengthened to deliver shock-resilient education and learning
Sub-Output: JAM: Education system is strengthened to deliver resilient, equitable, inclusive, quality, and relevant education services with a focus on the most vulnerable (children with disabilities, children at risk of dropping out, out-of-school and those affected by emergencies)
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: Core Funding, European Union, Spanish Committee for UNICEF, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, UNICEF Private Sector Fundraising, UNICEF WASH Thematic Trust Fund
Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Education, Youth and Information, Jamaica Teaching Council
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 6 Clean Water and Sanitation
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: Emphasizing learning recovery and resilience, the JCO continued) to fund the completion of the Ministry of Education and Youth’s Learning Passport (LP) Jamaica, Educational Management Information System (EMIS) and Accessible Digital Textbook (ADT) pilots reaching over 4000 educators, administrators, parents and students. Recognized as a featured learning recovery effort by the MOEY, the LP is well-positioned to grow to support mainstream learning through the secondary level, ongoing capacity development of teachers on remote learning and provide continuity during any future school closures. 932 lessons across 19 categories were developed and sector sensitizations were staged through webinars, workshops and social media activations including a summer series with playful, age-appropriate, culturally relevant, Foundational Literacy and Numeracy (FLN) content that garnered 500 views and directed students to the LP using a QR code. A FLN focused “Cornershop Challenge” poster was distributed to 100 locations island-wide in partnership with a telecommunication company’s foundation. That social media reel received 209,000 views. The EMIS pilot was completed in 20 schools potentially impacting 2000 students. 87 administrators participated in training on eight data points related to student and teacher attendance, behaviour, and student assessment.   Penetration tests were completed and the EMIS platform is preparing to go live aiming for full roll out within 2 years.The JCO made progress on inclusive content development with two of the targeted 12 accessible digital books reaching some 3777 users and the remaining ten slated for dissemination in 2024. Two ADT informational webinars were attended by some 700 teachers. Innocenti released its report on the pilot with specific recommendations for inclusive digital teaching and learning in the Jamaican context. Support to safer school environments continued to be prioritised. A total of 409 schools received trainings on implementing the student-centred School-wide Positive Behaviour Intervention and Support (SWPBIS) framework, potentially impacting some 250,000 students. Twenty master trainers completed PFA training to help create SWPBIS aligned communities of care in 2024. Thirty-one participants also completed the Spotlight Initiative funded Leadership for Safer School (LSS) programme, while, through the same funding source, 611 students with disabilities and 152 of their parents and teachers received GBV training.  100 school leaders completed Child Friendly Schools (CFS) training and 100 teachers completed the Jamaica Teaching Council’s second PFA-based Return to Happiness (RTH) course Together these initiatives support ongoing efforts towards improved mental health and psychosocial support sector-wide. Surveys of these course participants are underway to enable identification of best practices in how schools can prioritize children’s rights throughout 2024.The JCO  provided technical assistance to the finalization of a national character education training plan aligned with the SWPBIS scale-up, as well as the national Education Transformation Oversight Council and the National Violence Prevention Commission.  Finally, the school wellness survey, the Welbin Index, was disseminated to key stakeholders and to some 500 individual schools (accounting for almost 70% of all primary and secondary schools). Efforts were also made to involve youth in program design and implementation, referencing relevant U-Report polls and facilitating ongoing dialogue with JCO Youth Council members.
2024 Narrative: To support improved data-driven decision-making, leading to more student-centered and effective educational support, resource allocation and increased sector resilience, the national EMIS roll out started in 245 schools identified by the education ministry based on device and internet access. This represents the first phase of an SDG fund digital education focused joint programme that began implementation in September. In addition, 1100 principals were sensitized to the EMIS through the UNICEF developed EMIS behaviour change management strategy required to ensure buy in and encourage the onboarding of all primary and secondary schools between 2024-26. EMIS data collection started with Attendance and Behaviour modules along with the school census. A digital audit instrument, slated to become interoperable with the EMIS, was also completed with UNICEF support and staff members of the Technical and Vocational Unit were trained to facilitate the creation of a database of the physical resources available in the 15 technical and agricultural high schools to better determine where technical support and resources are most needed.  Data driven efforts to address sector inequity also included content creation. Ongoing promotion of the FLN focused Learning Passport (LP) platform (following successful completion of the pilot) and of the complete 12-book Accessible Digital Textbook (ADT) series as core components of the education ministry’s online summer school has led to over 8000 users since both went live in mid-2024. The ADTs are featured on the LP and the JCO developed “Summer Spark” online Instagram series and “Cornershop Challenge” poster which features a QR code linked to the LP was reprinted and distributed to 100 locations island-wide through a partnership with a local telecommunication company’s foundation. A UNICEF led workshop with publishers and Jamaica’s signing of the Marrakesh Treaty has also confirmed interest in developing guidelines for the incorporation of universal design for learning principles into the country’s textbook approval process.  Efforts to empower teachers to create safe, supportive, inclusive, and growth-oriented learning environments also continued, with 191 school leaders completing various CFS-focused programmes potentially impacting some 25,000 students, 50 more schools completing training related to the Schoolwide Positive Behaviour Intervention and Support (SWPBIS)/VAC framework pushing the number of schools using this methodology to close to 600 (60% of primary and secondary schools). MHPSS also emerged as a key element of instruction with the total of teachers and volunteers having completed aligned training in the PFA focused Return to Happiness (RTH) approach and socio-emotional learning, rising to over 1000. This includes 530 teachers from the regions most affected by Hurricane Beryl and members of the 63 Communities of Care teams who support Guidance Counsellors in SWPBIS scale up efforts island-wide. In addition, 15,000 students received copies of the “Be Prepared,” disaster preparedness and response activity guide following the July passage of Hurricane Beryl as part of in-school based PFA sessions in the 45 most affected schools. These also included the creation and distribution of PFA support kits. An online version of “Be Prepared” was also shared sector wide. 348 recreation kits remain positioned with the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM). UNICEF continued to support Education in Emergency (EiE) efforts providing substantial technical and financial assistance to the finalization of the Safe Schools Policy. School-based emergency guidelines and disaster preparedness and response plans will form part of the EMIS in its phased rolled out.

Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund

SDG Targets: 16.3 Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: As a result of UNICEF’s support, consultations regarding ‘Access to Justice and effective remedies were conducted with 124 children including those with disabilities, from schools, childcare facilities, and (pre-)detention centers, which provided valuable insights into their lived experiences, concerns, and recommendations and also assessed the children’s ability to exercise their right to access justice and seek remedies for rights violations. Additionally, consultations were conducted with 34 key stakeholders, including government, NGOs, and the judiciary, resulting in critical insights that helped verify whether States Parties are taking the necessary legislative, administrative, and other measures to ensure children's right to access justice and effective remedies, thereby ensuring the full realization of their rights.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1138 - Contributing for the implementation of results-based management and governance of the national response to STD/AIDS and Viral Hepatitis among vulnerable populations focusing on access and quality of health education
Description: The present project aims to contribute to the efficiency and effectiveness of results management, improving the governance of the national response to STD, AIDS and Viral Hepatitis, focusing on prevention and health education as well as on expanding access, research and quality of services to vulnerable population.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
The Project has been working on HIV prevention with the key population for HIV. The activities of this Project are always focused on gender equality and gender mainstream. The Project always seeks to guarantee access to condoms. However, other alternatives to HIV prevention strategies, such as combined prevention, as a focus on the most vulnerable populations, are always considered. Involvement with organized civil society is still a fundamental axis of project actions. New technologies are always designed to access these populations and to foster access to treatment and prevention. Besides, it ensures that evidence-based strategies are the driving axes of all project actions.
There were not many Project's actions during 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. However, there is a forecast of continuity of preventive operations - remote and in face-to-face - with civil society for the second half.
In the second half of 2020, 35 civil society organizations were selected to support actions in the territory for HIV prevention, other STIs with COVID as the central axis. Actions are starting and are expected to last throughout 2021.
Besides, it is essential to highlight that this Project contributes to 40 C/5 and SDG achievement. As can be seen in the success of the expected outcomes and goals and objectives:
Major Program I, Expected Result: 6.
Goal 3: (3.3, 3.5, and 3.d) Through access to condoms and combined prevention strategies, especially for vulnerable and key populations for the epidemic.
Goal 4: (4.7, 4.a). Investing in lifelong education in partnerships with organized civil society and NGOs that invest in the education of people living with HIV/AIDS. Besides, the Project invests in distance education strategies and face-to-face training of young people as strategic alternatives for training young leaders for HIV.
Goal 10: (10.3 and 10.4). Promoting gender equity actions, implemented through sexual diversity, access to health services.
2022 Narrative: The Project's goal is to apply Result-based management and Governance in the implementation of the National Policy for STD/HIV/AIDS and Viral Hepatitis to enhance the efficiency and efficacy of Preventive Education Programs toward the most vulnerable population. The Brazilian Health Ministry is a UNESCO greater partner and has been working on HIV prevention with the most vulnerable populations: young people, men who have sex with men, transvestites, female sex workers, drug users. To do so, UBO and the Project have established strategies to reach the most vulnerable populations easily in the territory. This Project supported formal education programs, enhancing Program Health in School and Project Health and Prevention in School, from which we implement EDUCAIDS in Brazil. However, considering the political conservative scenario in the country, schools are just talking about prevention against specific groups. During 2020, there are almost no school opened. The public schools were opened util the middle of March, considering the sanitary emergency. Also, informal education activities will be developed in partnership with civil society organizations that work with society's most vulnerable segments.The Project managed to achieve the main proposed results:Developing eight distance education courses for health professionals, education professionals, organized civil society, and young people; These courses are being incorporated into the Ministry of Health's distance education platform to ensure greater access.Twenty NGOs were selected to work with HIV prevention and health promotion. Actions are focused on the most vulnerable populations and key populations for HIV.Exhibitions and debates on the combined prevention of HIV and syphilis were held.Investing in lifelong education in partnerships with organized civil society and with NGOs that invest in the education of people living with HIV / AIDS. Besides, the Project invests in distance education strategies and face-to-face training of young people as strategic alternatives for training young leaders for HIV.As part of the scope of the Project's objectives, it is to promote studies and research on epidemiological, behavioral, and effectiveness trends in STI / HIV / AIDS. The Project, in partnership with some publica universities such as University of São Paulo developed some studies related to these issues. It developed: a cascade of care with an estimate of those infected with HIV; epidemiological and assistance analyzes of HIV and AIDS; epidemiological analysis of viral hepatitis reports; analyzes related to notifications of pregnant women with HIV / AIDS; analyzes related to cases of congenital syphilis; analyzes similar to syphilis during pregnancy. The Project has provided Management with the development of actions that contribute to analyzing the dynamics of the HIV / AIDS epidemic in the state and the strengthening of Management's governance capacity.The production and systematization of technical-scientific information have become an essential strategy for reaching health professionals and contributing to public political processes.Women, including Lesbians, bisexuals, transvestites, and transsexuals, were the population group with the most data produced. Consequently, new strategies of action and professional training.Currently, the HIV epidemic affects more young people, so the focus of the project's actions was aimed at young people. Both research, interventions, and strategies considered young people, men who have sex with men and women in situations of social vulnerability and difficulty accessing education and health services.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilience to Climate Change and Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Outcome: Caribbean people, communities, and institutions enhance their adaptive capacity for inclusive, gender responsive DRM and climate change adaptation and mitigation
Output: MSDCF 5.1: Strengthened institutional  capacity for gender-inclusive adaptation and disaster management
Sub-Output: 2.6.15 BDS Increasing the Resilience of the Education System to Climate Change Impacts in the Eastern Caribbean
Description:
The project “Increasing the Resilience of the Education System to Climate Change Impacts in the Eastern Caribbean” aims to advance climate-resilient sustainable development in both countries by enhancing the resilience of their respective educational systems to extreme climate events. This will be done through the three components:
Component 1: Strengthen the enabling environment for adaptation planning within the education sector at the national and regional level
Component 2: Strengthen the capacity of schools, businesses, communities and households to understand climate risks and adaptation options, and cope with socio-emotional impacts,
Component 3: Climate-proofing interventions implemented in select school buildings to improve resilience to, and recovery from, extreme climate events
Component 3: Climate-proofing interventions implemented in select school buildings to improve resilience to, and recovery from, extreme climate events"
Agencies: United Nations Human Settlement Programme
Implementation partners: Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States

Description: In Brazil there was no regulation of the collaboration regime among the federative actors (municipalities, states and federal) or the definition of legal forms of cooperation, despite the Federal Constitution guidelines. Due to the educational system inequalities between the geographic regions and results on student achievement and educational equity and equality this project aims to contribute to construction of an effective collaboration regime among the federal entities assuring a quality education for all through public policies built democratically and designed based on articulated programs and actions.

2021 Narrative:
The Project was interrupted in 2018. A substantive revision was signed in September 2020 and its execution was resumed in 2021 with the following ongoing activities:
• Study aiming mapping international experiences in voluntary certification of teachers who work in literacy to support the Secretariat of Literacy in the formulation of possible public policies for the continued education of literacy teachers or those in the early years of elementary school.
• Study aiming mapping evidence, good practices in everyday school life and practical tools for educational planning and the exercise of leadership by school managers to support the Literacy Department in the formulation of materials that assist in the training and performance of these important agents in improving learning.
• Aiming to introduce and subsidize the pedagogical work on the effectiveness of different approaches used to teach children to read and write, the National Reading Panel was created in the United States in 1997 and published in 2000, involving different specialists and was fully based on scientific research evidence. The NRP was one of the main references to produce the National Report on Evidence-Based Literacy, prepared by the Ministry of Education. The mentioned material was translated into Portuguese, revised, and diagramed for its publication.
2022 Narrative: The following activities are taking place:A study aiming to map international experiences in voluntary certification of teachers who work in literacy to support the Secretariat of Literacy in the formulation of possible public policies for the continued education of literacy teachers or those in the early years of elementary school.A study aiming mapping evidence, good practices in everyday school life, and practical tools for educational planning and the exercise of leadership by school managers to support the Literacy Department in the formulation of materials that assist in the training and performance of these important agents in improving learning

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
Focal users: Nicholas Guribie, N'guetta Koutoua Emery Bosso
2022 Narrative: Countries recognized that the passage of legislation can begin or sustain attitudinal change against corporal punishment and other forms of interpersonal violence, as they tackle general societal violence. High-level advocacy briefs on the legal status of corporal punishment in all 12 programme countries, development of a draft Victims’ Rights Policy and 19 new draft laws against gender-based violence in Grenada, and the opening of the child-friendly Family Court Division in Antigua and Barbuda were among initiatives which have the potential for long-term, transformative impact for protecting girls, boys and women through legal and policy reform and institutional strengthening. The Eastern Caribbean Area (ECA) registered an uptick in gun-related violence, family violence as well as school-based interpersonal violence among peers, sustaining concern over the issue of Violence Against Children (VAC). UNICEF supported governments to continue tackling the issue through a multi-pronged approach. Within this output, UNICEF supported governments through technical assistance to improve their institutional frameworks to prevent and respond to VAC. There were several notable achievements. One was the production of key advocacy briefs towards ending state sanctioned use of corporal punishment. This resulted in increased knowledge of stakeholders on the legal status of corporal punishment in each of the 12 ECA countries and territories, where the eye-opening research highlighted persistent legislative gaps. In Grenada, a draft Victims’ Right Policy and 19 pieces of draft legislation for ending family and gender-based violence are being considered by the new administration. In Antigua and Barbuda, the first Family Court Division was opened in July 2022, with the technical and financial support of UNICEF. Cases can be lodged via the e-portal and the people-centred nature of the court whether through in-person or virtual hearings, is already helping reduce stigma associated with gender-based violence and child abuse, making the process more user-friendly, efficient and effective. In Trinidad and Tobago, a National Protocol for the Prevention and Management of Child Abuse and National Child Safeguarding Strategy were delivered in support of government’s response to curtailing VAC. This was also supported by the roll-out of Primero Child Protection Case Management Information System increasing the capacity of frontline workers by reducing administrative burdens and supporting better quality case work. The issue of children’s online safety was brought to the fore with programming through the OECS Education Unit and associated awareness building of approximately 121 frontline workers to improve the safety of children’s online presence. Lastly, advocacy and support were provided to the Barbados and St Kitts and Nevis governments to ensure that forthcoming legislation eliminates all forms of corporal punishment to better adhere to the international standards for children’s alternative care.    The use of corporal punishment and the belief that it is a necessary form of discipline to reduce the surge in general societal violence is widespread. Policymakers have also demonstrated an understanding that community crime undermines positive parenting. However, they were hesitant to take bold legislative changes that negatively affected public opinion. Another challenge was the increased school-based violence, where teachers and children needed to re-embrace the positive behaviour management strategies after two straight years of online interaction caused by the COIVD-19 measures. This temporary phenomenon gave rise to political promises for harsher responses to ‘soft approaches’ on children in Antigua and Barbuda ahead of general elections. Together these realities mean that UNICEF ECA’s consistent advocacy and support for the development and implementation of new laws, policies, protocols, and attitudes to support the prevention and response to VAC will be critical over the medium to long term.  ﻿Globally, as more countries legally prohibit the practice of corporal punishment and document their circumstances, a lesson learned for the Eastern Caribbean is that apart from use of countries’ parliamentary processes to outlaw the use of physical force against children, activists will need to consider other strategies for accelerating banning corporal punishment through public interest litigation and judicial condemnation.   Strategic partnerships with global actors End Corporal Punishment and the European Union/United Nations Spotlight programme, together with relevant national Child Protection agencies, ministries of legal affairs [and their legal drafting departments and the civil society organization (CSO)], Grenada National Organisation of Women, were critical to the systems strengthening initiatives implemented in 2022. The latter championed policy and legislative initiatives while the CSO partner was key in public awareness activities as they link to historically marginalized communities. In addition, in both Spotlight countries - Grenada and Trinidad and Tobago, the respective Spotlight Working Groups offer support needed to drive the policy and legislative agenda across the sectoral work of the many UN partners.
2023 Narrative: Dominica:In 2023, UNICEF and other partners’ long-term advocacy resulted in the parliamentary approval of key laws that ban behaviour that can harm children or require action to protect children. This suite of laws comprised the Children (Care and Adoption) Act, which provides for the care and protection of children, operation of adoption services and for related matters; Domestic Violence Act which provides greater protection for victims of domestic violence and makes provision for granting protection orders and for related matters; Maintenance of Children Act which provides for maintenance of children in conformity with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the connected and incidental matters; and the Status of Children Act which provides for equal status of children, removes all discriminatory provisions in the laws relating to a child born out of wedlock and provides for related matters.GrenadaThrough the EU UN Joint Spotlight on gender-based violence (GBV), UNICEF collaborated with PAHO to ensure that 75 service providers knew how to apply the draft Victims’/Survivors’ Rights Policy and the standard operating procedures to their work with the affected population. UNICEF technical assistance also supported the near finalization of bills to improve the legislative framework for preventing and responding to GBV. This includes an outright ban on preventing pregnant girls from mainstream education and on the use of corporal punishment in educational settings. The accountability mechanism for the draft Victims’/Survivors’ Rights Policy was established to ensure cabinet approval of the policy before year-end. To facilitate passage of the draft legislation, UNICEF ensured that parliamentarians had strengthened capacity to use parliamentary procedures, integrate gender concerns into their ongoing work in the Houses of Parliament and take specific bipartisan actions to address gender-based and family violence, as this will be key to the societal transformations required.  St. Vincent and the Grenadines UNICEF supported the Child Development Division, Ministry of National Mobilisation in the implementation of the Primero Child Protection Information Management System (CPIMS+) to enhance child protection systems strengthening in emergency and non-emergency settings and improve case management from identification and registration, to assessment, case planning, referrals and transfers, and case closure.

Description: The present project has the purpose to give support to the Ministry of Education and the Brazilian Hospital Services in its primary mission to create appropriate technical conditions for teaching and research in healthcare in hospitals linked to the Brazilian federal universities network. These conditions are created by actions of physical, technological and human resources restructuration and especially creating the management model, seeking the excellence in the provision of health care services and the need to make them suitable for undergraduate training practice scenarios and specialists.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: This project has started in the second year of Ebserh's activities, in a context where the first professionals from the headquarters were still being hired and the first hospitals were making up the network, whose priority was its integration and consolidation. It is a project whose purpose is to support EBSERH in its main mission of creating adequate technical conditions for care, teaching, and research in the health area, through actions of physical and technological restructuring, provisioning and developing people and, mainly, the management model.
2022 Narrative: The achievements against the planned outputs and outcomes· Completion of studies to bring improvements in the management processes of the surgical waiting list in the federal university hospitals of the Ebserh Network, with a focus on reducing the waiting time of patients for elective surgeries.· Completion of studies to support the process of definition, monitoring, collection, and management of data from teaching and extension activities, so that it is possible to plan an institutional policy of information management that allows the dimensioning of the real installed capacity of the teaching activities in the Network's hospitals and that favors the best use of the existing structure and planning of adjustments as needed.· Completion of System Architecture related to the processes and management of information linked to Technical Education, Undergraduate, Graduate, and Extension activities carried out in the University Hospitals of the Ebserh Network so that it is possible to plan an institutional information management policy.· Completion of studies to support the process of identification, description, and specification of needs for the implementation of prototypes of new technologies used in teaching carried out by means of Information and Communication Technologies.Challenges and risks in implementationThe execution of the project had been affected by the successive managerial changes faced by the Federal Public Administration, which consumed approximately twenty-four months of its duration. EBSERH has undergone profound changes in its value proposition to society and has a new strategic map, which implies new priorities, challenges, and changes in the project scope.It is also important to mention that the COVID-19 pandemic caused delays in the project and affected hiring, so that, from the consultants hired, only one delivered products, because all the others were hired between November and December 2021, and therefore did not have time to make their deliveries.This project started in the second year of Ebserh's activities, in a context where the first professionals from the headquarters were still being hired and the first hospitals were making up the network, whose priority was its integration and consolidation. It is a project whose purpose is to support Ebserh in its main mission of creating adequate technical conditions for care, teaching, and research in the health area, through actions of physical and technological restructuring, provisioning, and development of people, and, mainly, the management model.Since then, two main challenges have been impacting the project's progress: the constant changes in public administration management and the COVID-19 pandemic. To overcome the situation, a review of the project's results was carried out to align the project with the real needs of the EBSERH Network. Even in a challenging scenario, eight consultants were hired in 2021 who are currently conducting important studies with the intention of improving the processes of the EBSERH Network and that should be finalized in 2022.

2022 Narrative: Prova São Paulo Meta-evaluation: The São Paulo test is composed of four assessments: Portuguese language, mathematics, natural sciences, humanities plus text production for primary education. UNESCO is implementing the Meta-evaluation assessment Research of the São Paulo Test involving both the systematization of the knowledge already produced since 2007 including the organization and registration of the documentation, as well as the definition of an analysis methodology. It is intended, at the end of the evaluation process, to also build a model for monitoring the implementation of the São Paulo Digital Test.Methodological Study for São Paulo Digital Test: Detailed work plan with objectives and content, as well as a methodological guide with the work guidelines for processing the São Paulo Test – Study of the construction of the São Paulo Digital Test proficiency scale in the curricular components: Portuguese Language; Mathematics; Natural Sciences; Human Sciences.Peaceful School Coexistence – Elaboration of a measuring instrument for the diagnosis of School co-existence for the Municipal Teaching Network in São Paulo. The work will be based on evidence regarding the interrelationship between well-being, positive school climate, promotion of coexistence and lower school dropouts, and a greater sense of belonging, aiming for better academic performance compared to a lower incidence of bullying and suffering emotional, among others.Anti-racism study: investigate the presence of racism and anti-racism in educational spaces, through the analysis of Political-Pedagogical Projects (PPP) for the organization of physical spaces, iconographies available in the environments, didactic and educational materials, toys, activities pedagogical and social relations in/of schools and in interactions in the school environment.All the products that result from the technical cooperation are absorbed, implemented, and monitored by the secretariat as well as by the schools making all the activities mentioned above sustainable and completely absorbed by the partner.

2022 Narrative: Government in partnership with UNIECF has achieved an increase in Early Childhood Development (ECD) coverage by 22 % of migrant children and those in their host communities. UNICEF also supported the launch of the ECD Centre of Excellence at the University of Guyana for a multidisciplinary approach to Early Childhood Development through research, teaching, and practice. It is serving 150 children ages 3 months to 8 years and is providing care for children with learning disabilities as well as migrants and other vulnerable children.

El proyecto buscará mitigar la migración irregular desde El Salvador y reducir la estigmatización de los retornados al aumentar el acceso equitativo a oportunidades educativas formales para posibles migrantes, retornados y sus familias para generar esperanza, prosperidad y autoestima positiva en sus vidas.

El Sub-Output está alineado con las transiciones de Educación y Empleo y protección social.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: El Salvador Ministerio de Educación, Ciencia y Tecnología
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project promotes activities linked to gender equity through its academic offerings. Women are a prioritized population for enrollment, in particular in non-traditional areas, and individual psychosocial support is delivered considering gender needs. A referral mechanism is in place for specialized assistance related to Gender-Based-Violence (GBV). For women in the scholarship program, the psychological service constitutes a key support for their wellbeing and selfcare, as well as an increase in knowledge and empowerment. In addition, psychosocial services for women contributes to retention, empowerment for employment, and in some cases helps to reduce the pressure from their partners to migrate irregularly.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Human rights approach is considered directly by providing education right to vulnerable population and out-school persons. It is algo a crosscutting theme for psychosocial assistance, including referrals and partnership with human rights specialized institutions.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Los principios transversales relevantes del proyecto son: 1) empoderamiento de las mujeres y equidad de género y 2) desarrollo positivo de juventudes. Esto se toma en cuenta con base en un breve análisis coyuntural, plasmado en el documento de proyecto, que aborda el conflicto o la violencia de la siguiente forma: Una considerable proporción de migrantes irregulares son jóvenes. Esto es debido a necesidades económicas por ausencia de oportunidades, por violencia y por inseguridad; además, muchos jóvenes son objetivos para ser reclutados por pandillas... En este sentido, el proyecto facilita oportunidades educacionales a jóvenes migrantes para garantizar  su desarrollo positivo a través del acceso a trabajo formal y medios de vida.
2023 Narrative: Para diciembre de 2023, el Proyecto facilitó el acceso a empleo/nuevos emprendimientos nuevos o mejorados para 479 beneficiarios de becas (42% hombres, 58% mujeres): 383 becarios (39% hombres y 61% mujeres) accedieron a nuevas actividades laborales/emprendimientos y 96 becarios (55% hombres y 45% mujeres) mejoraron la percepción de la calidad de sus empleos/emprendimientos.  Un total de 2,505 becarios estaban inscritos en los programas educativos: cursos cortos, programas educativos técnicos superiores y programas de educación acelerada.
2024 Narrative: El proyecto brindó oportunidades educativas integrales a 1,909 personas en riesgo de desplazamiento y en condiciones de vulnerabilidad, con el objetivo de reducir la migración irregular y fomentar la esperanza, la prosperidad y la autoestima en sus vidas. Esto incluye a 427 migrantes retornados. Para el año 2024, el proyecto ha alcanzado un total de 7,155 personas desde su inicio.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: Prosperity: Prosperity and quality of life for all
Outcome: Outcome 4: Inclusive and environmentally sustainable economic growth, with productive diversification, industrial strengthening, resilient infrastructures, increased productivity and innovation, transparency, social participation and enhancement of micro and small enterprises
Output: 4.1 Public policies, private initiatives and institutional capacities strengthened to promote the improvement of value chains, stimulating innovation, entrepreneurship and associativism, improving competitiveness to promote productive inclusion and sustainable economic development
Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ1016 Lessons in entrepreneurship to achieve an emancipatory and transformative education
Description: This project aims to benefit, through educational activities, secondary education students, of all genders, enrolled in Brazilian public schools, in themes focused on the development of entrepreneurship, aiming at achieving an emancipatory and transforming education. The activities foreseen in this project will be carried out face-to-face and at distance, using digital platforms, comprising courses, workshops, lectures, seminars, and conversation circles, with the provision of videos and educational material.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Instituto Êxito
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In the scope of this project, it has been created a 1 training methodology and the pedagogical material was elaborated containing 16 lessons on entrepreneurship for students. The material will be printed and distributed to students in 2022, as part of a pilot project.
- 1 in-progress teacher's guide with guidelines on how to conduct the entrepreneurship course with their students.
- 1 online platform available with videos and materials to enable students to take the course on entrepreneurship virtually.
- 1 partnership established with the Secretariat of Education of Distrito Federal, which will enable the implementation of the pilot project with lower and upper secondary education teachers and students from public schools in 2022.
2022 Narrative: The main results achieved in this output were: 1 training course on entrepreneurship adapted for distance learning;  earning materials in the process of being printed and distributed; Face-to-face training about entrepreneurship carried out with high school students from the public school system in the city of Bezerros, Pernambuco State.Regarding gender equality, the project foresees that half of the students enrolled in the entrepreneurship training will be girls. The survey carried out as the first activity of the project showed a higher proportion of girls interested in entrepreneurship than boys, which points to a great need to work on this theme among the young female population. In addition, the training material was careful to avoid gender stereotypes and show examples of women entrepreneurs as a way to empower and encourage female students to fulfill their personal and professional ambitions and projects.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
