Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ5003 Free Education
Description: The Free Education Project consists in the development of an interactive platform to provide capacity building, enhancement and the insertion of young people in the workplace through technological solutions that enable the creation of educational itineraries adaptable to the user's profile, as well as free learning using mutual collaboration mechanisms. The Project aims to implement an educational platform for youth and ensure they have the necessary skills to match them with job opportunities in the industry sector aiming to reduce unemployment rates among youth and promote training and lifelong skills.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Serviço Nacional de Aprendizagem Industrial
SDG Targets: 8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: Not available yet.
2022 Narrative: The Free Education Project consists on the development of an interactive platform that aims to provide training, improvement and insertion of young people in the job market through technological solutions that allow the creation of pedagogical itineraries adapted to the user's profile, in addition to free learning using collaboration mechanisms mutual.In 2022, one of the main goals of the project was to continue the mobilization of users, ensuring that the project gains more scale. Therefore, it is essential to promote the continuity and establishment of new partnerships with governments at the federal, state and municipal levels, in addition to the strategy of seeking new agreements with private companies.The following objectives were met: (i) to carry out maintenance, development of the web application interfaces and evolution of the technological products of the Free Education project, as well as to identify technology gaps and ensure the improvement of use; (ii) UI/UX designer for the platform; (iii) Review and update trails and resources already published on the platform; (iv) develop new learning trails; (v) Develop and adjust methodologies to meet the needs of partners and customers and monitor and generate feedback on the training trails with the necessary actors; (vi) Prospect and ensure the effectiveness of articulation with partners and customers in different sectors, such as private companies, government and NGOs, and coordinate the relationship with them; (vii) support in customer service and monitoring demands of the platform. The project provides a concrete way for young women to enter the job market. In addition to that, it can generate other underlying impacts, such as increasing the educational level of the participants, increasing income, increasing the productivity of certified professionals and, consequently, the productivity of the industry, with the increase in qualified hiring by the private sector, considering gender equality. All these other underlying consequences benefit gender equality. Also, the project team has a majority of women.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: PE1 Alcanzar el bienestar, el goce de derechos y la inclusión social,  con especial énfasis en las poblaciones en condición de  vulnerabilidad.
Outcome: E2 Al 2026, todas las personas, especialmente aquellas en  situación de mayor vulnerabilidad, principalmente por las  desigualdades de género incrementan su participación e  inclusión en las esferas política, social y económica y ejercen  más plenamente su derecho a una vida libre de violencia y  discriminación.
Output: E2P3 Instituciones públicas, privadas y organizaciones de sociedad civil tienen capacidades  fortalecidas para diseñar, implementar, monitorear y evaluar políticas y estrategias que mejoren  la inserción económica y laboral de las mujeres, reconozcan el trabajo doméstico no remunerado  y de cuidado, y que promuevan la corresponsabilidad e implementación de servicios de cuidado,  con enfoque de género y masculinidades.
Sub-Output: Scholarships for Educational Opportunities Program
Description:
El proyecto buscará mitigar la migración irregular desde El Salvador y reducir la estigmatización de los retornados al aumentar el acceso equitativo a oportunidades educativas formales para posibles migrantes, retornados y sus familias para generar esperanza, prosperidad y autoestima positiva en sus vidas.

El Sub-Output está alineado con las transiciones de Educación y Empleo y protección social.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development, United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: El Salvador Ministerio de Educación, Ciencia y Tecnología
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project promotes activities linked to gender equity through its academic offerings. Women are a prioritized population for enrollment, in particular in non-traditional areas, and individual psychosocial support is delivered considering gender needs. A referral mechanism is in place for specialized assistance related to Gender-Based-Violence (GBV). For women in the scholarship program, the psychological service constitutes a key support for their wellbeing and selfcare, as well as an increase in knowledge and empowerment. In addition, psychosocial services for women contributes to retention, empowerment for employment, and in some cases helps to reduce the pressure from their partners to migrate irregularly.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Human rights approach is considered directly by providing education right to vulnerable population and out-school persons. It is algo a crosscutting theme for psychosocial assistance, including referrals and partnership with human rights specialized institutions.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Los principios transversales relevantes del proyecto son: 1) empoderamiento de las mujeres y equidad de género y 2) desarrollo positivo de juventudes. Esto se toma en cuenta con base en un breve análisis coyuntural, plasmado en el documento de proyecto, que aborda el conflicto o la violencia de la siguiente forma: Una considerable proporción de migrantes irregulares son jóvenes. Esto es debido a necesidades económicas por ausencia de oportunidades, por violencia y por inseguridad; además, muchos jóvenes son objetivos para ser reclutados por pandillas... En este sentido, el proyecto facilita oportunidades educacionales a jóvenes migrantes para garantizar  su desarrollo positivo a través del acceso a trabajo formal y medios de vida.
2023 Narrative: Para diciembre de 2023, el Proyecto facilitó el acceso a empleo/nuevos emprendimientos nuevos o mejorados para 479 beneficiarios de becas (42% hombres, 58% mujeres): 383 becarios (39% hombres y 61% mujeres) accedieron a nuevas actividades laborales/emprendimientos y 96 becarios (55% hombres y 45% mujeres) mejoraron la percepción de la calidad de sus empleos/emprendimientos.  Un total de 2,505 becarios estaban inscritos en los programas educativos: cursos cortos, programas educativos técnicos superiores y programas de educación acelerada.
2024 Narrative: El proyecto brindó oportunidades educativas integrales a 1,909 personas en riesgo de desplazamiento y en condiciones de vulnerabilidad, con el objetivo de reducir la migración irregular y fomentar la esperanza, la prosperidad y la autoestima en sus vidas. Esto incluye a 427 migrantes retornados. Para el año 2024, el proyecto ha alcanzado un total de 7,155 personas desde su inicio.

2021 Narrative: The financial crisis in the state of Minas Gerais has hindered the progress of this technical cooperation with UNESCO. Consequently, the transfer of resources from the Government of Minas Gerais for the execution of this project has been hampered. Thus, without adequate resources, the project took at a very slow pace, executing a very low number of activities. Even so, it is worth mentioning that, even in this difficult context, the project has been hiring consultants to carry out studies and research aiming at supporting the Secretary of Education of Minas Gerais in making decisions regarding the management of financial resources in schools.

Description: Special attention must be paid to reaching and effectively serving adolescent girls and other vulnerable groups in Grenada, including disabled persons, sex workers, rural women and girls, elderly women and persons living with HIV, through focused outreach, advocacy, the provision of safe spaces, and innovative methods to improve the accessibility of information and services. By leveraging the early wins from several innovative programmes that are homegrown, SI Grenada breathes additional life into upscaling efforts, complements ongoing and planning programming as well as strengthens programming linkages between secondary prevention, access to quality and acceptable services and women’s economic empowerment, agency and autonomy at critical points.

Sub-Output: 3.1.3.4 - Capacity development for teachers across at least 6 primary and secondary schools in Grenada and Carriacou to pilot better implementation of the Health and Family Life Education programme addressing the root causes of Gender Based Violence and by using Comprehensive Sexuality Education principles.
Description: The HFLE is a life skills-based curriculum which includes a unit titled “Exploring Gender Issues”.   Based on the school enrolment rate in Grenada, it can be argued that HFLE reaches a very large number of adolescents to provide age appropriate sexuality and sexual health education. A qualitative study  in Grenada revealed perceptions that HFLE was not effective in reaching students due in large part to the lack and/or quality of the training that teachers received, as well as teachers’ own experiences with sexual violence. Furthermore, there were concerns that schools independently made decisions about what aspects of the sexuality and sexual health module to implement, with some principals placing less priority on HFLE because it is not an examinable subject. The HFLE program has implications for changing societal gender norms around sexuality, including family-based VAWG, as well as for facilitating help-seeking from teachers and essential service providers as envisioned in pillar 4 of the SI.
Agencies: The United Nations, UN Women
Implementation partners: GRE_CPA, GRE_MEHRD, GRE_MOH, GRE_MYES

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: People:  An inclusive and equitable society with full rights for all
Outcome: Outcome 1: Strengthened social development throughout the country, with poverty reduction through access to quality public goods and services, particularly in the areas of education, health, welfare, food and nutritional security and decent work, equitably and with emphasis on gender, racial, ethnic and generational equality
Output: 1.1 Public policies and institutional capacities strengthened in the areas of education, health, social assistance, food security and nutrition and decent work in order to address the needs of the most vulnerable groups and promote gender, race, ethnicity throughout the life course
Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1045 Implementation of education innovative technologies for prevention of STD / HIV / AIDS in the state of Rio de Janeiro
Description: The objective of this Cooperation Agreement is to apply innovative methodologies in the field of preventive education and communication on HIV / AIDS, support and encourage research and studies in different fields on HIV / AIDS to support public policies formulation and decision-making management.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: #BR Government of the State of Rio de Janeiro
Implementation partners: #BR Government of the State of Rio de Janeiro
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Despite the political and financial challenges of the project and it is still on track. Moreover, the project managed to develop research, studies, and technologies for the most vulnerable population to HIV in the state of Rio de Janeiro. The gender component is substantial in the project and has been addressed by the project coordination and civil society. Considering that this is an HIV prevention project and addressed to key populations for the AIDS epidemic, the gender issue should not be excluded in this response. In this way, dealing with transvestites, transsexuals, young men, and black women were aspects identified by the project and are directly related to the scope of both ODG and C / 5.
The strategies of intersectoral relations among education and health are fundamental for the AIDS response in the territory. In these aspects, the AIDS program in Rio de Janeiro has been articulated with state and municipal education secretariats to work on sexuality education issues and HIV / AIDS prevention. The 2021 external evaluation shown these powerful results.
The financial execution has been fulfilled considering quality, best cost-benefit for the project, and impartiality in the selection.
2022 Narrative: The Project is focused on the most vulnerable groups for STI and HIV in the State of Rio de Janeiro, considering that the HIV incidence is rising rapidly, particularly in some socially vulnerable groups, and therefore deserving a priority in policymaking. Among these groups are youth, drug users, migrants, sex workers, MSM, transvestites, and homeless people. It is estimated that people with less than 25 years now are half of the new HIV infections, which justifies targeted approaches and the construction of specific strategies for preventing disease in the school environment. This scenario demands an investment of human, financial, and technological structures for effective responses to the epidemic based on two complementary axes that require coordinated approaches: prevention and reducing impacts.The Project focused on designed new prevention methodologies with the Secretariat of Education to orient the redefinition of prevention strategies, particularly for vulnerable populations targeted for adolescents and young people.As part of the scope of the Project's objectives, it is to promote studies and research on epidemiological, behavioral, and effectiveness trends in STI / HIV / AIDS. The Project, in partnership with one of the largest Brazilian universities - UFRJ - organized a working group to discuss lines of research of interest to the Project: in two components: epidemiological and socio-behavioral.It developed: a cascade of care with an estimate of those infected with HIV; epidemiological and assistance analyzes of HIV and AIDS; epidemiological analysis of viral hepatitis reports; analyzes related to notifications of pregnant women with HIV / AIDS; analyzes related to cases of congenital syphilis; analyzes similar to syphilis during pregnancy. The Project has provided Management with the development of actions that contribute to analyzing the dynamics of the HIV / AIDS epidemic in the state and the strengthening of Management's governance capacity.The production and systematization of technical-scientific information have become an essential strategy for reaching health professionals and contributing to public political processes.One of the Project's most strategic strategies was civil society's participation in developing preventive actions and the development of new non-formal education technologies. Eight NGOs are being hired to reach vulnerable groups. The project will be implemented during 2023.The achievement of this objective has contributed to the expansion of sustainability and technical capacity. Moreover, the development of methodological processes that enable different ways to use technologies (media and social networks, platforms collaborative, among other initiatives) aimed at populations and population groups that require communication and dialogue alternatives for the success and incorporation of preventive measures and behaviors.It is noteworthy that the Project has gone through some political and financial crises since its beginning, impacting its implementation. So that some activities could not be carried out and some results could not be achieved. Since the signing of the Project, the Project has passed through seven state health secretaries. Besides, the state government of Rio de Janeiro experienced a severe financial crisis and fiscal recovery. This issue affected the capacity to provide the necessary infrastructure for the technical activities of the Project.As part of the scope of the Project's objectives, it is to promote studies and research on epidemiological, behavioral, and effectiveness trends in STI / HIV / AIDS. The Project, in partnership with one of the largest Brazilian universities - UFRJ - organized a working group to discuss lines of research of interest to the Project: in two components: epidemiological and socio-behavioral.It developed: a cascade of care with an estimate of those infected with HIV; epidemiological and assistance analyzes of HIV and AIDS; epidemiological analysis of viral hepatitis reports; analyzes related to notifications of pregnant women with HIV / AIDS; analyzes related to cases of congenital syphilis; analyzes similar to syphilis during pregnancy. The Project has provided Management with the development of actions that contribute to analyzing the dynamics of the HIV / AIDS epidemic in the state and the strengthening of Management's governance capacity.The production and systematization of technical-scientific information have become an essential strategy for reaching health professionals and contributing to public political processes.Women, including Lesbians, bisexuals, transvestites, and transsexuals, were the population group with the most data produced. Consequently, new strategies of action and professional training.Last year, a georeferenced app for the most vulnerable young population on HIV prevention and other STIs was developed. Thus, the young population can investigate their vulnerability and access the places with the most comfortable access to prevention, PREP, and PEP testing inputs. The App is called Sem Caô and is available for Android and IOS phones.Currently, the HIV epidemic affects more young people, so the focus of the project's actions was aimed at young people. Both research, interventions, and strategies considered young people, men who have sex with men and women in situations of social vulnerability and difficulty accessing education and health services.

Although there might be planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO partnered with the Brazilian Ministry of Culture (MinC) to strategically support the rebuilding phase of the main Brazilian cultural policies and governmental culture programmes, such as the Cultura Viva Programme and the Culture National System. Through the project, UNESCO has supported the building and rebuilding of cultural facilities and supported governmental programs of incentives for writing and reading with the main role of educating for democracy. The first contracting processes are ongoing as the project was signed in December 2023. These contracts will encompass the assessment of the previous architectural project of the CEUs da Cultura and the development of a new modular architectural proposition that will be replicated in different areas of the heterogenous Brazilian territory.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were improved to better promote democracy, citizenship, and diversity through culture and education, with the support of UNESCO. Technical assistance was provided to support the Ministry of Culture developing methodologies and strategic methodologies to enhance culture and education as means for the strengthening of democracy, citizenship, and diversity across key cultural public policies, namely: National Culture System, National Living Culture Policy; National Artistic and Cultural Training Program; National Reading Incentive Program (PROLER); National Public Library System; Museum of Democracy; Culture Unified Center of Arts and Sports (CEUs da Cultura); Peripheral Culture; and Aldir Blanc and Paulo Gustavo Laws. Community engagement was also improved through the organization of participatory workshops in all Brazilian states to develop the new National Culture Plan, engaging more than 1,000 participants. Technical assistance was also provided to enhance the Ministry's leadership in the G20's Culture Working Group Meetings, including the International Seminar on Culture, Climate Change and Socia Inclusion.

2024 Narrative: To foster and strengthen open dialogues between educational institutions, parents, and students about sexuality education within the context of Suriname’s Basic Life Skills program, parent awareness materials have been developed to support the delivery of Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) in schools. These materials—comprising a brochure, a print-ready poster, and a video—were created in collaboration with the Basic Life Skills Education Unit of the Ministry of Education.  The materials raise awareness about the importance of providing young people with accurate, age-appropriate information, which is essential for their development of skills in decision-making, communication, and critical thinking. Furthermore, the materials emphasize the vital role of parents and care givers as trusted figures with whom children can engage when faced with questions about their bodies, relationships, and values. Empowering parents to act as accessible, reliable resources is crucial to fostering a supportive environment for young people, ensuring their overall health, well-being, and survival. The CSE in school materials follow international standards. Through its efforts, UNFPA contributes significantly to the goals outlined in the National Education Policy 2024-2031, particularly in the integration of Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) into the curricula of basic education, high schools, and vocational schools across Suriname.  see: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1ZHPpM-SmUrzu4MOYkLTo5_4Lv0-ezes3

2021 Narrative:
The Pernambuco State STI/AIDS Program is a UNESCO grater partner. The project has been working on HIV prevention with the most vulnerable populations: young people, men who have sex with men, transvestites, female sex workers, women, drug users, people living with HIV.
In addition, the project carried out a review and ensured the inclusion of prevention to COVID in its activities. In this sense, HIV and COVID prevention work together with the most vulnerable populations in the state of Pernambuco.
The project always seeks to guarantee combined prevention strategies for vulnerable groups. Involvement with organized civil society is still a fundamental axis of project actions. New technologies are ever designed to access these populations and to foster access to treatment and prevention.
The project activities are directly linked to the expected outcomes of the 40 C/5 and SDG. Since the beginning, the Project strengthens the institutional capacity of the state of Pernambuco in response to the HIV epidemic and COVID Pandemic, especially against the most vulnerable populations. The project always involves an organized civil society in its actions. Besides, it ensures that evidence-based strategies are the driving axes of all project actions.
The Project also underwent a review that extended its term for more three years and incorporated 4 million reais into its budget. In this sense, it will be possible to carry out research, applications, and support to civil society that was not possible due to lack of resources. This year the Project was impacted by the pandemic and should resume face-to-face activities with stability in cases of covid in the state, expected in mid-2021.
2022 Narrative: The Pernambuco State STI/AIDS Program is a great UNESCO partner. The Project has been working on HIV prevention with the most vulnerable populations: young people, lesbians, men who have sex with men, transvestites, female sex workers, women, drug users, and people living with HIV. In addition, the Project reviewed and ensured the inclusion of the prevention of COVID in its activities. In this sense, HIV and COVID prevention work with the most vulnerable populations in Pernambuco.This achievement results from continued action public policies that have been maintained and expanded, in addition to working with committed professionals and institutions.These integrated actions make it possible to adequately perform prenatal care; the main factor preventing vertical transmission by allowing early tests and immediate treatment initiation. The availability of HIV testing, monitoring of these pregnant women, and the training of professionals for continuous care are among the municipalities' actions, with UNESCO's technical support over the years. Considering the main results of the year, the Project managed to achieve the main proposed results:NGO selection to develop activities with the most vulnerable population.Development of education, communication, and information strategies on health education, HIV and COVID prevention.The evaluation of the project's results began.Training and workshops were held with organized civil society and health professionals on new strategies for preventing HIV, other STIs, and Covid. Investing in lifelong education in partnerships with organized civil society and NGOs that support educating people living with HIV / AIDS. Besides, the Project invests in distance education strategies and face-to-face training of young people as strategic alternatives for training young leaders for HIV.he activities of this Project are always focused on gender equality and gender mainstream. The Project always seeks to guarantee access to condoms. However, other alternatives to HIV prevention strategies, such as combined prevention and focus on the most vulnerable populations, are always considered. Involvement with organized civil society is still a fundamental axis of project actions. As part of the scope of the Project's objectives, it promotes studies and research on epidemiological, behavioral, and effectiveness trends in STI / HIV / AIDS. The Project, in partnership with some public universities, such as the University of São Paulo, developed some studies related to these issues. It developed: a cascade of care with an estimate of those infected with HIV; epidemiological and assistance analyses of HIV and AIDS; epidemiological analysis of viral hepatitis reports; research related to notifications of pregnant women with HIV / AIDS; studies related to cases of congenital syphilis; analyzes similar to syphilis during pregnancy. The Project has provided Management with the development of actions that contribute to studying the dynamics of the HIV / AIDS epidemic in the state and strengthening Management's governance capacity.The production and systematization of technical-scientific information have become an essential strategy for reaching health professionals and contributing to public political processes.Women, including Lesbians, bisexuals, transvestites, and transsexuals, were the population group with the most data produced. Consequently, new strategies of action and professional training.Currently, the HIV epidemic affects more young people, so the focus of the Project's actions was aimed at young people. Both research, interventions, and strategies considered young people, men who have sex with men and women in situations of social vulnerability and difficulty accessing education and health services.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilience to Climate Change and Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Outcome: Caribbean people, communities, and institutions enhance their adaptive capacity for inclusive, gender responsive DRM and climate change adaptation and mitigation
Output: MSDCF 5.1: Strengthened institutional  capacity for gender-inclusive adaptation and disaster management
Sub-Output: REG Caribbean governments and other stakeholders supported to integrate climate change and disaster risk reduction into relevant strategies and policies across and within the education sector
Description:
UNDRR will continue to collaborate with Governments, partners, and networks through targeted and contextualized technical assistance to promote and implement comprehensive risk management governance. This will establish a shared understanding of risk as the basis for integrated implementation across timescales. 

These interventions aim at strengthening governance at the national level for the alignment of policies, practices, and knowledge related to both disaster risk and climate.

Using a package of guidelines and tools on comprehensive risk management developed during the previous biennium, UNDRR will provide technical assistance to Governments to develop and implement disaster risk reduction strategies and national adaptation plans in the context of the Country Support Approach.
 
UNDRR will assist in extending such synergy to key sectors like the education sector. In particular, support will be provided to the Caribbean Safe Schools Initiative (CSSI) and its Action Plan in accordance with the Antigua and Barbuda Ministerial Declaration of 2017 and the Sint Maarten Declaration on School Safety 2022, which reaffirms the 2017 declaration. These declarations provide key entry points for comprehensive risk management in the education sector. National and local linkages will be further strengthened through the application of the comprehensive school safety framework.
Agencies: United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations
Implementation partners: Anguillan Ministry of Social Development, Education & Library, Antigua & Barbuda Ministry Of Education and Sports, Bahamas Ministry of Education, Barbados Ministry of Education, Technological and Vocational Training, British Virgin Islands Ministry of Education, Culture, Agriculture, Fisheries, Sports & Youth Affairs, Curacao Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport, Grenada Ministry of Education, Youth, Sports & Culture, Guyana Ministry of Education, Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Education, Youth and Information, Montserrat Minister of Education, Youth Affairs and Sports, Saint Lucia Ministry of Education, Sustainable Development, Innovation, Science, Technology, and Vocational Training, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Ministry of Education and National Reconciliation, Sint Maarten Ministry of Education, Culture, Youth and Sport, St. Kitts and Nevis Ministry of Education, Youth, Social Development, Gender Affairs, Aging and Disabilities, Trinidad and Tobago Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 11.5 By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.
Geography: Saint Kitts and Nevis, Virgin Islands, British, Curaçao, Saint Lucia, Jamaica, Sint Maarten (Dutch part), Guyana, Turks and Caicos Islands, Bahamas, Dominica, Barbados, Anguilla (United Kingdom), Montserrat, Antigua and Barbuda, Trinidad and Tobago, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights

2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNDRR supported the chair of the Caribbean Safe Schools Initiative (CSSI), St. Maarten, through technical assistance and political support, such as developing webinars and expanding the work such as the inclusion of the topic of extreme heat and its implications in education. The ‘Caribbean Safe School Initiative’ (CSSI) was launch in April 2017 during the ‘First Caribbean Ministerial Forum on School Safety’. The CSSI is the suggested framework to advance school safety in the Caribbean. The initiative is the Caribbean contribution to the ‘Worldwide-Initiative on Safe Schools (WISS)’ and shall be a partnership for advancing safe school implementation at the national level among Caribbean countries. Ministries of Education will lead the implementation supported by international, regional and national partners.

2021 Narrative:
UNESCO has been supporting the city of São Paulo in HIV prevention since 2002. This year the São Paulo City Hall received certification of elimination of vertical transmission of HIV.
The Project focused on the prevention and well-being of people living with HIV and AIDS. The Project has been working on HIV prevention with the most vulnerable populations: young people, men who have sex with men, transvestites, female sex workers, women, drug users, people living with HIV. This achievement is the result of continued action public policies that have been maintained and expanded, in addition to working together with committed professionals and institutions.
These integrated actions make it possible to adequately perform prenatal care, which is the main factor preventing vertical transmission by allowing early tests and immediate treatment initiation. The availability of HIV testing, monitoring of these pregnant women, and the training of professionals for continuous care are among the municipalities' actions, with UNESCO's technical support over the years.
The activities of this Project are always focused on gender equality and gender mainstream. The Project always seeks to guarantee access to condoms. However, other alternatives to HIV prevention strategies, such as combined prevention, focus on the most vulnerable populations, are always considered. Involvement with organized civil society is still a fundamental axis of project actions. New technologies are ever designed to access these populations and foster access to treatment and prevention, such as App to youth.
The project activities are directly linked to the expected outcomes of the 40 C/5 and SDG 3, 4, 5, and 10. Besides, it ensures that evidence-based strategies are driving axes linked to Human rights.
2022 Narrative: UNESCO has supported the city of São Paulo in HIV prevention for a long time. This year the São Paulo City Hall received certification for the elimination of vertical transmission of HIV.The Project focused on the prevention and well-being of people living with HIV and AIDS. Achieving the parameters required to obtain a city certification with 12 million inhabitants and the municipal capital's complexity is almost impossible. No such populous city in the world has achieved this feat. This achievement results from continued action public policies that have been maintained and expanded, in addition to working together with committed professionals and institutions.It has been working on HIV prevention with the most vulnerable populations: young people, men who have sex with men, young people, transvestites, female sex workers, and drug users.The Project focused on the prevention and well-being of people living with HIV and AIDS. The Project has been working on HIV prevention with the most vulnerable populations: young people, men who have sex with men, lesbians, transvestites, female sex workers, women, and people living with HIV. This achievement results from continued action public policies that have been maintained and expanded, in addition to working together with committed professionals and institutions.These integrated actions make it possible to adequately perform prenatal care; the main factor preventing vertical transmission by allowing early tests and immediate treatment initiation. The availability of HIV testing, monitoring of these pregnant women, and the training of professionals for continuous care are among the municipalities' actions, with UNESCO's technical support over the years. Considering the main results of the last semester, the Project managed to achieve the main proposed results, and developed the following activities:Development of studies to comprehend the dynamics of the HIV epidemic focused on a vulnerable population. Development of education, communication, and information strategies on health education and HIV prevention.The evaluation of the project results was carried out.Training and workshops were held with organized civil society and health professionals on new strategies for preventing HIV and other STIs.A seminar on HIV studies in the municipality was held, involving the most significant teaching, research, and technology institutions. Investing in lifelong education in partnerships with organized civil society and NGOs that support educating people living with HIV / AIDS. Besides, the Project invests in distance education strategies and face-to-face training of young people as strategic alternatives for training young leaders for HIV.The activities of this Project are always focused on gender equality and gender mainstream. The Project always seeks to guarantee access to condoms. However, other alternatives to HIV prevention strategies, such as combined prevention and focus on the most vulnerable populations, are always considered. Involvement with organized civil society is still a fundamental axis of project actions. As part of the scope of the Project's objectives, it promotes studies and research on epidemiological, behavioral, and effectiveness trends in STI / HIV / AIDS. The Project, in partnership with some public universities, such as the University of São Paulo, developed some studies related to these issues. It developed: a cascade of care with an estimate of those infected with HIV; epidemiological and assistance analyses of HIV and AIDS; epidemiological analysis of viral hepatitis reports; research related to notifications of pregnant women with HIV / AIDS; studies related to cases of congenital syphilis; analyzes similar to syphilis during pregnancy. The Project has provided Management with the development of actions that contribute to studying the dynamics of the HIV / AIDS epidemic in the state and strengthening Management's governance capacity.The production and systematization of technical-scientific information have become an essential strategy for reaching health professionals and contributing to public political processes.Women, including Lesbians, bisexuals, transvestites, and transsexuals, were the population group with the most data produced. Consequently, new strategies of action and professional training.A georeferenced app for the most vulnerable young population on HIV prevention and other STIs was developed. Thus, the young population can investigate their vulnerability and access the places with the most comfortable access to prevention, PREP, and PEP testing inputs. The App is available for Android and IOS phones.Currently, the HIV epidemic affects more young people, so the focus of the project's actions was aimed at young people. Both research, interventions, and strategies considered young people, men who have sex with men and women in situations of social vulnerability and difficulty accessing education and health services.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: People:  An inclusive and equitable society with full rights for all
Outcome: Outcome 1: Strengthened social development throughout the country, with poverty reduction through access to quality public goods and services, particularly in the areas of education, health, welfare, food and nutritional security and decent work, equitably and with emphasis on gender, racial, ethnic and generational equality
Output: 1.1 Public policies and institutional capacities strengthened in the areas of education, health, social assistance, food security and nutrition and decent work in order to address the needs of the most vulnerable groups and promote gender, race, ethnicity throughout the life course
Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ1018 Educational resources for quality education for all: restructuring the YouTube Edu platform
Description: The project "Educational resources for quality education for all: restructuring of the YouTube Edu platform" aims to restructure YouTube Edu, a large broadcasting platform of educational videos, in order to promote among lower and upper secondary education students and teachers quality educational resources as a tool in the teaching-learning process. The target audience of this project are students, teachers, school community, and education personnel.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: YouTube
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: The current Project was signed in December 2021. The activities will be implemented in 2022.
2022 Narrative: - 1 research finished on the status of the YouTube Edu channel and on the perception of students and teachers from secondary education on the use of educational videos. The research main findings were presented to the UBO and YouTube team.- 1 methodology for YouTube Edu elaborated, including the way the playlists will be organized, as well as the number of videos expected in each playlist.- 48 playlists created, revised and validated containing educational videos aligned with the subjects foreseen at National Common Curricular Base (BNCC), directed to the secondary education, totalizing more than 1,000 videos.- 40 playlists created and under revision regarding the SDGs, the National Common Curricular Base general competencies and other educational subjects.The project contributes to UNESCO's global priority of gender equity, as its methodology for searching and selecting videos to be part of YouTube Edu channel sought a balanced number of videos produced by men and women. In addition, videos in the areas such as Math, Physics and Chemistry that are produced by women were prioritized, when possible. Still, it has been identified that few relevant female teachers produce and disseminate videos in these areas.Given their great potential to be accessible anytime and anywhere, educational resources can be an important inclusion tool, enabling individuals from disadvantaged groups to have access to education. In addition to allowing equal access to quality educational resources among boys and girls, in the methodology to restructure the YouTube Edu channel, issues such as the balanced number of videos produced by men and women has been considered. We highlight that in addition to the playlists related to school subjects, the new YouTube Edu will have two new playlists dedicated to gender equality: a playlist dedicated to SDG 5, with videos about discrimination, infant and maternal mortality, sexual and reproductive rights, female leadership and empowerment, gender-based violence etc; and a more general playlist on gender equality, which will be placed in the general education topics playlists section. Such playlists have the potential to aware consciousness regarding gender equality in Brazil. The project also contributes to the global priority of Africa, since the selected videos, all in Portuguese language, can also be accessed by African Portuguese-speaking countries

Description: Develop tools and strategies to strengthen monitoring and inspection of prison and socio-educational systems, with an emphasis on improved control and reduction of overcrowding and overpopulation in these systems. To achieve these purposes, the improvement of criminal alternative and electronic monitoring policies will be central, as well as the improvement of compliance with socio-educational measures in an open regime #UNODC
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: #BR National Council of Justice
SDG Targets: 16.3 Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.,16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.,16.9 By 2030, provide legal identity for all, including birth registration.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The gender perspective will be mainstreamed throughout the implementation of the project. It will focus on the production of data, studies development and proposal of new action plans to strengthen strategic actions for vulnerable groups deprived of liberty such as the LGBT population, women, foreigners, the elderly, people with disabilities, among others.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The project developed tools, methodologies  and strategies to strengthen monitoring and inspection of the prison and socio-educational systems, with an emphasis on reducing overcrowding and overpopulation in the prison system and controlling the number of adolescents deprived of liberty in the socio-educational system.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: > In 2023, the National Council of Justice (CNJ), with UNDP’s support, updated its prison release task force methodologies. 100,000 processes were reviewed, and 21,000 provisional detainees had their right to freedom returned. This review was possible due to the implementation of the Unified Electronic Execution System (SEEU), developed by the “Fazendo Justiça” Program. > “Fazendo Justiça” promoted a first cycle of trainings in 2023 about the SEEU, qualifying close to 20,000 professionals.  > In 2023, the National Action for Civil Identification and Documentation of Prisoners completed its implementation cycle in São Paulo. The state has a third of the country's prison population. As a result, the 27 units of the federation now have permanent processes to ensure that people deprived of their liberty are identified and have their documents up to date — fundamental to access to basic rights. The National Action for Civil Identification is an initiative by the “Fazendo Justiça” Program.
2024 Narrative: On the promotion of human rights, the National Action for Civil Identification for Persons Deprived of Liberty reached a total of 297,259 people by July 2024, approximately 45% of the country’s prison population. The partnership with the National Council of Justice (CNJ) also promoted 5th Literary Journey in Prisons, reaching around 8,000 people within 253 prison units, and the 3rd Literary Journey on the socio-educational system, reaching 78 units and, at least 1,500 people on its launch day. Over 11,800 magistrates, judicial officers, members of the Public Prosecutor’s Office, public defenders, and professionals from Secretariat’s of Criminal Policy joined trainings on the system that facilitates the integration of criminal enforcement = proceedings throughout the country (SEEU).

2024 Narrative: UNICEF partnered with the OECS, UNESCO, and CARICOM to improve education systems in the region, focusing on data collection, monitoring, and strengthening educational practices. Through resource mobilization and capacity building at the 9th Annual Statisticians Meeting, UNICEF has supported the professional development of Ministry of Education statisticians to enhance data-driven education policy and programming across member states. UNICEF’s collaboration with the OECS has made significant progress in improving educational and social outcomes for youth across the region. Through targeted initiatives, both adults and youth have contributed to enhancing education and youth development programmes. These efforts have positively impacted thousands of children and youth, creating greater learning opportunities. In total, 156 adults and 494 children/youth participated in programmes benefiting over 125,000 young people, primarily in pre-primary, primary, and secondary education. In 2024, UNICEF and the OECS Council of Ministers organized key events to advance youth development and education. The OECS Youth and Sports meeting in March engaged 300 participants, focusing on youth development. The September education meeting brought together 43 adults and 10 youth, while the Digital Curriculum Hackathon involved 17 adults and seven youth, focusing on digital education. The OECS Implementation Meeting in April focused on education policy, involving 58 adults. These events shaped educational policies, promoted youth engagement, and improved the overall learning experience in the OECS. Through the Education Council of Ministers, all nine countries have collectively and individually made a Commitment to Action for Foundational Learning. Following the 2022 Transforming Education Summit and study in seven Caribbean islands, UNICEF conducted research, consultation, and validation of the Commitment to Action for Transforming Education, in the United Kingdom Overseas Territories, Anguilla, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat and Turks and Caicos Islands. The research received input from a wide range of stakeholders, including premiers, governors, and education ministers, demonstrating strong political commitment to transforming education in these territories. Addressing the multifaceted challenges of reimagining education in the UKOTs requires a coordinated approach that balances regional needs with global trends. Adapting the education system is essential to equip students with skills for the future, ensuring education remains relevant and transformative. In Trinidad and Tobago, UNICEF has worked to improve the inclusivity of education for Venezuelan migrant children. A 2024 amendment to the immigration regulations allows children under 18, registered under the 2019 Migrant Registration Framework, to attend national schools. As chair of the Education Working Group, UNICEF has collaborated with the Ministry of Education to develop a system for registering these children. To date, 60 children have been enrolled in 22 schools. UNICEF continues to support the Ministry in addressing the needs of both migrant and local children. Additionally, UNICEF has partnered with eight community-based organizations running 18 child-friendly spaces, offering informal education and services to migrant children. Despite these efforts, access to formal education remains hindered by the legislative framework. UNICEF continues advocating for the inclusion of all migrant and refugee children. Through ongoing advocacy and capacity-building, UNICEF champions cultural acceptance and broader inclusion.  Promoting Accessibility. UNICEF and the Trinidad and Tobago Ministry of Education provided eye screenings to facilitate glasses for approximately 600 children in need. By December 2024, 328 of over 1,200 students received glasses, improving their engagement in learning. Progress was also made in the Caribbean Safe School Initiative across eight participating states. Six countries - Saint Kitts and Nevis, Antigua and Barbuda, Dominica, Saint Lucia, Barbados, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines - approved the CSSI policy, and a monitoring tool was developed. A cost-cutting proposal for the Secretariat, supported by CDEMA, was completed, and discussions for further funding are ongoing. Additionally, 346 educators were trained in disaster risk management, impacting over 5,000 students and 3,950 parents. The migration of over 9,000 curriculum-based digital content items to ministry of education platforms in Barbados, Dominica, Grenada and Turks and Caicos Islands is progressing, with completion expected by April 2025. Capacity-building programmes for teachers in Barbados will be completed by March 2025, with a detailed support programme set for early 2025. The integration of technology, including AI and emerging technologies, is reshaping global education, making it essential for the UKOTs to update their educational offerings. Strategic investments in innovation are necessary to build a resilient education system that empowers youth, enhances global competitiveness, and drives sustainable development. The GIGA initiative has improved education in the Eastern Caribbean by enhancing school connectivity and resilience. It has developed the Children’s Climate Risk Index-Disaster Risk Model (CCRI-DRM) and helped ministries address connectivity gaps. Workshops for senior officials from eight governments have focused on managing connectivity and financing, ensuring sustainable digital inclusion. Through these efforts, GIGA is working to provide equitable access to quality online resources and meaningful connectivity for students across the region.

2022 Narrative: "Education remains as one of the most important parts of UNHCR’s programming. During 2022 UNHCR continued its community-based ESL classes for Waroe and Spanish speaking out of school children in different indigenous communities of Region 1. The community-based classes aim at providing children with the most basic skills in preparation for enrollment in formal schooling, while awaiting space to become available. The project is run through direct implementation by UNHCR in coordination with the Toushous and community leaders and provides also employment opportunities within the communities through the UNV Programme. A total of 7 UN Community Volunteers were employed and some 147 indigenous out of school children enrolled. In addition, UNHCR established a partnership agreement with the Ministry of Education to provide after school ESL classes to Venezuelan and Guyanese returnee children enrolled in the formal education system. In regions 1, 3 and 7, a total of 472 children attended the after-school classes, while capacity strengthening training in ESL has been delivered to teachers from 14 schools. UNHCR considers education as a core right, thus it contributed to strengthen the capacity of schools and the Ministry of Education. Throughout 2022, UNHCR procured and donated various types of equipment and school supplies. All children enrolled in the ESL after-school classes received learning materials, and schools were equipped with tablets and school furniture. In addition, UNHCR supported the newly established Migrant Support and Risk Management Unit of the MoE with various office supplies. UNHCR also supported the Ministry with the development of the first ESL Curriculum and Diagnostic Assessment tools in Guyana. "

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO developed a cascade of care with an estimate of those infected with HIV and provided epidemiological and assistance analyses of HIV/AIDS and viral hepatitis reports. It also carried out analyses related to notifications of pregnant women with HIV / AIDS, congenital syphilis, and syphilis during pregnancy. UNESCO also provided expert support through the development of actions that contribute to analyzing the dynamics of the HIV / AIDS epidemic in the state. It also strengthened Management's governance capacity. Civil society had a prominent role in developing preventive actions and new non-formal education technologies. Eight NGOs were hired to reach vulnerable groups. The achievement of this objective has contributed to the expansion of sustainability and technical capacity. Moreover, the development of methodological processes that enable different ways to use technologies (media and social networks, collaborative platforms, among other initiatives) aimed at populations and population groups that require communication and dialogue alternatives to incorporate preventive measures and behaviors successfully.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO implemented integrated actions that enabled the state of Pernambuco to perform prenatal care adequately. The availability of HIV testing, monitoring of these pregnant women, and the training of professionals for continuous care are among the municipalities' actions, with UNESCO's technical support over the year. The agency also managed to achieve the following main results: NGO selection to develop activities with the most vulnerable population; development of education, communication, and information strategies on health education, HIV and COVID prevention. The project evaluation has been completed, and 15 training and refresher courses for health professionals and civil society organizations were held on PreP, PEP, and Combined Prevention.
2024 Narrative: No activities were held in 2024, as the project has been finalized in December 2023.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: AT2. Prosperidad e innovación
Outcome: ED4. Al 2025, el Estado mexicano cuenta con una estrategia de desarrollo productivo que promueve la asociatividad, la innovación, la productividad y la competitividad, así como el incremento de contenido nacional en los encadenamientos productivos con mejor gobernanza para la igualdad, basada en el marco de los derechos humanos y con perspectiva de género.
Output: Pr4.1. Al 2025, las instituciones gubernamentales, el sector privado, la academia,  las organizaciones de la sociedad civil y de trabajadores cuentan con capacidades fortalecidas y han habilitado espacios para generar alianzas con el fin de aumentar el contenido nacional en la economía, promover los emprendimientos inclusivos y sostenibles, con énfasis en mujeres, jóvenes, personas migrantes y refugiadas, así como fomentar la incorporación económica de poblaciones vulnerables desde el enfoque integrado, considerando los desafíos económicos ocasionados por el COVID-19.
Sub-Output: Transferencia de metodología de Second Chance Education

2024 Narrative: El Gobierno de Jalisco, a través de la Secretaría de Igualdad Sustantiva entre Mujeres y Hombres (SISEMH), en colaboración con ONU Mujeres, integró la metodología de SCE en el manual operativo del Centro de Reunión y Atención para las Mujeres (CREA) y la implementó en dos Centros de Justicia para las Mujeres (CJM Guadalajara y CJM Tlajomulco), ampliando las oportunidades de empleo, emprendimiento y educación de mujeres víctimas de violencia de género en Jalisco. También se fortalecieron las capacidades de seis facilitadoras de los centros de justicia y 40 personas funcionarias de la SISEMH que desempeñan funciones dentro de programas de gobierno dirigidos a mujeres.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: SERVICES SOCIAUX DE BASE ET APPUI AU CONTRAT SOCIAL
Outcome: La population, particulièrement les groupes vulnérables et marginalisés, a un meilleur accès à des services sociaux de base équitables, inclusifs et de qualité, avec une emphase sur le respect des droits humains, l'égalité de genre, et l'inclusion du handicap, en vue du renforcement du contrat social.
Output: Produit 4.1. La planification, la mise en œuvre, la coordination et le suivi des politiques publiques et cadres normatifs promouvant un accès universel à la protection sociale et aux services sociaux de base sont renforcées.
Sub-Output: Education parentale pour la préparation à l'école - soins pour le developpement de l'enfant
Description: Ce projet vise à mettre en œuvre un programme de soins pour le développement de l’enfant, avec pour objectif d'améliorer la santé, le bien-être et le développement global des enfants, notamment ceux en situation de vulnérabilité. Le résultat principal attendu est une augmentation des taux de développement sain chez les enfants de moins de 5 ans, incluant une meilleure nutrition, un accès à des soins de santé appropriés et un environnement d'apprentissage favorable. Les bénéficiaires ciblés sont les enfants, en particulier ceux issus de familles à faible revenu.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, UNICEF Multi-Donor Mobilization, UNICEF Other Resources, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministère de l’Education Nationale et de la Formation professionnelle, Haiti
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.5 By 2020, maintain the genetic diversity of seeds, cultivated plants and farmed and domesticated animals and their related wild species, including through soundly managed and diversified seed and plant banks at the national, regional and international levels, and ensure access to and fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge, as internationally agreed
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
Focal users: Jean Ernst SAINT FLEUR, Micher Lamour
2023 Narrative: L'UNICEF a déployé des efforts considérables pour soutenir l'offre d'éducation (formelle et non formelle) à des niveaux multiples ou des voies alternatives (y compris dans des espaces d'apprentissage temporaires). Dans le cadre de la réforme du curriculum, elle a soutenu le Ministère de l'Education pour le développement de contenus éducatifs de qualité pour la radio/télévision éducative avec des sujets scolaires, éducation parentale, EVAC, PSEA, santé et hygiène, adolescents, etc., Et que leur diffusion massive reste d'actualité à travers le plan de travail glissant (PTR) qui se poursuit jusqu'en 2024, en plus de soutenir la mise en œuvre d'un programme d'intégration scolaire pour les enfants handicapés. La fourniture de matériel scolaire aux enfants ainsi que l'appui sous forme de transferts monétaires aux familles vulnérables, avec la participation des responsables communautaires et scolaires à la scolarisation de leurs enfants, ont été des stratégies efficaces utilisees cette annee pour contribuer à l'accès équitable des enfants à l'éducation. En outre, le soutien psychosocial apporté aux enfants victimes de violences pour qu'ils résistent à l'éducation a été un moyen efficace de les faire participer aux cours et de les maintenir à l'école.
2024 Narrative: Pour l'année 2024, L'UNICEF a maintenu ses engagements de soutenir le developpement sain de l'enfant en milieu de  scolarisation formelle ete non formelle. a travers des partenaires   ONG OCCED’H, CEDDUC et APADE’H, l'Unicef a  poursuivi son assistance auprès des enfants en détresse mentale. Durant l’année 2024, 41,517 enfants dont 22,133 filles 18,764 garcons ont bénéficié de ce soutien psychosocial. À ce jour, sur une cible de 35 000 enfants, UNICEF a pu doter 18 545 enfants de kits individuels, dont 10 500 à Port-au-Prince. et 3500 parents ont reçu les transferts de cash à travers mobile money. Une évaluation permettra de générer des évidences sur le lien entre le cash transfert et l’accès et le maintien des enfants à l’école dans le contexte de crise.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: SERVICES SOCIAUX DE BASE ET APPUI AU CONTRAT SOCIAL
Outcome: La population, particulièrement les groupes vulnérables et marginalisés, a un meilleur accès à des services sociaux de base équitables, inclusifs et de qualité, avec une emphase sur le respect des droits humains, l'égalité de genre, et l'inclusion du handicap, en vue du renforcement du contrat social.
Output: Produit 4.1. La planification, la mise en œuvre, la coordination et le suivi des politiques publiques et cadres normatifs promouvant un accès universel à la protection sociale et aux services sociaux de base sont renforcées.
Sub-Output: Education: Renforcement du système et génération d'évidences y compris dans les situations d'urgence.
Description:
Ce projet est structuré autour de sept composantes clés :

Composante 1 : Appuyer le fonctionnement de la coordination des urgences au niveau national et décentralisé, afin d'assurer une réponse efficace face aux crises.

Composante 2 : Renforcer le système éducatif en appuyant la mise en place de normes et de structures de gouvernance en matière d'apprentissage précoce et pré-primaire.

Composante 3 : Soutenir la révision du curriculum du préscolaire en conformité avec le Cadre d'Orientation Curriculaire (CoC) et les standards d'apprentissage précoce, en veillant à l'amélioration des infrastructures et des matériels pédagogiques.

Composante 4 : Renforcer la qualité de la formation initiale et continue des enseignants pour les niveaux fondamentaux 1 et 2 dans les départements ciblés qui ne sont pas affectés par des urgences.

Composante 5 : Améliorer l'éducation bilingue de qualité et promouvoir l'enseignement sûr en créole, y compris le développement de matériel pédagogique en créole et l'initiative SBC pour valoriser cet enseignement.

Composante 6 : Appuyer l'évaluation des compétences en lecture et en écriture dans les zones non affectées par des urgences, afin d'assurer un suivi des acquis des élèves.

Composante 7 : Renforcer les capacités des communautés scolaires dans les zones accueillant des enfants, par le biais d'exercices de simulation liés à la gestion des risques de désastre (GRD). 

Ces composantes visent à renforcer le système éducatif, améliorer l'accès et la qualité de l'éducation, tout en préparant les communautés à faire face à d'éventuelles urgences.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: Belgian National Committee for UNICEF, UNICEF Multi-Donor Mobilization, UNICEF Other Resources, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministère de l’Education Nationale et de la Formation professionnelle, Haiti
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.,5.a Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: Pour renforcer la coordination au niveau central, le cluster éducation a été activé et l'UNICEF a soutenu l'organisation de réunions de cluster sur une base régulière en collaboration avec Save the children en tant que co-responsables. Au niveau départemental, nous pouvons mentionner l'existence de personnel de terrain de l'UNICEF dans le Sud et le déploiement régulier d'un spécialiste de l'éducation dans l'Artibonite, qui a permis d'appuyer les DDE dans la coordination entre les partenaires, la collecte d'informations sur les écoles et la planification d'activités en réponse aux urgences sectorielles.
2024 Narrative: Au cours de l'annee 2024, dans le Grand Sud, l’UNICEF et l’ONG The Children en collaboration avec le MENFP, ont organisé une formation sur l'Éducation en Situations d'Urgence (ESU) au profit de 75 acteurs  en vue d’outiller les acteurs du secteur éducatif des compétences aidant à répondre aux besoins urgents et à garantir l'accès à l'éducation dans ces circonstances exceptionnelles.  Ces sessions ont permis d’aborder des thèmes clés en conformité avec les Normes Minimales pour l'Éducation en Situations d'Urgence (INEE), publiées par le Réseau Inter-agences pour l'Éducation en Situations d'Urgence.  En parallèles 2 tables sectorielles ont été animées dans le Sud-Est et dans le Sud pour amener les acteurs à prendre conscience de leurs responsabilités quotidiennes en matière d’ Education en situations d’urgence (ESU). Pour renforcer la coordination au niveau central, l’organisation d’une conférence nationale sur la petite enfance, organise en septembre 2024, en soutien au MENFP, marquant une avancée importante dans la promotion de l'éducation préscolaire.

2023 Narrative: Durant la mise en oeuvre du projet au cours de la période de 2022- 2023, le Bureau International de l'Education (BIE) et UNESCO ont organisé une série d'ateliers sur la transformation du système éducatif haïtien, la feuille de route de la reforme curriculaire, les mécanismes de pilotage de la Réforme Curriculaire. Des ateliers ont également été organisé avec différentes directions du Ministère de l'éducation, et des organisations locale et internationale travaillant dans le secteur de l'education afin de réfléchir sur les implications curriculaires du Cadre d’Orientation Curriculaire (COC) par rapport au Multilinguisme basé sur la langue maternelle et aux Approches pédagogiques visant à développer les compétences des élèves.Ces ateliers ont permis, entre autre, de renforcer les compétences de 164 agents et 87 agentes curriculaires du MENFP et des différentes parties impliquées dans la chaîne curriculaire, en matière de diagnostic curriculaire et d’analyse documentaire, afin qu’ils accompagnent la réalisation par l’UNESCO-BIE dudit Rapport d’état et qu’ils garantissent l’alignement avec le COC et la pertinence des documents curriculaires qui seront développés ou révisés au cours du projet. Ils ont également permis de dégager un consensus autour du contenu de la feuille de route de la réforme curriculaire avec les cadres du MENFP et accroître l’appropriation des parties prenantes et permettre à 109 hommes et 86 femmes de travailler sur la feuille de toute de la reforme curriculaire et 166 hommes et 86 femmes de débattre sur les mécanismes de pilotage de la Réforme Curriculaire à Port-au-Prince.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO provided technical assistance to the city of São Paulo by developing studies to understand the dynamics of the HIV epidemic focused on a vulnerable population and the development of education, communication, and information strategies on health education and HIV prevention. Project evaluation was carried out. Additionally, 16 training sessions and workshops were held with organized civil society and health professionals on new strategies for preventing HIV and other STIs, and nearly 40 seminars and meetings on HIV studies in the municipality were held, involving the most significant teaching, research, and technology institutions. As a result, over 1,200 persons are expected to have benefited from the activities, and São Paulo City Hall received certification for the elimination of vertical transmission of HIV.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: SERVICES SOCIAUX DE BASE ET APPUI AU CONTRAT SOCIAL
Outcome: La population, particulièrement les groupes vulnérables et marginalisés, a un meilleur accès à des services sociaux de base équitables, inclusifs et de qualité, avec une emphase sur le respect des droits humains, l'égalité de genre, et l'inclusion du handicap, en vue du renforcement du contrat social.
Output: Produit 4.2. Le plaidoyer et la capacité des détenteurs d'obligation et titulaires de droits pour l’accès aux services de base et à la protection sociale, ciblant particulièrement les femmes et les filles marginalisées, sont accrus en vue de réduire les inégalités.
Sub-Output: Education:Les détenteurs d'obligation et titulaires de droits pour l’accès aux services de base en education ont leur capacités renforcées pour réduire les inégalités.
Description:
Ce projet comprend deux principales composantes :

- La composante 1 vise à assurer un enseignement à plusieurs niveaux, aussi bien formel que non formel, ainsi que des parcours d'apprentissage alternatifs, y compris dans des espaces d'apprentissage temporaires.
- La composante 2 a pour objectif de renforcer les communautés scolaires, telles que les associations de parents d'élèves et les comités de gestion des écoles, dans les zones non affectées par les urgences.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, UNICEF Multi-Donor Mobilization, UNICEF Other Resources, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministère de l’Education Nationale et de la Formation professionnelle, Haiti
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.,14.2 By 2020, sustainably manage and protect marine and coastal ecosystems to avoid significant adverse impacts, including by strengthening their resilience, and take action for their restoration in order to achieve healthy and productive oceans.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
