Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: SERVICES SOCIAUX DE BASE ET APPUI AU CONTRAT SOCIAL
Outcome: La population, particulièrement les groupes vulnérables et marginalisés, a un meilleur accès à des services sociaux de base équitables, inclusifs et de qualité, avec une emphase sur le respect des droits humains, l'égalité de genre, et l'inclusion du handicap, en vue du renforcement du contrat social.
Output: Produit 4.3. Les capacités institutionnelles, techniques et infrastructurelles (l'État, Organisations de la Société Civile et Organisations Communautaires de Base) sont renforcées pour soutenir l'offre des services sociaux de base et l’amélioration de la résilience des ménages.
Sub-Output: Education: l'amelioration de l 'acces des services d'education.  Les institutions scolaires sont renforcees pour fournir  un paquet de soins  educationnels integres , de services essentiels efficaces et efficientes aux populations cibles y compris dans les situation d'urgence.
Description: Le projet a pour objectif de renforcer l'accès à une éducation de qualité pour les enfants dans les zones touchées par des urgences. Le principal résultat attendu est l'amélioration des infrastructures scolaires et la garantie de la scolarisation des enfants issus de familles vulnérables. Les bénéficiaires incluent les élèves et les familles vivant dans ces zones affectées. Ce projet se décline en trois composantes : la première consiste à appuyer les Directions Départementales de l'Éducation (DDE) dans la construction et la réhabilitation de salles de classe, ainsi que dans l'équipement de celles-ci, tout en fournissant des kits récréatifs. La deuxième composante vise à soutenir des familles vulnérables par des transferts monétaires afin d'assurer une scolarisation équitable pour leurs enfants. Enfin, la troisième composante se concentre sur l'établissement d'un système de suivi de l'apprentissage et de maintien des élèves. Le projet est prévu pour une durée déterminée, avec un budget total qui sera défini en fonction des interventions nécessaires pour atteindre ces objectifs.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: Belgian National Committee for UNICEF, UNICEF Multi-Donor Mobilization, UNICEF Other Resources, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministère de l’Education Nationale et de la Formation professionnelle, Haiti
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 13 Climate Action
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Support Functions
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: Cette annee, Unicef a soutenu 11 355 enfants issus de familles vulnérables dans les départements de l'Ouest, du Nord et du Sud. Un montant de 105 USD par enfant est versé aux parents,  selon les situations en vue d'atténuer les effets de la crise et de répondre à la situation de vulnérabilité aiguë des familles.  l'UNICEF a reçu du gouvernement une liste de 39 écoles à réhabiliter, relocaliser, ou équiper en mobilier à Port-au-Prince. À date, UNICEF a pu réhabiliter et/ou équiper trois écoles à Port-au-Prince, une école à Léogâne, et une autre dans l'Artibonite. Les évaluations pour la réhabilitation et l'équipement de 12 autres écoles sont en cours.  La distribution de kits scolaires individuels pour les enfants, constitue une activité clé de la campagne a atteint une cible de 35 000 enfants, À ce jour, environ 15 000 enfants non scolarisés ont été réintégrés dans le système éducatif. La campagne d'identification se poursuivra jusqu'à la fin du mois de décembre 2024.

Le principal résultat attendu est l'amélioration des standards de qualité dans les programmes d'éducation non formelle, permettant ainsi un meilleur accès à une éducation adaptée. Les bénéficiaires incluent les jeunes, les adultes et les communautés locales qui dépendent de ces services. 2024 Narrative: Au cours de l'annee 2024, Unicef a mis en place, un programme d’éducation de base non formelle visant à offrir une formation pratique et professionnelle dans divers métiers manuels,  dans le but de répondre aux besoins éducatifs et professionnels des adolescents et adolescentes dans des centres d’hébergement temporaires de la zone métropolitaine de Port-au- prince. L’implémentation de ce programme d’éducation non formelle a permis à 300 enfants déplacés internes de bénéficier des activités d'éducation non formelle (Cosmétologie, Macramé, Crochet, Dépannage Motocyclette, Dessein, Maroquinerie) durant la période allant du mois de mai au mois de septembre. De plus, dans l’optique de porter assistance aux enfants victimes et qui fuient la violence des groupes armés, 8406 enfants déplacés internes (5 505 filles et 2 901 garcons) ont participé à des activités éducatives dans les espaces temporaires d’apprentissage.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: SERVICES SOCIAUX DE BASE ET APPUI AU CONTRAT SOCIAL
Outcome: La population, particulièrement les groupes vulnérables et marginalisés, a un meilleur accès à des services sociaux de base équitables, inclusifs et de qualité, avec une emphase sur le respect des droits humains, l'égalité de genre, et l'inclusion du handicap, en vue du renforcement du contrat social.
Output: Produit 4.3. Les capacités institutionnelles, techniques et infrastructurelles (l'État, Organisations de la Société Civile et Organisations Communautaires de Base) sont renforcées pour soutenir l'offre des services sociaux de base et l’amélioration de la résilience des ménages.
Sub-Output: Education:Renforcement du système - éducation inclusive pour d'autres enfants vulnérables - quintile le plus pauvre, minorités ethniques/linguistiques, enfants migrants, non-citoyens/enfants sans papiers, etc.
Description: Le projet vise à promouvoir une éducation inclusive pour des enfants vulnérables, y compris ceux issus du quintile le plus pauvre, des minorités ethniques et linguistiques, ainsi que des enfants migrants, non-citoyens et sans papiers. L'objectif principal est d'assurer un accès équitable à une éducation de qualité pour ces groupes marginalisés. Les bénéficiaires incluent directement ces enfants vulnérables et leurs familles.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, UNICEF Multi-Donor Mobilization, UNICEF Other Resources, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministère de l’Education Nationale et de la Formation professionnelle, Haiti, Ministère des Affaires Sociales et du Travail, Haiti, United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.5 By 2020, maintain the genetic diversity of seeds, cultivated plants and farmed and domesticated animals and their related wild species, including through soundly managed and diversified seed and plant banks at the national, regional and international levels, and ensure access to and fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge, as internationally agreed,3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.,4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 2 Zero Hunger, 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
Geography: Sud, GrandeAnse, Haiti, Centre, Artibonite, Ouest, Sud-Est, Nippes
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
Focal users: Micher Lamour, Jean Ernst SAINT FLEUR
2024 Narrative: Au cour de l'annee 2024, Un total de 67 écoles prioritaires identifiées par la Direction Départementale de l'Éducation de la Grand’Anse (DDEGA) ont participé à l’enquête JENA (Joint Education Needs Assessment). Et les résultats de l’enquête permettront à la DDEGA et à ses partenaires de Prioriser les actions selon les besoins identifiés. par ailleurs, la distribution de materiels scolaires dans la cellule des mineurs en conflit avec la loi a ete effectuee et aussi la distribution de 100 school in bag a 200 écoles dans la zone de Canaan. A noter que chaque school in bag peut permettre d’atteindre 40 élèves.

Ce projet a pour objectif de renforcer le Ministère de l'Éducation Nationale et de la Formation Professionnelle (MENFP) ainsi que ses structures déconcentrées dans leurs capacités de planification, de coordination et de suivi de la mise en œuvre de leurs plans d'activité annuels. Le principal résultat attendu est une amélioration significative de l'efficacité et de l'efficience dans la gestion des activités éducatives. 
Les bénéficiaires incluent les fonctionnaires du MENFP, les agents des structures déconcentrées et, indirectement, les élèves et les communautés scolaires.

2024 Narrative: durant l'annee 2024, en ce qui concerne le renforcement du dispositif SIGEE au niveau des DDE, environ 10 ordinateurs sont remis au MENFP, 21 postes Starlink, de panneaux solaires portables et de 300 tablettes au niveau central et dans les 10 DDEs  départements du pays. Ce soutien technique va contribuer au renforcement de la capacité opérationnelle du SIGEEE en permettant au MENFP de tracer le parcours des élèves- mieux évaluer la carte scolaire/disponibilité de l’offre éducative et aussi de faciliter des activités de cash transfert dans les écoles.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: SERVICES SOCIAUX DE BASE ET APPUI AU CONTRAT SOCIAL
Outcome: La population, particulièrement les groupes vulnérables et marginalisés, a un meilleur accès à des services sociaux de base équitables, inclusifs et de qualité, avec une emphase sur le respect des droits humains, l'égalité de genre, et l'inclusion du handicap, en vue du renforcement du contrat social.
Output: Produit 4.3. Les capacités institutionnelles, techniques et infrastructurelles (l'État, Organisations de la Société Civile et Organisations Communautaires de Base) sont renforcées pour soutenir l'offre des services sociaux de base et l’amélioration de la résilience des ménages.
Sub-Output: Soutenir l'acces a une education de qualite dans la peninsule Sud d'Haiti frappee par le tremblement de terre d'aout 2021.
Description: Le soutien du MPTF permettra  à l'UNESCO de mettre en œuvre une stratégie de réhabilitation des infrastructures scolaires dans les départements de la péninsule sud,touchés par le séisme d'août 2021 particulierement les departements du Sud, des Nippes et de la Grande Anse, conformément au Plan d'Action pour le Redressement de la Péninsule Sud (PRIPS). L’UNESCO dispose d'un budget de 5,7 millions de dollars pour la réhabilitation des écoles. Suivant la base de données des écoles évaluées (dont 300 dans la péninsule Sud) par la méthodologie d’évaluation multirisque VISUS, les écoles prioritaires sont identifiees ce qui permet de réduire les couts de réhabilitation (une partie conséquente des études préalables étant déjà disponible) et de raccourcir les délais de réalisation. Ainsi l’UNESCO pourra réhabiliter près de 25 écoles suivant la liste retenue par la Direction du Génie Scolaire (DGS) du MENFP. Par ailleurs, les écoles réhabilitées, seront dotées majoritairement voire dans leur totalité  de point d’eau, d’assainissement et d’hygiène(WASH), fonctionnant à l’énergie solaire, pour assurer la disponibilité et la durabilité des travaux au profit de la communauté éducative. Cette disposition permettra aux établissements de fonctionner de manière optimale, dans un environnement favorable aux apprentissages. Ces travaux prendront en considération la question du genre, notamment en ce qui concerne les toilettes. Toutes les ecoles réhabilitees  seront conçues de maniere a prendre en compte les possibilités d’accueillir des sinistres en cas de catastrophes naturelles ou tout autre évènement pouvant entrainer la nécessité d’abriter provisoirement des populations déplacées.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: Government of Brazil, Government of Canada
Implementation partners: Ministère de l’Education Nationale et de la Formation professionnelle, Haiti, Organización de las Naciones Unidas para la Educación, la Ciencia y la Cultura
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.
Geography: Nippes, Port-Salut, Jérémie, Haiti, Baradères, Beaumont, Les Cayes, Marfranc, Sud, GrandeAnse, Miragoâne, Anse-d'Ainault

Human rights marker narrative: "The project supports the government in making a private-public partnership to build and operate a social-educational centre for youth offenders. UNOPS contributed to defining the obligations of the private operator in caring for the adolescents, including guaranteeing: - Rights and respect for the LGBTQIA+ population in different situations, and all professionals will receive training in social-educational and human rights issues to guarantee compliance with these protocols. - Establishing a channel for reporting rights violations - Adapting sports offered to people with disabilities - Ensuring the design includes spaces for children (considering family members visiting the centre) and accessibility for people with disabilities."

2023 Narrative: In 2023, the project finalised the PPP modelling studies for the State of Minas Gerais, which were revised to take into account contributions from the public consultation, public hearing and rounds of dialogue with stakeholders. After the final review of the documents by CAIXA and the public institutions of the State of Minas Gerais, the tender was launched on 15 December 2023. The project evaluated the PPP model, developed a Contract Management Model, and began developing a Public Policy Impact Assessment Manual which will be delivered in 2024.The full bid notice can be accessed at: http://dataroom.mg.gov.br/ and https://www.seguranca.mg.gov.br/socioeducativo/ppp-socioeducativo-licitacao
2024 Narrative: In 2024 the project liaised with potential private operators and other stakeholders in order to improve tender documents for the Minas Gerais component. The documents are currently under public consultation.The Santa Catarina component was suspended in 2024, but the Government of Santa Catarina has informed UNOPS they are ready to continue the component in 2025.

2022 Narrative: The project is mainly focused on two axes: 1) the São Paulo city strategy for homeless people ("população em situação de rua") and 2) the development of contents and a training programme for human rights education for city public servants. The partner and UNESCO developed a few studies as inputs for local human rights policy making and other HRBA informational material produced by the UNESCO team. As regards activities developed, the project has published a call for proposals for a research study on quality of services provided by the social assistance centres dealing with older population and people living in the streets. The study shall be conducted in 2023 and will be published by UNESCO and the city of Sao Paulo. Other reference guides on access to social services (QAs, maps, etc) have also been produced in the scope of the project.

2022 Narrative: Institute Palavra Aberta promotes media and digital literacy education, especially for teachers promoting lectures and discussing issues related to the quality of education in digital literacy and media and how to improve digital and media literacy through research and public policies. In partnership with UNESCO the Palavra Aberta Institute has been promoting Media and Information Literacy in Brazil among policy makers and educators so teacher can help youth understand their rights and responsibilities when using mass media, popular culture and digital media.  A manual with guidance for teachers and an online course on Media education and the National Curricular requirements was developed for teacher and a Hub with resources and good practices was developed. Palavra Aberta Institute with UNESCO, ITU and Childhood promoted and event to discuss the report discussing on line safety of children and youth on the Internet, Desinfodemic and the impact of disinformation and the need to promote media education and literacy in Brazil. MIL has already been included in the National Curriculum and is now a subject at the National Commonly Shared Curricular Base (BNCC, in the Portuguese acronym) – present in the general competencies. Several joint events and lives were jointly promoted involving National Press Associations, the American Embassy, judges of the Brazilian High an Electoral Courts and course for journalists on Freedom of Expression and Disinformation ecosystems.The partnership with Palavra Aberta has allowed UNESCO to promote MIL, Freedom of Expression and Safety of Journalists agenda reaching key players in the private and government sector.

2024 Narrative: Through UNICEF support, local capacity for data-driven decision making in Education was strengthened. As part of these efforts, EMIS training was provided to 92 head teachers, teachers, and data entry clerks from 24 schools (6 nursery, 16 primary and 2 secondary), allowing for the electronic tracking of 4,685 students' records including attendance. This support benefitted 11 schools in region 1, one of Guyana's interior indigenous regions. Schools with internet connectivity now have the ability to update students' records in real-time while others can utilize the offline EMIS capability which gets updated on a monthly basis. From this support, enrollment and attendance information is readily available at the school level for both teachers and students and can be used for informed planning and resource allocation in order to improve education outcomes. While underway, the out of school study in Guyana was postponed for an indefinite amount of time due to a shift in Government priorities. UNICEF will continue to advocate for up-to-date information on out of school children in Guyana including information on those at risk of dropping out.

2022 Narrative: IOM supported the Ministry of Education (MOE) through the establishment of an educational project. As part of the project, IOM supports the hosting of free ESL (English as a Second Language) classes and provide homework assistance to students on a weekly basis. Sessions are currently ongoing every Tuesday and Wednesday from 15:30 to 17:00HRS at the Learning Resource Center in Region 9.The class is intended to benefit migrant and local children between the ages of 6 and 12. Since its initial phase September through December, there was an increase in attendance ranging from 20 to 31 children (15 girls and 16 boys) at the close of the school year.  At present, the majority of the students are from the migrant population, but classes are also extended to locals who can benefit from extra classes and the opportunity to engage with children their age in the process of integration. Students who are part of the project are better integrated into the local school community and there is evidence of improved academic performance among other benefits. The implementation of the project has since created employment for two (2) local teachers and one (1) supervisor.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, IOM conducted ESL classes in eight primary schools in Regions 4 (6 classes) and 9 (2 classes). A Donation Agreement was signed between the International Organization for Migration and the Ministry of Education Risk Management and Migration Support Section, which signified ongoing support for the ESL Classes Project. Resources necessary for conducting the ESL classes were acquired in September 2023 and officially transferred to the Ministry on October 11, 2023. These resources included English as a Second Language (ESL) Books (Math, Language, Social Studies, and Science), stationery supplies, flash cards, water bottles, tablets and a water dispenser.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Outcome: 2.1 Até 2027, o Brasil terá ampliado e fortalecido a proteção social e demais políticas públicas para serem mais intersetoriais, inclusivas, participativas e efetivas, baseadas em evidências, atentas a grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e orientadas, em todos os níveis de governo, ao respeito aos direitos humanos e à redução da pobreza, da fome e das desigualdades de grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade e à promoção da igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia e do desenvolvimento sustentável ambiental e socialmente.
Output: 2.1.3 Capacidades de gestão de políticas públicas de educação de qualidade, acesso, permanência e aprendizagem fortalecidas, proporcionando, com equidade, proteção e inclusão de grupos e pessoas em situação de vulnerabilidade, e oportunidades de aprendizagem ao longo da vida, a partir da perspectiva de geração, gênero, raça e etnia e respeito aos direitos humanos.
Sub-Output: IOM IS.0093 Passport for Education - Phase three
Description: This project aims to suport  the voluntary relocation process and integration of Venezuelan refugees and migrants by providing families with children and adolescents with adequate information and about education rights in Brazil. Activities are implemented within the framework of a UN to UN Agreement between UNICEF and IOM.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Implementation partners: United Nations Children's Fund
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
Humanitarian marker narrative: Through this project, IOM supports the Brazilian Government's humanitarian response Operation Welcome, mainstreaming protection through a comprehensive verification process of relocation cases, with a focus on identifying and mitigating protection risks, and addressing specific vulnerabilities, in particular of children and adolescents.​ Also, IOM follows the humanitarian principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality and independence.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: During project development, a gender analysis was conducted and protection principles and gender considerations were mainstreamed in the project narrative and relevant results.As for activities, IOM ensured gender parity among target beneficiaries, and equal gender representation in project materials that were distributed. Also, IOM dedicated efforts to supporting pregnant adolescents in need of timely information on access to education in Brazil.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The project has as primary contribution the realization of human rights for refugee and migrant children and adolescents through the promotion of education integration. The project is explicitly grounded in the enjoyment or fulfilment of human rights, focusing of mitigating the effects of discrimination, inequality and marginalization. It makes clear reference to ‘rights holders’ and/or ‘duty bearers’, also promoting the participation and meaningful engagement of various stakeholder, including target communities. Moreover, the issues addressed are identified through a human rights based analysis, incorporating a gender perspective throughout all phases.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: Key achievements of this project include:• 4,918 children and adolescents, of 1,326 families, were assisted through information sessions on education rights, procedures for school transfer and enrolment, among others, and distribution of 2,900 educational kits.• 71% of beneficiaries reported to have enrolled in school in cities of destination.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1077 Innovative solutions in São Paulo State education developed
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: #BR Government of the State of São Paulo
Implementation partners: #BR Government of the State of São Paulo
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there might be planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Other, Children , LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity), Youth
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO carried out a diagnosis of the training needs of teachers, managers, and technical teams of the public teaching system in the São Paulo State, considering current educational policies and developing monitoring strategies, evaluation, and diagnosis of the students’ learning process in São Paulo education system. It also developed diagnostic and evaluation tools to support education planning and management, including data collection and migration from the Computerized Systems of the São Paulo State Secretariat of Education to the INEP’s Educacenso System - School Census of Basic Education. Additionally, it planned and implemented the new student exchange program in the schools of the state network of São Paulo, including teachers and pedagogues, as wel as implemented and enhanced the management of didactic material, large-scale assessments, and teacher training processes, as well as supporting stakeholder engagement during execution.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened in the city of São Paulo to promote quality education by developing innovative solutions in São Paulo State education with the support of UNESCO. Throughout the year, technical support and knowledge sharing were provided to support the development of evaluation instruments for nine technical courses offered by the State Education Network of São Paulo and to revise the lessons for ten technical courses. SEDUC/SP Pedagogical Coordination team was equipped with new methodologies and tools to enhance professional education. Data management policies were also improved through the development of capacity-building training sessions at the School of Training and Improvement of Education Professionals of São Paulo (EFAPE), support for the implementation of the VAAR (Value Student Year by Result) indicator, and the strengthening of the results-based management culture in state and municipal schools. Social inclusion was also enhanced through the development of a Music Pilot Project targeting students in the state education network.

Output: 2.1.4 Capacidades de gestão de políticas públicas de saúde, soberania e segurança alimentar e nutricional fortalecidas, com foco na produção ambientalmente adequada, no acesso igualitário, na qualidade e na ação intersetorial, de forma inclusiva e protetiva para todas as pessoas, em especial as que estão em situação de vulnerabilidade, a partir das perspectivas de geração, gênero, raça e etnia e do respeito aos direitos humanos.
Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1082 Education innovative technologies for prevention of STD/HIV/AIDS implemented in the state of Rio Grande do Sul
Description: The objective of this Project is to apply innovative methodologies in the field of preventive education, health prevention, communication, and to support research and studies in different fields of knowledge to support public policy formulation and management decision making in the state of Rio Grande do Sul.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: #BR Government of the State of Rio Grande do Sul
Implementation partners: #BR Government of the State of Rio Grande do Sul
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there might be planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Children , LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity), Other, Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.), Youth
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO carried out studies to understand the dynamics of the HIV epidemic focused on a vulnerable population, developed educational, communication, and information strategies on health education and HIV prevention, and implemented a particular strategy focused on young people in schools related to health and sexuality education – Geracao Consciente project.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened by the Government of the State of Rio Grande do Sul, with the support of UNESCO, to develop education innovative technologies for prevention of STD/HIV/AIDS in Rio Grande do Sul. Although project implementation has started in the second semester due to delays in funds transfer, remarkable achievements were made, as the implementation of an HIV prevention center, health promotion, and access to PReP and PEP has been proposed and articulated. Also, LNOB groups (such as LGBTQI+ communities, sex workers and people who use drugs) are directly benefiting from the project, as access to health and prevention supplies in vulnerable territories and at alternative times has been granted. A study to provide data for and evaluate STI and HIV/AIDS prevention and clinical follow-up actions has been carried out, and strategies to prevent HIV/AIDS and other STIs, especially among transvestites and transsexuals, were developed. Additionally, technical assistance and knowledge sharing have been delivered to evaluate state-level strategic projects with CSOs, and community leaders and cultural collectives to reduce HIV infection, as well as to develop guidelines for strengthening prevention actions for the most vulnerable and at-risk population for STI/HIV/Aids.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1090 (UNOPS 23850) Development of Actions to Qualify Basic Education in the Municipality of Porto Alegre supported
Description: The objective of this project is the consolidation of pedagogical, curricular and management practices by the education network; the improvement of pedagogical and curricular practices; updating the knowledge of education professionals; the adoption of innovative educational content and methodologies; the improvement of the management capacity of priority educational programs, as well as the expansion and improvement of the offer of places for early childhood education and elementary education.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Municipal Government of Porto Alegre
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
Geography: Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO, in a joint partnership with UNOPS, carried out two missions to plan actions, visit schools, conduct interviews, and elaborate a list of adjustments and pedagogical requests from the Porto Alegre Municipal Secretariat of Education. The agency also started the development of fire protection, prevention, and firefighting projects, targeting 99 schools. Additionally, it launched a bidding process to prepare architectural and engineering projects to conclude five schools’ buildings.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened to promote quality education by developing, with the support of UNESCO, actions to improve basic education in the Municipality of Porto Alegre. While a project for the renovation and construction of five schooles has been developed through partnership with UNOPS (UNOPS 23850), the Political-Pedagogical Project for primary education was developed, focusing on improving the quality of teaching and the inclusion of innovative methodologies that meet the students' needs.

Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: #BR Government of the State of Paraná
Implementation partners: #BR Government of the State of Paraná
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.

Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there might be planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO developed four Terms of Reference focused on Elementary and High School education, addressing the pedagogical material needs for indigenous peoples, quilombola, rural education, and ethnic-racial relations students. It also carried out situational diagnoses, participatory processes, awareness raising, and engagement of stakeholders involved in the construction and/or expansion of pre-selected schools within the state's public school network. Recommendations for 7 new future schools to be built in the state were made, including the holding of public consultations with the communities around the areas where the new units would be constructed, to assess the impact of the project.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened in the state of Paraná to promote quality education by developing innovative solutions in São Paulo State education with the support of UNESCO. Throughout the year, managers and basic education professionals were equipped with a series of capacity-building training, and innovative management and information tools. Technical assistance was provided to develop tools and improve mapping, diagnosis, data management, and information processes, focusing on enhancing the National School Feeding Program (PNAE) in state schools in the Curitiba Regional Education Center (NRE). Teachers were also equipped with tools, training, and learning material to better address school violence, particularly bullying, and develop actions to prevent violence and improve the school climate, with a focus on qualified professionals.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1115 Strategies and Tools for Monitoring and Evaluating the Implementation of Public Educational Policies developed according to the Goals of the National Education Plan - PNE and the Articulated Action Plan - PAR
Description: This Project aims to improve the institutional capacity of the Management, Articulation and Educational Projects Department (DIGAP), at the National Education Development Funs (FNDE) through the review of processes, provision of subsidies for the review of standards, and definition of strategies for improving effectiveness in the application of education resources, with regard to infrastructure of schools and educational spaces, education staff training, and acquisition of teaching material. The proposed results should contribute to the achievement of greater effectiveness of the public resource and the provision of more efficient school structures.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR National Fund for Educational Development
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.

Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO improved the functionalities of the Integrated System of Monitoring Execution and Control (Sistema Integrado de Monitoramento, Execução e Controle - SIMEC), facilitating the search for data and information for decision-making, demand studies, accountability to controlling bodies, definition of public policies, planning of new bids, service analysis, as well as greater speed, having information in real-time, without the need to wait for service from the agency's technology sector. It also identified and overcame bottlenecks in administrative procedurese and the compatibility of technical-managerial reports that subsidize the FNDE's High Management. The agency also planned, developed and implemented the "Management Panel of Works" tool, whose project was conceived in Management Board Articulation and Educational Projects (DIGAP) and duly implemented by the Ministry of Education later in 2022. Improvements in the technical assistance were also provided, with the elaboration of new guidelines and improvements in the PAR legislation to optimize and give more transparency to the objectives’ fulfillment and accountability.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the National Fund for Educational Development, with the support of UNESCO, has enhanced the capacities of its Management, Articulation and Educational Projects Department (DIGAP) to better produce disaggregated data, indicators, research and analyses to tackle the multiple dimensions of poverty, including education. Throughout the year, standards and recommendations regarding educational infrastructure actions and pedagogical resources were reviewed, and a survey to assess the needs for DIGAP's work on educational management, human resource training, and pedagogical practices was carried out. As a result, the National Education Procurement Plan methodology was improved, and national technical assistance was enhanced through the development of new guidelines and internal regulations to increase transparency. Resources from the Joint Action Plan (PAR) were also optimized to provide efficient and high-quality technical and financial support, and the SIMEC system was improved to facilitate real-time access to data and information for decision-making, demand studies, and accountability.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1147 Education governance in the municipality of São Paulo strengthened to better provide innovative actions towards quality Education and democratic management
Description: The present project aims to strengthen Education governance in the municipality of São Paulo through actions of innovations of quality Education and democratic management. UNESCO in Brazil, through its expertise will promote initiatives and priorities in achieving the objectives of Education for All, regarding the planning and implementation of actions to improve the efficiency, equity and quality of educational opportunities and democratic management of the municipality.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Municipal Government of São Paulo
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there might be planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO developed training paths based on the City Curriculum and its didactic guidelines, focusing on new educational research and interdisciplinary teaching and learning processes in literacy, targeting primary education teachers and pedagogical coordinators. It also provided advisory support through management education together with the cooperation project between SME-SP and UNESCO, collaborating with its management team and with the specialized departments of the Secretariat in the preparation of technical documents and support for the review and evaluation of guidelines according to the SME-SP matrix of results and strategic planning. The agency also carried out quantitative and qualitative research about access, frequency, and permanence of students from the São Paulo Municipal Education System during the pandemic of COVID-19. Training, working groups, guidelines, and documents were also held to improve educational management practices in São Paulo, to strengthen democratic management, and to ensure students' learning and development. It also launched the research “São Paulo: Lighthouse against Structural Racism,” which aims to address the structural racism in Brazilian society and influence the formation of the next generations, emphasizing activities in early childhood education (in progress). Finally, it developed the research implementation of the VI Municipal Congress of Education of the city of São Paulo from 4 to 6 October with more than 5.000 participants.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened by the Municipality of São Paulo, with the support of UNESCO, to improve education governance and better provide innovative actions towards quality education and democratic management. As the project has been finalised in 2024, solid initiavies to promove innovation and democratic management were developed to create a more inclusive, equitable and high-quality education system. As a result, the support of UNESCO not only better prepared, but also promoted sustainable and fair development, thus positioning São Paulo as a global model in education.A large set of educational areas, such as early childhood education, youth and adult education, bilingual education and guidance on ethnic-racial relations, were benefited by the project. One of the most notable highlights of this project is the pioneering spirit of the city of São Paulo in integrating the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into the municipal education curriculum. This alignment not only strengthens the relevance of the content taught, but also engages students in essential global issues, preparing them to be conscious and active citizens in promoting a sustainable future.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1149 Strategies and tools developed to strengthen and consolidate school maintenance public policies as national and international references in excellent educational public policies
Description: This Project aims to improve the institutional capacity of the National Education Development Fund - FNDE, in particular the General Coordination of Support for School Maintenance (CGAME), the Educational Actions Board (DIRAE), to become a national and international reference in public transport and school maintenance policies excellence. The proposed results should contribute to the improvement of these educational policies and, as a consequence, reduce educational inequality and achieve better access and learning rates for Brazilian students.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR National Fund for Educational Development

2023 Narrative: This Project aims to improve the institutional capacity of the National Education Development Fund - FNDE, in particular the General Coordination of Support for School Maintenance (CGAME), the Educational Actions Board (DIRAE), to become a national and international reference in public transport and school maintenance policies excellence. The proposed results should contribute to the improvement of these educational policies and, as a consequence, reduce educational inequality and achieve better access and learning rates for Brazilian students.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened by the Brazilian Ministry of Education, with the support of UNESCO, to improve the management and implementation of public transport and school maintenance policies held in the framework of the National Education Development Fund (FNDE) and its Directorate of Educational Actions (DIRAE). While the National School Transport Support Programme (PNATE) and the "Caminho da Escola" programme were successfully revised and strengthened, technological strategies for the managerial monitoring of the Direct Money for Schools Program (PDDE) were implemented. Tailored technical assistance and knowledge sharing was also delivered to improve the monitoring and evaluation of Brazil's school maintenance programmess, as well as technological advancements in the acquisition of school buses. Furthermore, progress was made in operational procedures and workflows, accompanied by impact assessments that identified challenges and fostered improvements in the execution by beneficiaries.

Description: The project aims to provide subsidies to the Ministry of Education for the implementation of integrated policies and programs, monitoring and evaluation of actions aimed at the development and strengthening of Brazilian education through actions aimed at teachers, managers and students, seeking to expand integration of programs and policies, in order to promote equality and quality at all levels of education. 2023 Narrative: The project aims to provide subsidies to the Ministry of Education for the implementation of integrated policies and programs, monitoring and evaluation of actions aimed at the development and strengthening of Brazilian education through actions aimed at teachers, managers and students, seeking to expand integration of programs and policies, in order to promote equality and quality at all levels of education. Additionally, the present project aims to support the implementation of the National Policy for the Recovery of Learning in Basic Education with technical support in obtaining data and developing methodologies for institutional strengthening of the education sector in Brazil.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened by the Brazilian Ministry of Education, with the support of UNESCO, to improve the implementation of the National Policy for the Recovery of Learning in Basic Education, as well as other integrated programmes, policies and initiatives that promote equality and quality at all levels of education. Throughouth the year, a large set of data was analysed from multiple data gathering workshops held in 2023 in twelve Brazilian cities, as well as from 75 questionnaires collected during the 47th Annual Meeting of Federal Vocational Education Institutions Leaders (REDITEC). As a result, a technical report has been developed to identify key findinds and needs. Finally, within the scope ot the partnership, the present and future of the international education architecture was debated by 650 participants, including 60+ Ministers of Education, during the Global Education Meeting (GEM), which took place on October 31, November 1, and 2.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1151 Digital Education and Combined Prevention Strategies for STI/HIV/AIDS implemented in the city of São Paulo
Description:
"This Technical Cooperation Project aims to implement innovative strategies and develop new Combined Prevention strategies and digital education in the fight against STI/HIV/AIDS, mainly for the most vulnerable and priority populations, with the prevention, information, and education actions aimed at reducing transmission of HIV and other STIs.
The project hopes there will be a reduction in the number of cases of transmission of HIV and other Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs), mainly in the most vulnerable populations, especially trans and transvestites, gays, and other men who have sex with men (MSM)."
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Municipal Government of São Paulo
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: This initiative focuses on gender equality and gender mainstreaming, as it seeks to guarantee access to condoms. However, other alternatives to HIV prevention strategies, such as combined prevention and focus on the most vulnerable populations, are always considered.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity), Children , Other, Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.)
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO carried out a study to provide data for and evaluate STI and HIV/AIDS prevention and clinical follow-up actions, and developed strategies to prevent HIV/AIDS and other STIs, especially among trans population. The agency also provided the technical evaluation of strategic projects with the civil society, community leaders, and cultural groups aimed at promoting strategies to reduce HIV infection. Additionally, UNESCO developed strategies with projects for Support Houses for People Living with HIV/AIDS, as well as guidelines for strengthening prevention actions for the most vulnerable and at-risk populations for STI/HIV/Aids. A study was carried out to enable access to information and prevention supplies for the most vulnerable population and innovative strategies to increase access to information were developed, as well as other strategies related to combined HIV prevention for the most vulnerable populations.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened by the Municipal Government of São Paulo city, with the support of UNESCO, to implement digital education and combined prevention strategies in STI/HIV/AIDS in São Paulo. In 2024, remarkable achievements were made, as LNOB groups (such as LGBTQI+ communities, sex workers and people who use drugs) have been directly benefiting from the project, and access to health and prevention supplies in vulnerable territories and at alternative times has been granted. A study to provide data for and evaluate STI and HIV/AIDS prevention and clinical follow-up actions has been carried out, and strategies to prevent HIV/AIDS and other STIs, especially among transvestites and transsexuals, were developed. Additionally, studies were developed to better understand the dynamics of HIV epidemic amongst targeted vulnerable population, and education, communication, and information strategies on health education and HIV prevention were developed and implemented.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1152 Knowledge and data produced to assess the quality of education progress in Brazil
Description: This project aims to produce knowledge and data that contribute to the education quality progress in Brazil. The results obtained should serve as subsidy to the Ministry of Education for the planning and implementation of an innovative, quality, inclusive and equitable educational policy for the country.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: This project aims to produce knowledge and data that contribute to the education quality progress in Brazil. The results obtained should serve as subsidy to the Ministry of Education for the planning and implementation of an innovative, quality, inclusive and equitable educational policy for the country.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened by the Brazilian Ministry of Education, with the support of UNESCO, to produce knowledge and data to assess the quality of education progress in Brazil. As the project has been terminated in 2024, technical assistance and knowledge sharing have been delivered, inter alia, to better assess the processes related to the qualification of social organizations as per Law No. 9.637, of May 15, 1998, and Decree No. 9.190, of November 1, 2017, including an analysis of the legal framework (normative, objectives, and competencies) and institutional memory of such processes. In-depth research was carried out to better understand the practices and methodologies for pricing educational services, as well as to analyze state-level capacities to reach educational goals as recommended by the methodology used by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) to generate indicators for vocational education and training (VET). A national strategy for the prioritization of policy actionsto support the best allocation of resources was also proposed, detailing steps by region, state, and policy. Key instruments for the implementation of important national programmes, such as "Pé de Meia" and "Mulheres Mil" were developed to ensure compliance with the General Data Protection Law (LGPD). A survey was also carried out to gather information on the data dictionaries available under the Bolsa Família programme, the Population Census, and Caixa Econômica Federal's requirements for social account openings, along with a methodology for cross-referencing these data sets.

2022 Narrative: To establish green spaces in primary schools to teach students and teachers how conserve endemic and indigenous flora and build resilience against the adverse impacts of climate change.      - Launched the climate change textbook “Let’s Make A Difference – A Caribbean Primer on Climate Change’ developed in consultation with the Ministry of Education. - Portable tents were issued to four (4) schools equipped with portable solar generators to be utilized for their reading gardens.    - Automatic Weather Stations installed to World Meteorological Organization Standard and now providing data within the network of national and global climate observing system. Schools are using the stations for the study of weather and climate, they have engaged neighbouring schools so that the benefits extend well beyond the immediate beneficiaries.

Description: The project aims to support the National Education Development Fund (FNDE) by improving the management of the Articulated Actions Program (PAR), providing technical assistance to States and Municipalities that are implementing PAR funds, and building 120 schools for indigenous and traditional quilombola communities.
Agencies: United Nations Office for Project Services
Implementation partners: #BR National Fund for Educational Development
SDG Targets: 4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The project will carry out a human rights analysis and will work to guarantee effective participation for stakeholders due to a free, prior and informed consent process. The project is to build schools in indigenous and quilombolas communities contributing to the fulfilment of the right of education.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: In 2024 the project carried out infrastructure and social assessments of 17 incomplete schools in indigenous communities in Pará, Roraima and Maranhão. The assessments include recommendations on the best solutions for completing each school. The project started the bidding process for the construction of 10 schools in Pará and Roraima, the process will conclude in 2025. The project also developed a preliminary design for schools adapated to the context of indigenous and quilombolsa communities.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: 4. Governança e Capacidades Institucionais
Outcome: 4.1 Em 2027, o Brasil terá fortalecido, no marco do estado democrático de direito, sua governança, legislação, capacidades e articulação institucionais com ampliação da participação popular para elaborar e executar políticas públicas baseadas em evidências, em direitos humanos e igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia, com vistas à prevenção e ao enfrentamento à corrupção, ao crime e às múltiplas formas de violência, e orientadas às especificidades do território e à transparência, com inovação, cooperação nacional e internacional, e ampla participação da sociedade.
Output: 4.1.3 Capacidades institucionais fortalecidas para políticas públicas e programas para reduzir as múltiplas formas de criminalidade e violência contra públicos mais afetados e em situação de vulnerabilidade, com especial atenção à violência baseada em gênero e à discriminação racial e contra as juventudes, junto com a provisão de serviços de assistência social e acesso à justiça especializados para vítimas, suas famílias e comunidades.
Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ3050 Public policies on human rights and culture of peace of the city of São Paulo improved through Innovation for human rights education
Description: The following project is a partnership between the Human Rights and Citizenship Secretariat (Secretaria de Direitos Humanos e Cidadania de Sao Paulo) and the UNESCO Brasilia Office. The project is expected to improve the city policies on human rights and culture of peace by reinforcing the concept of "right to the city" and also reinforcing the transversality of human rights throughout all city secretariats, particularly the municipal education secretariat.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Municipal Government of São Paulo
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output has limited consideration for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment (GEWE). Although there might be planned activities targeting women in light of persistent gender inequalities, the contribution to GEWE is minor compared to the overall outcomes. Sex-disaggregated indicators are available for some activities, and the project adopts a gender-sensitive approach during its implementation phase, including the hiring of staff, consultants, and participants in activities where applicable.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Regarding the realisation of human rights, various social groups in situations of vulnerability are the targets of public policies developed by São Paulo City Hall. For the purposes of this international technical cooperation project, priority was given to areas that are often invisible and deserve full investment in Human Rights Education (HRE): the homeless population, the alcohol and other drug-using population and the LGBTI population.  São Paulo is the largest city in the southern hemisphere and the 6th most populous in the world, with over 12 million inhabitants. With a Human Development Index (HDI) of 0.805, according to the Atlas of Human Development (2010), São Paulo is ranked 28th out of more than 5,500 municipalities in Brazil.  When it comes to strategies for promoting Human Rights Education in the city, it is necessary to disseminate the subject as a field of study that works to train critical individuals capable of reflecting on and transforming the reality that surrounds them. It is an area of knowledge that is related to both formal and non-formal education practices. In Brazil and São Paulo, the basic documents are the National Guidelines for Human Rights Education and the National Plan for Human Rights Education.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Children , LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity), Youth, Women & Girls, Other, Minorities
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO organized a set of capacity-building activities, together with other teaching materials, which were produced in 2023. Activities related to human rights education, however, were not implemented in the current year.
2024 Narrative: Due to setbacks caused by managerial changes, limited progress has been made to enhance public policies on human rights and culture of peace through innovation for human rights education, with the support of UNESCO. However, immediate actions were taken to meet the outlined goals in in the newly agreed deadline.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1102 Innovative actions to promote Higher Education improved
Description: This project aims to promote Brazilian higher education by improving innovative actions implemented by the Ministry of Education's Secretariat of Higher Education (SESu). The project proposal consists in expanding new methodologies for teachers' and managers' training; studies evaluating access, permanence and insertion in the labor market; improvement of health residency programs; incentive to improve academic-institutional management; and strategies internationalization for higher education.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Considering that the enrollment profile of women in Brazilian public universities is predominantly concentrated on women, this population group is at the center of the actions developed by the project.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO carried out a series of studies to improve innovative actions implemented by the Ministry of Education. Such studies include:- Studies on the effectiveness of public universities and higher education institutions on the National Student Assistance Program - PNAES- Studies analyze flows and methodologies to provide further eficiency and effectiveness to tax regularity within the scope of the University for All Program (Prouni).- Study to analyze the impacts of COVID-19 on the internationalization actions of Brazilian Federal Institutions of Higher Education (IFES). - Analytical study for the adequacy of public universities in the context of the vacancies offered and the number of first-year students.- Analytical study regarding the redistribution of vacancy posts among Public universities. - Study to identify the impacts of COVID-19 on the Student-Graduate Agreement Program (PEC-G) and the Milton Santos Program for Access to Higher Education (PROMISES).- Study on the demands of parliamentarians on higher education;- Study on the judicialization of higher education.- Study on the benefits of financing low-income higher education students.- Study to analyze the areas that demand the most higher education professionals and need public policies to promote them.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened by the Ministry of Education, with the support of UNESCO, to promote quality education by improving innovative actions on the Brazilian Higher Education system. Technical advice and knowledge sharing were delivered to propose and disseminate new methodologies for training teachers and managers, assess programmes focused on the access and insertion of learners in the labour market, improve residency programmes in fields of health, to advance academic-institutional management, and to improve higher education internationalization strategies. A series of technical studies were carried out to assess, inter alia, th effectiveness of public universities and higher education institutions on the National Student Assistance Program (PNAES), the impacts of COVID-19 on the internationalization actions of Brazilian Federal Institutions of Higher Education (IFES), and the adequacy of public universities in the context of the vacancies offered and the number of first-year students.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 570BRZ1020 Free and accessible education promoted through the consolidation of "Educação Livre" Platform
Description: This project aims to promote free access to quality education by expanding and improving the EduLivre social technology platform. It seeks to revise its content and methodologies in an accessible, attractive and entertaining way, in order to contribute to the proficiency of competences and skills for the 21st century world of work, with a main focus on socio-emotional development, entrepreneurship, and the areas of languages, mathematics and natural sciences. The initiative also seeks to develop an ecosystem that connects various players to generate study and work opportunities for Brazilian youth, as well as promoting the creation of communities and communication strategies that generate engagement, scalability and sustainability for the Project's actions.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: #BR Serviço Social da Indústria
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth

Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNESCO and the contributed partner have supported the Member State in promoving free access to quality education, in line with the Sustainable Development Goal 4 and national priorities. The implementation of diverse initiatives under the SESI Network's Digital Transformation and Educação Livre Projects has yielded impactful results across multiple domains. Through robust monitoring and controlling mechanisms, the Digital Transformation Program for Documentation Services and the School Management System Program in 24 Regional SESI Departments have enhanced operational efficiency. The integration of data analysis and innovative pedagogical strategies in the Educação Livre Project has improved educational outcomes, particularly in Mathematics, Humanities, Languages, and Natural Sciences, while inclusive education initiatives have strengthened equity and accessibility. Professional development programs for educators, coupled with specialized content for Youth and Adult Education, have elevated teaching quality. Strategic advancements, such as the modernization of learning spaces, governance model development, and full-stack technological enhancements, have streamlined project execution. Additionally, effective communication, content creation, and compliance measures have amplified stakeholder engagement and transparency, reinforcing the SESI Network's commitment to excellence in education and strategic project management.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1085 Intersectionality between education and health promotion improved in Rio Grande do Norte
Description: This technical cooperation project aims to strengthen the planning actions that expand the intersectionality between education and health. This project also aims to guarantee access and enhance care in an integrated and intersectoral network of promotion, education, and social community at the RN + SAUDÁVEL Program, anchored by four priority axes: Culture of Peace, Healthy Lifestyles, Healthy Environments, and Equity/inclusion.
