2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO assessed the epidemiological situation of the indigenous people, developed educational material for HIV prevention and other STIs for the Potiguar indigenous group, and held a seminar on health promotion, benefiting 400 professionals from the education and health areas, as well as CSOs and local networks.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, institutional capacities were strengthened in the state of Rio Grande do Norte to promote quality education by developing innovative solutions with the support of UNESCO. Education and health professionals were equipped with training and expertise sharing opportunities to better implement the tool "Healthy Eating and Family Farming in Schools". As a result, professionals are better equipped to promote healthy eating habits and value family farming in schools.

2024 Narrative: The project has successfully completed its first year, achieving significant milestones in line with its planned objectives. Institutional capacities to assess education in Brazil were improved through studies, expertise sharing and recommendations focused on PISA evaluation, and on the efficiency of FUNDEB, the basic education financing fund. Notably, the Brazilian Education Thesaurus was updated to ensure its alignment with contemporary educational needs. Additionally, studies on higher education assessment instruments have provided valuable insights for future improvements. The project remains on track, with activities progressing as scheduled.

Sub-Output: UNESCO 914BRZ1155 Inclusive education strengthened in Brazil
Description: This project aims to strengthen the programs and actions of the Secretariat for Continuing Education, Youth and Adult Literacy, Diversity and Inclusion (Secadi/MoE), promoting equity and acknowledging diversity in all education modalities and levels. Focus is given on: 1) bilingual education for the deaf people, 2) special from an inclusive perspective, 3) traditional communities (quilombolas), 4) rural education, 5) indigenous education, and 6) youth and adults education. The project has transversal achievements in human rights, education for ethnic-racial relations, environmental education and the target-audiences on education for youth and school inclusion of children and adolescents beneficiaries of the Bolsa Família Program.

2024 Narrative: In 2024, the State of Rio Grande do Sul, with the support of UNESCO, has made significant progress in strengthening the management of its education system to ensure equity, protection and inclusion of vulnerable groups to quality education, according to SDG 4 targets. Rio Grande do Sul's State Policy on School Care and Well-being was developed and implemented in alignment with the National Common Curricular Base (BNCC), oriented by learning socio-emotional skills to build a safe, welcoming, and resilient education network. A series of books and reports were also produced to record the management of the crisis caused by the 2024 climate disaster and its impact over the State Education Network in its various aspects, such as infrastructure, pedagogy, and socio-emotional aspects. Additionally, the School Contingency Plans was developed and implemented, and a series of technical documents, tools, and methodologies for diagnosing, planning, creating, executing, and monitoring of educational projects were preprared and disseminated.

2022 Narrative: "Supported the reform in primary education by extending primary with 2 orientation years, which also aims at building the system back better based on lessons learned from the effects of the COVID pandemic on education globally. In the area of education for children with disability, the UNICEF supported curriculum for special education at primary education level, and facility upgrading to serve as a testing and observation room for early detection of functional difficulties were implemented this year.   "
2023 Narrative: The last official education sector plan dates from 2008, and since then MoE has implemented numerous reforms in terms of among others education structure, content, assessments and pedagogy. A long-term plan however to align those reforms, particularly across ministerial terms, is lacking. This resulted in a flux of reforms being implemented and overturned without sufficient implementation time which made it challenging for students, parents and teachers to cope with the continuous changing environment. Capitalizing on the momentum for policy development in the ministry this year, the CO is supporting MoE with the de development of an education policy 2030 based on reflections of what worked until now, what can be to sustained and strengthen, and what needs to be modified to ensure the education system is resilient and caters to the development of student’s talents.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: PE1 Alcanzar el bienestar, el goce de derechos y la inclusión social,  con especial énfasis en las poblaciones en condición de  vulnerabilidad.
Outcome: E1 Al 2026, las personas, especialmente aquellas en situación  de mayor vulnerabilidad y exclusión, tienen acceso equitativo  a educación, salud, servicios sociales y sistemas de  protección social integral, contribuyendo a la reducción de la  pobreza multidimensional y de las brechas de desigualdad  en todas sus manifestaciones.
Output: E1P2 El MINEDUCYT y las instituciones públicas seleccionadas tienen capacidades fortalecidas  para expandir la oferta y el acceso a la educación de forma pertinente, relevante, equitativa,  inclusiva, laica, multimodal y de calidad, así como para aumentar la conectividad y el uso de  tecnologías; para prevenir la deserción escolar y el trabajo infantil y promover la transición y  finalización exitosa del ciclo escolar; incluyendo la educación integral de la sexualidad, con  enfoque en las poblaciones en condiciones de vulnerabilidad garantizando el acceso universal y  la participación de personas con discapacidad34, jóvenes, mujeres, población LGBTIQ+, así como  pueblos indígenas, permitiéndole al país el aprovechamiento del bono demográfico.
Sub-Output: Scholarships for Educational Opportunities Program
Description:
El proyecto buscará mitigar la migración irregular desde El Salvador y reducir la estigmatización de los retornados al aumentar el acceso equitativo a oportunidades educativas formales para posibles migrantes, retornados y sus familias para generar esperanza, prosperidad y autoestima positiva en sus vidas.

El Sub-Output está alineado con las transiciones de Educación y Empleo y protección social.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: El Salvador Ministerio de Educación, Ciencia y Tecnología

Gender marker narrative: The project promotes activities linked to gender equity through its academic offerings. Women are a prioritized population for enrollment, in particular in non-traditional areas, and individual psychosocial support is delivered considering gender needs. A referral mechanism is in place for specialized assistance related to Gender-Based-Violence (GBV). For women in the scholarship program, the psychological service constitutes a key support for their wellbeing and selfcare, as well as an increase in knowledge and empowerment. In addition, psychosocial services for women contributes to retention, empowerment for employment, and in some cases helps to reduce the pressure from their partners to migrate irregularly.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Human rights approach is considered directly by providing education right to vulnerable population and out-school persons. It is algo a crosscutting theme for psychosocial assistance, including referrals and partnership with human rights specialized institutions.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Los principios transversales relevantes del proyecto son: 1) empoderamiento de las mujeres y equidad de género y 2) desarrollo positivo de juventudes. Esto se toma en cuenta con base en un breve análisis coyuntural, plasmado en el documento de proyecto, que aborda el conflicto o la violencia de la siguiente forma: Una considerable proporción de migrantes irregulares son jóvenes. Esto es debido a necesidades económicas por ausencia de oportunidades, por violencia y por inseguridad; además, muchos jóvenes son objetivos para ser reclutados por pandillas... En este sentido, el proyecto facilita oportunidades educacionales a jóvenes migrantes para garantizar  su desarrollo positivo a través del acceso a trabajo formal y medios de vida.
2023 Narrative: Para diciembre de 2023, el Proyecto facilitó el acceso a empleo/nuevos emprendimientos nuevos o mejorados para 479 beneficiarios de becas (42% hombres, 58% mujeres): 383 becarios (39% hombres y 61% mujeres) accedieron a nuevas actividades laborales/emprendimientos y 96 becarios (55% hombres y 45% mujeres) mejoraron la percepción de la calidad de sus empleos/emprendimientos.  Un total de 2,505 becarios estaban inscritos en los programas educativos: cursos cortos, programas educativos técnicos superiores y programas de educación acelerada.
2024 Narrative: El proyecto brindó oportunidades educativas integrales a 1,909 personas en riesgo de desplazamiento y en condiciones de vulnerabilidad, con el objetivo de reducir la migración irregular y fomentar la esperanza, la prosperidad y la autoestima en sus vidas. Esto incluye a 427 migrantes retornados. Para el año 2024, el proyecto ha alcanzado un total de 7,155 personas desde su inicio.

2022 Narrative: The CO continued to support the ministry in catching up on processing of educational data for the release of statistical yearbooks. The 2020 yearbook was released, and the 2021 yearbook is expected this year as well. The EMIS webportal is further being expanded with additional education indicators including for WASH in schools as well as data collection in line with the Joint Monitoring Program (JMP) standards. With this support in its is expected that Suriname will be able to provide validated WASH in Schools data nationally for the first time to feed into the global JMP database.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued to support the ministry in catching up on processing of educational data for the release of statistical yearbooks. The 2019-2021 yearbook was finalized and expected to be released this year. The EMIS web portal was further improved, and adjustments are being made to align to the structural reforms that were implemented from 2021 onwards.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: MSDCF 4.3: National institutions strengthened to deliver shock-resilient education and learning
Sub-Output: GUY 4.3.7 Education Planning and Monitoring- Evidence Generation through the national Out of School Study, Capacity building in EMIS for Education Officers & Head Teachers; technical support to  Mid-term Review of  Education sector Plan (ESP)
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Guyana Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: Through UNICEF support, local capacity for data-driven decision making in Education was strengthened. As part of these efforts, EMIS training was provided to 92 head teachers, teachers, and data entry clerks from 24 schools (6 nursery, 16 primary and 2 secondary), allowing for the electronic tracking of 4,685 students' records including attendance. This support benefitted 11 schools in region 1, one of Guyana's interior indigenous regions. Schools with internet connectivity now have the ability to update students' records in real-time while others can utilize the offline EMIS capability which gets updated on a monthly basis. From this support, enrollment and attendance information is readily available at the school level for both teachers and students and can be used for informed planning and resource allocation in order to improve education outcomes. While underway, the out of school study in Guyana was postponed for an indefinite amount of time due to a shift in Government priorities. UNICEF will continue to advocate for up-to-date information on out of school children in Guyana including information on those at risk of dropping out.

Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Suriname Ministry of Education, Science and Culture
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Women & Girls, Persons With Disabilities, Youth, Indigenous Peoples, Minorities
2022 Narrative: Supported the reform in primary education by extending primary with 2 orientation years, which also aims at building the system back better based on lessons learned from the effects of the COVID pandemic on education globally. In the area of education for children with disability, the UNICEF supported curriculum for special education at primary education level, and facility upgrading to serve as a testing and observation room for early detection of functional difficulties were implemented this year.
2023 Narrative: 45 teachers from 10 schools along the Marowijne border with French-Guyana successfully completed the Basis level course in French with the aim of supporting students with French as a supportive language of instruction.Extra-curricular program developed for grades 6, 7 and 8 in the subjects of language, math and life skills education (ICT in Class) and provision of readers and assignments (educational material) provided to test the program implementation in 1 school. Extra-curricular skills development short practical classes for students in primary in microbiology and agriculture conducted in 3 districts reaching 600 students.Readers for all courses developed for improving uniformity (vocational and general education stream) of content delivery across schools that provide education in grades 9 and 10 (for 22 subjects a reader for grade 9 and 10 was developed). All (150) lower secondary schools (vocational and general education stream) received a memory stick with the 22 readers in soft copy. With the workshop covering the readers for grade 9 and 10, 75 school leaders and 75 teachers were reached and participating schools subsequently (teachers) conducted a knowledge sharing session for their team. A 2-day workshop conducted for the inspectorate on the education innovations and the role of the inspectorate to improve the implementation of reforms in schools.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: 4. Governança e Capacidades Institucionais
Outcome: 4.1 Em 2027, o Brasil terá fortalecido, no marco do estado democrático de direito, sua governança, legislação, capacidades e articulação institucionais com ampliação da participação popular para elaborar e executar políticas públicas baseadas em evidências, em direitos humanos e igualdade de geração, gênero, raça e etnia, com vistas à prevenção e ao enfrentamento à corrupção, ao crime e às múltiplas formas de violência, e orientadas às especificidades do território e à transparência, com inovação, cooperação nacional e internacional, e ampla participação da sociedade.
Output: 4.1.3 Capacidades institucionais fortalecidas para políticas públicas e programas para reduzir as múltiplas formas de criminalidade e violência contra públicos mais afetados e em situação de vulnerabilidade, com especial atenção à violência baseada em gênero e à discriminação racial e contra as juventudes, junto com a provisão de serviços de assistência social e acesso à justiça especializados para vítimas, suas famílias e comunidades.
Sub-Output: UNDP BRA/23/017 Innovation strengthened and monitored in the penal and socio-educational systems, in line with national and international human rights principles and guidelines
Description: Develop innovative methodologies and actions to reestablish the regular functioning of the prison and socio-educational systems. Actions will also produce subsidies to strengthen the monitoring and inspection of official interventions on these systems, in line with national and international human rights principles and guidelines.
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: #BR National Council of Justice
SDG Targets: 16.3 Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.,16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Normative Support, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The gender perspective will be transversal throughout the implementation of the project, with emphasis on the production of data, preparation of studies and proposal of new plans/actions based on studies carried out through judicial policies.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: This project is a direct response to the need to give new meaning to the role of the Judiciary, as an instance of promoting and protecting human rights, focusing on action centered on the jurisdiction, ensuring that each person, regardless of their position or circumstance, is treated with respect , justice and dignity in its interface with the penal and socio-educational systems, and that these systems correspond to the judiciary with efficiency, speed and recognizing the importance, meaning and significance of all these individualities.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2024 Narrative: This initiative is the second stage of the “UNDP BRA/18/019 (UNODC) Strengthened monitoring and supervision of the Prison and Socio-Educational System by CNJ” that will cease its activities in 2025. Results are shared by both suboutputs in 2024. On the promotion of human rights, the National Action for Civil Identification for Persons Deprived of Liberty reached a total of 297,259 people by July 2024, approximately 45% of the country’s prison population. The partnership also promoted the 5th Literary Journey in Prisons, reaching around 8,000 people within 253 prison units, and the 3rd Literary Journey on the socio-educational system, reaching 78 units and 1,500 people on its launch day.  Over 11,800 magistrates, judicial officers, members of the Public Prosecutor’s Office, public defenders, and professionals from secretariat’s of Criminal Policy joined trainings on the system that facilitates the integration of criminal enforcement proceedings throughout the country (SEEU).

Outcome: ED2. Al 2025, la población, en especial la que está en condiciones de mayor vulnerabilidad, ejerce plenamente sus derechos a la salud, educación, cultura, vivienda, alimentación, protección social y de cuidados, y accede a servicios universales y a un sistema integral de cuidados de calidad.
Output: Pr2.3. Sub-Output: Promoting basic literacy skills in primary education
Description: In recent assesments, Mexico has shown that primary education students do not have the necessary language skills, with school closure due to the Covid 19 pandemic, this issue has deepened. The office has been working with vulnerable populations to ensure development of literacy basic skills and competencies. In addition, we will be working specifically with migrants in coordination with San Jose an Guatemala offices to ensure a strategy for education of migrants that is contextualized to the specific challenges in this region. Finally, we are working in the response to the Hurricane in Guerrero that impacted at least 600 schools in November 2023.

Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation

Geography: Coahuila de Zaragoza, Sinaloa, Sonora, Mexico, Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, Nuevo León, Tamaulipas, Yucatán, Querétaro de Arteaga, Guanajuato, Guerrero

Sub-Output: Case Study: An innovative proposal for education transformation in vulnerable contexts
Description: The Social Model for Strengthening Educational Communities, is an initiative of the Alberto Baillères Foundation, following the 2017 earthquakes in Mexico. Its intention is to promote education in vulnerable areas through the construction of educational habitats. This concept integrates innovative and high-quality infrastructure, and the generation of socio-community processes involving the entire community. Since 2019, UNESCO Mexico has provided technical assistance for the development and consolidation of the model, showcasing evidence to contribute to SDG 4 and the 2030 Agenda. The purpose is to expand collaboration, consolidate the Model and develop the rural chapter.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Derecho a la educación de calidad
2024 Narrative: The Social Model is implemented in 19 schools in vulnerable locations in two educational subsystems, in three states: Mexico City, the State of Mexico and Yucatán. By 2024, 10,373 students (5,295 women and 5,078 men), 831 teachers and management staff, and 19,775 family members have benefited directly.The assistance provided by UNESCO included: The conceptual and methodological review of its proposal; and as a result, the design of the National Accompaniment Standard for the strengthening and transformation of educational communities, endorsed by the Ministry of Public Education and the first of its kind in Mexico.An evaluating instrument for the progress of educational communities by stages (initial, in process, developing, advanced and sustainable). This instrument represents an important achievement for the systematization and dissemination of results in similar experiences. Dissemination and learning exchange in at least three national or regional meetings.

Sub-Output: Innovation Laboratory for the Development of Education Public Policies
Description: UNESCO Mexico, at the request of the Ministry of Education of Guanajuato, will provide technical assistance to support the implementation of the "Laboratory of Educational Innovation for the Development of Public Policies", in order to strengthen the actions established in the Social Pact for Education. UNESCO will also seek connections between the educational policies of the state Ministry of Education with the 2030 Agenda. Finally, UNESCO will support the construction of new alliances between the public, public- private and civil society spheres to achieve the goals, particularly to address the problems of school dropout, lag in learning, and the lack of specific support for teachers.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: Mx- Gobierno del Estado de Guanajuato
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Sensible al género
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Derecho a la educación de calidad
